Allocation of Income, Gains, Losses and Distributions Income from investments in cash equivalents will be allocated and distributed among the partners in proportion to their investment percentages with respect to such investments. All other distributable cash received from investments will be allocated among the partners in proportion to each partner’s funding percentage to the Partnership’s total invested capital in the investment. Per the Assignment and Admission Agreement, the General Partner’s entitled allocation to carried interest payments will be distributed to the Special Limited Partner after the effective date of January 1, 2018. The amount initially allocated to SCS, either directly or indirectly through the PH Blocker (together with SCS, the “SCS LP”), will then be reallocated as follows: (a) First, 100% to the SCS LP until the cumulative distributions pursuant to this clause (a) from all portfolio investments that have been disposed of equal the aggregate of the following: (i) the SCS LP’s aggregate capital contributions that were used to fund the purchase of all portfolio investments, including allocable partnership expenses that have been disposed of, including the pro rata portion of the acquisition cost of any portfolio investments that have been partially disposed of; (ii) the SCS LP’s aggregate capital contributions that were used to fund the purchase of all portfolio investments, including allocable partnership expenses, other than the portfolio investments referred to in (i), in respect of which the Partnership’s carrying value is less than the Partnership’s cost of such portfolio investments; and (iii) the SCS LP’s proportionate share of the cumulative fees and expense borne by the Partnership that is allocable to the portfolio investments referred to in (i) and (ii). (b) Second, 100% to the SCS LP until the SCS LP receives cumulative distributions equal to a cumulative compounded preferred return of 6% per annum on its capital contributions to SCS with respect to the outstanding amounts described in (a) above (the “Preferred Return”); (c) Third, 100% to the General Partner and the Special Limited Partner until the General Partner and the Special Limited Partner receive cumulative distributions equal to 10% of the total amounts apportioned pursuant to clause (b) above and this clause (c); and confidential Delphine Bonfanti seinecap.com Feb 02, 2024 12:25 PM EST confidential Delphine Bonfanti seinecap.com Feb 02, 2024 12:25 PM EST 17 Proprietary and Confidential HAMILTON LANE STRATEGIC OPPORTUNITIES 2017 FUND HOLDINGS LP Notes to Financial Statements December 31, 2022 (d) Thereafter, 90% to the SCS LP and 10% to the combined General Partner and Special Limited Partner, as defined in the Assignment and Admission Agreement. The Limited Partnership Agreement of SCS dated August 8, 2016 provides that, if upon dissolution of the Partnership, distributions have been made to the Special Limited Partner pursuant to clauses (c) and (d) above (“Carried Interest Payments”), and either (i) such SCS LP has not received cumulative distributions equal to the sum of its total capital contributions and its Preferred Return with respect to all investments, or (ii) the Carried Interest Payments exceed 10% of (A) the amounts that would have been distributed to such SCS LP if there had not been any Carried Interest Payments, less (B) the SCS LP’s total capital contributions, then the General Partner will contribute to the Partnership for distribution to the SCS LP an amount equal to the lesser of (x) the amounts described in (a) (i) and (a) (ii) above, or (y) the cumulative Carried Interest Payments made to the General Partner and the Special Limited Partner (net of certain income taxes). Per the Assignment and Admission Agreement, the Special Limited Partner assumes and agrees to discharge the pro rata portion applicable to the General Partner of any amounts described in this paragraph, determined by reference to total Carried Interest Payments received by the Special Limited Partner and the General Partner. Income, Gains and Losses Income, gains and losses are generally allocated among the partners in the ratio in which the corresponding cash is distributable, as outlined above. The General Partner and Special Limited Partner do not participate in the net income or net loss, or any distributions of the Partnership, other than for the Carried Interest Payments discussed above. For the period ended December 31, 2022, the Special Limited Partner was allocated $(17,105) of unrealized carried interest. This amount, which is reflected in the accompanying financial statements, was calculated based on the Partnership’s results of operations from inception of the Partnership through December 31, 2022, including unrealized appreciation / depreciation on the Partnership’s portfolio investments as of December 31, 2022. The cumulative unrealized carried interest amount allocated to the Special Limited Partner and the General Partner from the inception of the Partnership through December 31, 2022 totaled $439,716. confidential Delphine Bonfanti seinecap.com Feb 02, 2024 12:25 PM EST confidential Delphine Bonfanti seinecap.com Feb 02, 2024 12:25 PM EST 18 Proprietary and Confidential HAMILTON LANE STRATEGIC OPPORTUNITIES 2017 FUND HOLDINGS LP Notes to Financial Statements December 31, 2022 The Agreement also provides that the Partnership may make distributions to the Special Limited Partner to provide them with funds to pay applicable federal, state and local income tax liabilities attributable to the Partnership’s income allocated to them (“Tax Distribution”). The only distributions with respect to carried interest that the Special Limited Partner received from the period from inception to December 31, 2022, were Tax Distributions totaling $103,740, which are included in the Special Limited Partner’s capital account balance. The distributions are not required to be, nor does the Special Limited Partner intend to, return them to the Partnership as the Tax Distributions did not exceed the amount of taxes payable to taxing authorities by the Special Limited Partner on the income allocated to the Special Limited Partner. The carried interest amounts that will actually be paid to the General Partner and Special Limited Partner in the future will be based on the amounts ultimately realized from the Partnership’s remaining investments, and the payments may be different than the amount reflected in the accompanying financial statements, and the difference could be material. 5. Portfolio Investments Fund Investment As of December 31, 2022, the Partnership directly held one fund investment, the fair market value of which individually represents more than 5% of the Partnership’s net assets. Webster Capital II- A, L.P. (“Webster II-A”) invests in lower middle-market healthcare services and branded consumer opportunities. On a look through basis, there is one investment as of December 31, 2022 in which the Partnership’s indirect ownership represents more than 5% of the Partnership’s net assets. Webster II-A holds an investment, Discovery Behavioral Health, LLC, operator of residential behavioral health centers and represents 28.86% of the Partnership’s net assets. The Partnership’s fund investment is generally considered to be illiquid. The Partnership will achieve liquidity only as and when the fund sells its portfolio company investments and distribute the proceeds received from the disposition of those investments to the Partnership and the fund’s other investors. It is also possible for the Partnership to dispose of its interests in the fund investments in the secondary market. Unfunded Commitment The Partnership's fund investment is summarized on the Schedule of Fund Investment. As of December 31, 2022, the Partnership has no outstanding unfunded commitments to fund investments. confidential Delphine Bonfanti seinecap.com Feb 02, 2024 12:25 PM EST confidential Delphine Bonfanti seinecap.com Feb 02, 2024 12:25 PM EST 19 Proprietary and Confidential HAMILTON LANE STRATEGIC OPPORTUNITIES 2017 FUND HOLDINGS LP Notes to Financial Statements December 31, 2022 Direct Investments The Partnership’s direct investments are generally considered to be illiquid investments. The Partnership will achieve liquidity only as and when the investor group that owns each investment, and which the Partnership is a member of, sells the portfolio company. Supplemental Investment Disclosures The following tables categorize the Partnership’s direct investments by country and industry as of December 31, 2022: Percentage of Net Cost Fair Value Partners’ Capital Country United States 119,022,002 $ 98,271,526 $ 69.25% 119,022,002 $ 98,271,526 $ 69.25% Industry Consumer discretionary 55,125,050 $ 54,835,846 $ 38.64% Financials 30,169,789 35,596,741 25.09 Healthcare - 3,239,460 2.28 Information technology 33,727,163 4,599,479 3.24 119,022,002 $ 98,271,526 $ 69.25% Fair Value Measurements The Partnership valued its investments, in the absence of observable market prices, using the valuation methodologies described in Note 2. One of the Partnership’s portfolio investments, Webster II-A, is valued using net asset value as a practical expedient. The General Partner’s determination of fair values is based on the best information available in the circumstances and involves significant management judgment. Because of the inherent uncertainties involved in the valuation of investments that are not publicly traded, the resultant estimated values may differ significantly from the values that would have been used had observable market prices for the investments existed, and the differences could be material. In accordance with ASC 820, investments measured and reported at fair value are classified and disclosed in one of the following categories: Level I – Quoted prices are available in active markets for identical investments as of the reporting date. The types of investments which would generally be included in Level I include listed equities. confidential Delphine Bonfanti seinecap.com Feb 02, 2024 12:25 PM EST confidential Delphine Bonfanti seinecap.com Feb 02, 2024 12:25 PM EST 20 Proprietary and Confidential HAMILTON LANE STRATEGIC OPPORTUNITIES 2017 FUND HOLDINGS LP Notes to Financial Statements December 31, 2022 Level II – Pricing inputs are other than quoted prices in active markets, which are either directly or indirectly observable as of the reporting date, and fair value is determined through the use of models or other valuation methodologies. The types of investments which would generally be included in Level II include corporate bonds and loans, currency option contracts, and less liquid and restricted equity securities. This category also includes interests in special purpose vehicles whose fair value is predominantly attributable to investments in Level I type securities. Level III – Pricing inputs are unobservable for the investment and include situations where there is little, if any, market activity for the investment. The inputs into the determination of fair value require significant management judgment or estimation. Those unobservable inputs, that are not corroborated by market data, generally reflect the reporting entity’s own assumptions about the assumptions market participants would use in determining the fair value of the investment. The types of investments which would generally be included in Level III include equity and/or debt securities issued by private entities and investments in private equity partnerships. In situations where the inputs used to measure fair value fall into different levels of the fair value hierarchy, an investment’s level within the fair value hierarchy is based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement. The following table summarizes the Partnership’s portfolio investments measured at fair value on a recurring basis by the above fair value hierarchy levels as of December 31, 2022: Level I Level II Level III Total Debt securities - $ - $ 38,861,996 $ 38,861,996 $ Member and limited partner interests - 3,686,666 35,149,535 38,836,201 Equity securities - - 20,573,329 20,573,329 Total - $ 3,686,666 $ 94,584,860 $ 98,271,526 Other investments measured at net asset value (A) 41,701,788 Total portfolio investments 139,973,314 $ Note (A) In accordance with Accounting Standards Update 2015-07, certain investments that are measured at fair value using the net asset value per share (or its equivalent) practical expedient have not been classified in the fair value hierarchy. The fair value amounts presented in this table are intended to permit reconciliation of the fair value hierarchy to the amounts presented on the Statement of Assets, Liabilities and Partners’ Capital. There were no transfers into or out of Level III during the period ended December 31, 2022. confidential Delphine Bonfanti seinecap.com Feb 02, 2024 12:25 PM EST confidential Delphine Bonfanti seinecap.com Feb 02, 2024 12:25 PM EST 21 Proprietary and Confidential HAMILTON LANE STRATEGIC OPPORTUNITIES 2017 FUND HOLDINGS LP Notes to Financial Statements December 31, 2022 The following table provides quantitative measures used to determine the fair values of the Level III investments as of December 31, 2022: Note (A) A valuation in this industry is based on a recent transaction, generally defined as investments purchased within six months of valuation date or a pending transaction with an expected close date after the valuation date. 6. Operating Expenses The Agreement provides that the Partnership is responsible for all of its own operating and administrative expenses, including out-of-pocket expenses of organizing, administration of the Partnership and organizational expenses. Expenses directly attributable to a particular portfolio investment will be allocated to the partners in accordance with their respective funding percentages with respect to such portfolio investment. The General Partner may allocate expenses among the partners differently if, and to the extent that such expenses are, in the reasonable discretion of the General Partner, solely or disproportionately attributable to one or more particular partners. 7. Related Party Transactions The Manager is entitled to receive a distribution management fee for its services related to the sale of securities received by the Partnership by way of distributions received in connection with the dispositions or other realizations of investments in an amount equal to 0.40% of the Limited Partners’ share of the net proceeds generated from such services. There were no distribution management fees incurred for the period ended December 31, 2022. At December 31, 2022, the Partnership had an amount receivable from affiliates of $290,764 for transfer for payment of management fees. Financial Highlights Financial highlights of the Partnership for the period ended December 31, 2022 for the Limited Partners are as follows: Ratios to average net assets: Net investment income (loss) 6.35% Expenses: Operating expenses 0.11% Carried interest allocation (0.01) Total operating expenses and carried interest allocation 0.10% Internal rates of return from inception through: December 31, 2022 11.01% January 1, 2022 12.22% The internal rates of return were computed based on the actual dates of the cash inflows (capital contributions) and outflows (distributions), and the ending Limited Partners’ capital account balances as of the measurement date (residual value). The net investment income (loss) and expense ratios were computed as a percentage of average net assets. Average net assets is the weighted average of the aggregate balances in the capital accounts of the Limited Partners during the period. Capital contributions were included from the date called and distributions were included from the date paid. Net income or loss allocable to the Limited Partners, including net change in unrealized appreciation / depreciation on portfolio investments, was included from the end of each quarter based on quarter-end valuations. Net investment income (loss) is the Limited Partners’ share of the Partnership’s investment income, net of the operating expenses incurred by the Partnership. The net investment income (loss) ratio does not reflect the effect of the carried interest allocation to the General Partner or the Special Limited Partner. Both the net investment income (loss) and operating expense ratios relate solely to the Partnership’s operations and do not reflect investment income or expenses of the portfolio investments in which the Partnership has invested. confidential Delphine Bonfanti seinecap.com Feb 02, 2024 12:25 PM EST confidential Delphine Bonfanti seinecap.com Feb 02, 2024 12:25 PM EST 23 Proprietary and Confidential HAMILTON LANE STRATEGIC OPPORTUNITIES 2017 FUND HOLDINGS LP Notes to Financial Statements December 31, 2022 The net investment income (loss) and expense ratios and the internal rates of return were calculated for the Limited Partner class taken as a whole. The calculations of such ratios and rates of return for individual limited partners may vary from these ratios and rates of return based on the timing of capital transactions for individual limited partners and varying funding percentages for some investments. 9. Subsequent Events The General Partner has evaluated events that occurred through March 29, 2023, which is the date these financial statements were available to be issued. There were no material events noted during this period that would require disclosure, except as discussed below. On March 10, 2023, Silicon Valley Bank, Santa Clara, California, was closed by the California Department of Financial Protection and Innovation, which appointed the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) as receiver. To protect insured depositors, the FDIC created the Deposit Insurance National Bank of Santa Clara (DINB). At the time of closing, the FDIC as receiver immediately transferred to the DINB all insured deposits of Silicon Valley Bank. As of March 29, 2023, the Partnership did not have cash exceeding the FDIC-insured limit at its account with Silicon Valley Bank. Management and the General Partner of the Partnership have evaluated the aforementioned circumstances for the Partnership and its portfolio companies and have concluded that no substantial doubt exists about the Partnership’s ability to continue as a going concern at the date the financial statements were available to be issued. confidential Delphine Bonfanti seinecap.com Feb 02, 2024 12:25 PM EST confidential Delphine Bonfanti seinecap.com Feb 02, 2024 12:25 PM EST;

[2025-03-17T12:04:19.825Z] MODEL: deepseek:deepseek-chat, USER: Unknown, REQUEST_TYPE: extract
Prompt:
Out of the following text, identify what financial variables are referenced, the text can be written in languages different than english, return me only the list of variables without the values

["var1", "var2", ...]

here is the text, return the name of the variables in english, also be consistent across names and try not to duplicate them, Im looking mostly for accounting variables
Also return the names of the variables in lower case and with underscores instead of spaces.

List first the variables that would be traditionally in an Income Statement, 
then the ones that would be in a Balance Sheet,
then the ones that would be in a Cash Flow Statement,
one that includes the description of the company, maximum one paragraph,
one that includes a variable that is the type of company, if it is a company or a fund, 
if the whole business of the company is to invest in other companies then consider it a fund.

(referred to as the “Company” or “Target”) for your investment decision . We are submitting this report as a result of the service we have performed . The Company and its management are responsible for the accuracy of the data provided by the sales advisor, while we assume no responsibility . ◆ We performed a video interview with the Company’s management once (July 10 , 2024 ) in accordance with the transaction procedures and conducted this service by receiving and responding to the Request for Information from the Company . ◆ Meanwhile, we have requested various data from the Company, including sales (POS data) information of franchise stores, delivery sales by franchise store, purchase status of franchise stores, and classification data related to changes in business divisions in previous years, but we have not yet received these data . Additionally, we have not received financial data from important business affiliates (logistics companies) during this service . Table of Contents CHAPTER I Scope of Work 03 CHAPTER II Executive Summary 06 CHAPTER III PL Analysis 18 CHAPTER IV BS Analysis 29 CHAPTER V Appendices 37 Strictly Private & Confidential l Nexia Samduk l 7 Target Overview Ogubonga Co . , Ltd . (the “Company”) was founded in November 2009 and runs a franchise business under the brand name of Ogu Rice Pizza . As of the due diligence date, it has 387 franchise stores across the country . The current organization is managed by five teams and 15 individuals, including the CEO and executives . Taking into account resignations and new hires in 2024 , it is projected to have around 10 employees in the future . Strictly Private & Confidential l Nexia Samduk l 9 Composition of Main Products The Company operates a pizza brand that uses a unique dough made with rice, barley, millet, black sesame, and wheat as part of its brand identity . It offers a variety of pizza options, including half - meter pizza, classic rice pizza, premium rice pizza, and single - serve pizza . Additionally, the Company provides a diverse range of menu options for both individual customers and groups . Most of the franchisees are located in the metropolitan area, including Seoul, Gyeonggi, and Incheon, which accounts for about 58 % of the total . Particularly, the number of stores in the Gyeonggi area has consistently stayed above 100 for a long time . The head quarter supplies a logistics distribution scale of about KRW 50 to 60 mn per franchise to franchisees through logistics contracts . The total distribution amounts are high in the Gyeonggi and Incheon areas due to the high number of stores and sales volume . The regional distribution is as follows : ① Daerim Distribution : It handles local logistics and provides distribution services in the Chungcheong, Gyeongsang, and Jeolla regions . ② Duri : The leading logistics provider, accounting for approximately 36 % of the total logistics . It operates logistics services in part of the metropolitan area and Chungcheong region, with most of its operations in the Gangwon region . ③ Baekyeon Food : It performs logistics in the metropolitan area and Chungcheong region, accounting for approximately 20 % of the total logistics . ④ Taewoong Food : An affiliated corporation that specializes in logistics in the metropolitan area, handling approximately 25 % of the total logistics . Distribution of logistics by region II Executive Summary Strictly Private & Confidential l Nexia Samduk l 12 Business Structure and Attribution of Profits Ogubonga’s sales consist of revenue from opening new franchise stores, commission sales from food and goods suppliers, and commission sales from four logistics companies . The profits of the logistics companies responsible for Ogubonga’s logistics are derived from the margin on the logistics performed or a certain percentage of the franchise delivery amount . ga. ▪ Taewoong Food : After recognizing the sales revenue and COGS of logistics, a small amount of support fee (Ogubonga’s logistics agency fee ) is paid to the Company (Ogubonga). ▪ Daerim Distribution : After recognizing the sales revenue and COGS of logistics, a small amount of support fee (Ogubonga’s logistics agency fee ) is paid to the Company (Ogubonga). ▪ Baekyeon Food : Receiving a 14.0% logistics agency fee based on sales delivered to the franchise store (after deducting 14.0%, the remainin g m argin is paid to the company ( Ogubonga ) as the Company’s logistics agency fee). ▪ Doori : Receiving a 12.5% logistics agency fee based on sales delivered to the franchise store (after deducting 1 2 . 5 %, the remaining margin is paid to the company( Ogubonga ) as the Company’s logistics agency fee). 2 4 2 2 2 Purchase of goods Delivery to franchise store II Executive Summary Strictly Private & Confidential l Nexia Samduk l 13 Business Structure and Attribution of Profits , continued The primary source of revenue for the Company is commissions from suppliers (brokerage commission sales) and commissions from logistics companies (logistics agency commissions) . Additionally, the margin from product sales from franchisees is entirely attributed to the logistics companies . The margin of logistics companies, including Taewoong Food, an affiliate company, corresponds to the synergy from this transaction based on the target’s (Ogubonga’s) FS standard . Source : Management Information Sales breakdown of the Company (Ogubonga) Franchise opening sales • One - off sales when opening a franchise, such as interior, facilities/furniture, franchise/technology fees, and technology transfer fees • Sales counterparts: Newly opened franchise stores Brokerage commission sales • Commission revenue received from suppliers (food ingredients, etc.) (compensation for product delivery) • Sales counterparts : Suppliers (food ingredients and related goods) • The Company receives it from suppliers in proportion to the amount delivered, which increases the purchase price for the logistics companies . Strictly Private & Confidential l Nexia Samduk l 14 Profit Structure by Logistics Company Ogubonga’s logistics are handled exclusively by four logistics companies . Taewoong Food, an affiliate, handles everything from purchasing from suppliers to selling to franchisees . Other logistics companies, such as Baekyeon, Daerim, and Doori, buy products at a price that includes the brokerage fees from suppliers and then sell them to franchisees . As a result, they operate at a lower profitability (approximately 14 % gross profit margin) compared to Taewoong Food . Source : Management Information Business structure and profit attribution of logistics companies Baekyeon Food, Daerim Distribution, Doori Taewoong Food (affiliate company) Revenue of Taewoong Food (*1) ▪ Gross profit margin Rate : 26.8%~29.5% ▪ Counterparts: Suppliers (manufacturers of food and supplies for franchise stores) ▪ Calculation of profit: Merchant delivery price (sales) – Product purchase price (COGS) Delivery price to franchisees Product purchase price (from suppliers) Profitability 26.8%~29.5% Profitability 14.1%~14.7% Delivery price to franchisees Product purchase price (from suppliers) (*1) Taewoong Food ▪ An affiliated logistics company of the target ▪ Taewoong Food serves as the de facto logistics division of the target (Ogubonga) ▪ The target (Ogubonga) does not record revenue for the logistics services provided by Taewoong. (A small sales support fee of KRW 5mn is received for a specific product, but the impact is minimal as of 2023) ▪ Accordingly, after removing the noise, the franchise’s margin can be estimated based on Taewoong Food. Revenue of logistics companies (Baekyeon, Daerim, Doori) ▪ Gross profit margin 14.1~14.7% ▪ Counterparts: Suppliers (manufacturers of food and supplies for franchise stores) ▪ Calculation of profit: Receiving approximately 14% based on the franchise delivery price ▪ : Logistics companies return any logistics margin exceeding the contracted cost (approximately 14% of the franchise delivery price) to the target, Ogubonga, as part of Ogubonga’s logistics brokerage commission sales. - KRW 179mn as of 2023 (5.8% of Ogubonga sales) Brokerage commission revenue Ogubonga brokerage commission revenue ▪ KRW 2.4 - 2.5bn per annum ▪ Counterparts: Suppliers (manufacturers of food and supplies for franchise stores) ▪ Calculation of profit: Receiving commissions proportional to the delivery amount. ▪ Ogubonga has an exclusive contract with the Company’s logistics distributors (which designates four distributors). ▪ Ogubonga’s brokerage commission sales have the effect of increasing the product purchase price (the three logistics companies are unaware of Ogubonga’s brokerage commission sales). Effect of increase in purchase price II Executive Summary 1 Strictly Private & Confidential l Nexia Samduk l 15 Profit Structure by Logistics Company (Transaction Example) The profit structures of the logistics companies mentioned earlier differ based on the example of actual transaction prices for a single item . Ogubonga receives brokerage commission revenue from the supplier (Hyungwon Co . , Ltd . ) before determining the purchase price of Baekyeon Food, Daerim Distribution, and Doori . As a result, this increases the purchase price of the merchandise, subsequently lowering the margin . When we deduct the brokerage commission sales (the target’s revenue) that increased the purchase cost from the purchase cost of logistics companies other than Taewoong Food, we find that the profitability of Taewoong Food and the other three logistics companies are calculated very similarly . This estimation reflects the profit margin of the Company after this transaction . Source : Management Information Logistics billing (merchandise sales) by logistics company GP margin of Taewoong Food ▪ Taewoong Food, an affiliate of the target (Ogubonga), considers all of the logistic margins it handles as revenue, without any additional fees, such as brokerage fees that need to be paid to Ogubonga, being generated in the purchase price of the merchandise. GP margin of Baekyeon Food, Daerim Distribution, and Doori ▪ Baekyeon Food, Daerim Distribution, and Doori purchase products at a higher unit price than Taewoong Food, even though they perform the same role. [Product purchase unit price of 3 logistics companies = Taewoong Food product purchase unit price + Ogubonga’s brokerage commission sales unit price] ▪ Suppliers who supply to logistics companies other than Taewoong Food add the brokerage commission, which must be paid to Ogubonga, to the unit price paid to Taewoong Food. Thus, they show a lower GP margin (14.4 - 14.6%) than Taewoong Food. ▪ Adjusted GP margin is calculated by deducting the brokerage commission sales (*1) from the purchase amount of three companies to assume the same structure of product purchase cost as Taewoong. It is very similar to Taewoong’s GP margin rate (less than 1%). II Executive Summary Strictly Private & Confidential l Nexia Samduk l 17 Restated Profit and Loss Through the transaction, the Company will absorb the original Ogubonga’s business and four logistics companies’ business operations . The logistics function for the Company’s products will be handled by a third - party logistics provider ( 3 PL) . As a result, the combined sales of the four logistics companies will be considered future sales . The primary sales from the Company (Ogubonga) and the sales from brokerage commissions will be factored in as a reduction in COGS or a decrease in purchase prices . The historical performance of the restructured corporate entity, based on the projected future sales structure, is outlined below . Table of Contents CHAPTER I Scope of Work 03 CHAPTER II Executive Summary 06 CHAPTER III PL Analysis 18 CHAPTER IV BS Analysis 29 CHAPTER V Appendices 37 Strictly Private & Confidential l Nexia Samduk l 19 PL Overview The Company recognizes the brokerage fees received from suppliers as its primary revenue . Sales to franchisees are considered revenue by four logistics companies . The brokerage and logistics agency fee revenues are commission - based and do not include COGS . Only the one - time sales cost is recorded as COGS . Additionally, SG&A contains costs related to real estate rental, such as accommodation buildings . Source : Management Information III PL Analysis ▪ Sales - Brokerage commission revenue : Commission revenue (product delivery fee) received from suppliers (food materials and related goods) . Received in proportion to the delivery billing and has the effect of increasing the logistics companies’ purchase price . - Logistics agency fee sales : The balance after deducting the logistics cost from the logistics agency product margin received from the four logistics agencies (Taewoong Food, Daerim Distribution, Baekyeon Food, and Doori) . - Franchise opening sales : One - time sales such as franchise fees/technical support fees, interior design costs, etc . when opening a new franchise store . - Other sales : Sales of some consumables such as uniforms and pizza bags for franchisees . - Rental sales : Rental income from the Company’s accommodation (KRW 15 mn/month) ▪ COGS - The Company’s COGS consists entirely of one - time sales costs (franchise opening and other sales), resulting in a negative margin situation due to expenditures for existing franchise store environment improvement projects . ▪ SG&A - The main expenses include labor costs, advertising, and insurance premiums . Depending on the scale of advertising, these expenses range from KRW 1 . 5 bn to 1 . 9 bn ( 50 % to 60 % ) . SG&A generated from rental real estate and related rental businesses, which account for 98 % of Tangible Assets, is recorded as mixed . - Labor cost/employee benefit : It consists of employee salaries and bonuses without a specific bonus policy . During the due diligence period, the Company spent approximately KRW 50 mn annually on employee benefits . - Severance benefit : The Company applies a defined contribution severance benefit system to all employees and accounts for external reserve assets of KRW 90 mn . However, an on - site adjustment is being conducted due to an accounting error . - Advertisement : The main changes in SG&A are an increase in video advertising costs in 2022 , followed by decreases in 2023 and 2024 . The Company has established a cost execution plan of spending 1 . 5 % of future sales (store delivery amount) . - Insurance premium : It comprises regular management insurance and four major insurances, with the majority of the premium at KRW 110 mn per year not planned to occur in the future . - Other SG&A : It consists of travel expenses, rent, and commissions with no additional details available . ▪ Reported EBITDA : The Company has consistently maintained an EBITDA of KRW 1 bn to 1 . 3 bn ( 32 . 2 % to 40 . 4 % ) in the past . 7 PL overview 2022 2023 2024.05 2024.05.LTM KRW mn 12 mth 12 mth 5 mth 12 mth Sales 3,236 3,094 1,260 3,148 Brokerage commission 2,424 2,540 1,029 2,603 Logistics agency fee 261 179 78 191 Franchise opening sales 394 185 69 159 Other sales 13 9 9 15 Rental sales 144 180 75 180 COGS 392 328 231 360 Franchise opening COGS 392 328 231 360 SG&A 1,880 1,525 541 1,484 Salary 520 569 230 547 Severance benefit 50 37 - 35 Employee benefit 49 50 24 53 Advertisement 796 386 68 319 Insurance premium 119 121 51 121 Travel expense 44 40 13 43 Rent paid 40 40 17 40 Commission paid 46 43 20 45 Entertainment expense 21 21 14 25 Taxes and dues 37 39 11 39 Repair expense 20 59 26 62 Other SG&A 138 119 68 155 Operating profit 964 1,241 488 1,304 Operating margin % 29.8% 40.1% 38.7% 41.4% D&A (SG&A) 80 66 22 88 EBITDA 1,044 1,307 510 1,392 EBITDA% 32.2% 42.3% 40.4% 44.2% Strictly Private & Confidential l Nexia Samduk l 20 Sales (1/2) The Company’s sales include brokerage commission revenue, logistics agency fee sales, franchise opening sales, and other sales . The details of each type of revenue are as follows : Source : Management Information III PL Analysis ▪ Sales - Brokerage commission revenue : The main revenue of the Company comes from the commission fee received from the supplier . This fee is paid by the franchisee’s head office in exchange for delivery and does not result in any costs for the Company . The Company assures sales for logistics companies by specifying four logistics partners in the contract . The breakdown of sales by business partners during the due diligence period is as follows : ✓ Sales in proportion to the delivery amount : Calculated as revenue per unit based on the supplier’s delivery amount . The contract unit price (commission unit price) is renegotiated approximately once a year . ✓ Effect of increased purchase price for logistics companies : Taewoong Food, an affiliate, has a low transaction volume with suppliers who receive brokerage commissions . The brokerage commission revenue received by the Company (Ogubonga) increases the product purchase price for three companies other than Taewoong Food . - Logistics agency fee sales ✓ Logistics agency product margin received from four logistics partners . After deducting the contracted commission ( 14 % ) from the product margin, the remaining amount is attributed to Ogubonga’s revenue . ✓ The logistics companies record the franchise delivery billing as sales and the product purchase amount as COGS . They then pay Ogubonga the amount after deducting the contracted logistics commission . ✓ Taewoong Food, Daerim Distribution : After recognizing the sales and COGS of the relevant logistics, a small portion of the sales support fee, referred to as Ogubonga’s logistics agency fee, is paid to the target, Ogubonga . ✓ Baekyeon Food, Doori : Receiving 12 . 5 % to 14 . 0 % of the franchisee’s delivery amount as commission . After deducting the logistics fee, the remaining margin is paid to Ogubonga, which represents Ogubonga’s logistics agency fee sales . The Company, which leases its own real estate, also records rental revenue, and the details of each sale are as follows : III PL Analysis ▪ Sales, continued - Franchise opening sales : The Company’s revenue when opening a new franchise store are as follows : ✓ Interior and exterior design : Received KRW 16 mn/store for interior decoration, KRW 5 mn/store for exterior decoration for newly opened franchise stores . ✓ Facility/furnishing sales : Recognized KRW 20 mn in sales per store for supplying kitchen appliances and utensils to new franchise stores . ✓ Franchise/technology transfer fee : Received KRW 2 mn in franchise fees as consideration for granting franchise operating rights and KRW 3 mn in sales as technology transfer fees per new franchise store . - Other sales : Other sales are sales of miscellaneous items such as uniforms, pizza bags, and aprons at franchise stores, and amount to KRW 10 to 15 mn annually . - Rental sales : Revenue generated from a lease contract for a hotel building, which the Company owns as a leased asset . The primary sources of revenue are brokerage commission revenue and logistics agency fee sales, both of which are commission - type sales with no associated costs . Here is the breakdown and nature of the sales : Source : Management Information Sales breakdown of Ogubonga Franchise opening sales • One - off sales when opening a franchise, such as interior, facilities/furniture, franchise/technology fees, and technology transfer fees • Sales counterparts : Newly opened franchise stores Brokerage commission sales • Commission revenue received from suppliers (food ingredients, etc.) • Sales counterparts : Suppliers (food ingredients and related goods) Logistics agency fee sales • Logistics agency product margin received from 4 logistics agencies (balance after deducting logistics commission costs) • Sales counterparts : Logistics companies (Taewoong Food, Daerim Distribution, Baekyeon, Doori) Other sales • Sales revenue generated during franchise operation (facilities, furniture, uniforms, etc.) • Sales counterparts : Franchise stores Rental sales (ex - transaction) • Rental income from investment properties held • Sales counterparts : Hotel Duruwa Bupyeong ▪ Franchise fee: KRW 2mn/store ▪ Technology transfer fee: KRW 3m/store ▪ Initial cost of goods: KRW 4mn One - time sales ▪ Interior: KRW 16mn ▪ Exterior: KRW 5mn ▪ Kitchen appliances and fixtures: KRW 20mn ▪ Commission revenue received from suppliers (cheese, dough, other raw materials, etc.) (received in return for supplying products to Ogu Rice Pizza franchisees). Logistics companies designated by Ogubonga (Taewoong Food, Daerim Distribution, Baekyeon, and Doori) ▪ Distribution margin (store delivery price - purchase price) is attributed to the logistics companies. Recurring sales (no associated cost) ▪ Commission income received from logistics companies (Taewoong Food, Daerim Distribution, Baekyeon, and Doori) ▪ Logistics companies collect logistics fees in proportion to sales (amount or quantity). ▪ Distribution margin (store delivery price - purchase price) belongs to the Company (Ogubonga) (after deducting logistics fees) ▪ Sales of uniforms, pizza bags, and other consumables sold to franchisees ▪ Small in size and insignificant in terms of profit Recurring sales ▪ The company leases the building in Bupyeong, Incheon, which the Company owns, and recognizes monthly rental revenue. ▪ Deposit: KRW 280mn, monthly rent KRW 15mn ▪ Accounting for receivables (overdue rent) of KRW 33mn Recurring sales (other than franchise business) 2023 Sales: KRW 185mn 2023 Sales: KRW 2,540mn 2023 Sales: KRW 179mn 2023 Sales: KRW 9mn 2023 Sales: KRW 180mn 6.0% 82.1% 5.8% 0.3% 5.8 % 1 3 2 III PL Analysis Strictly Private & Confidential l Nexia Samduk l 23 COGS The COGS is generated in relation to one - time sales, such as kitchen appliances, and averages approximately KRW 300 mn per year . Some COGS include purchases related to Bbalkong, which is unrelated to the Company’s business . The COGS rate exceeds 100 % due to purchases of products unrelated to the Company’s business . Source : Management Information III PL Analysis COGS 2022 2023 2024.05 2024.05 LTM Product COGS 392 328 231 360 Kitchen appliances 115 59 74 101 Franchise store interior 194 162 95 135 Food materials for training 73 100 19 77 Other products 11 7 15 18 Bbalkong - - 28 28 ❖ The cost of purchasing Bbalkong is included in the product’s COGS , and it’s challenging for the Company to differentiate the purchase history . As a result, we combine the remaining costs under kitchenware and interior expenses after excluding the specific costs related to Bbalkong . ▪ COGS - Product COGS : It includes one - time sales - related expenses such as franchise membership and opening costs, technology transfer costs, kitchen equipment, etc and the purchase of products related to Bbalkong, operated by Taewoong Food . It incurs an average of KRW 300 mn per year . ✓ Kitchen appliances : The supply of kitchen appliances (such as refrigerators and ovens) to the Company’s franchises decreased in 2023 due to a decline in the number of new franchises . Despite the ongoing decrease in new franchises since 2022 , the purchase of kitchen appliances in 2024 increased . It is estimated that this increase includes the purchase of kitchen appliances related to Bbalkong . ✓ Franchise store interior : The Company conducted interior construction for new franchises and environmental improvement projects for existing franchises . As the number of new franchises decreased and the environmental improvement projects for franchises ended, the related COGS decreased . ✓ Food materials for training : It consists of food materials for practical training for new and existing stores and generates an average of around KRW 80 mn per year . ✓ Bbalkong : Costs related to metal work and glass replacement at Bbalkong headquarters occurred from January to March 2024 ✓ Negative margin of product COGS ✓ COGS rate : Product COGS constitutes the purchase of goods related to one - time sales (franchise membership, opening fee, technology transfer fee, kitchen equipment, etc . ) . As of 2022 - May 2024 , the product COGS exceeds 100 % . ✓ Reason for negative margin : We have difficulty providing a consistent estimate because the Company is unable to differentiate between Ogubonga purchases and other purchases (Bbalkong, etc . ) . However, we believe that the purchase cost associated with Bbalkong is already included in the product’s COGS . We anticipate that excluding the purchase amount related to Bbalkong could lead to an improvement in the COGS rate . COGS rate 2022 2023 2024.05 2024.05 LTM One - time sales (KRW mn) 407 194 78 174 COGS (KRW mn) 392 328 231 360 COGS rate (%) 96.3% 169.3% 295.5% 206.8% Strictly Private & Confidential l Nexia Samduk l 24 SG&A(1/4) The Company’s SG&A expenses amount to an average of about KRW 1 . 5 bn per year, with the largest portion being attributed to salary and advertisement costs . The salary expenses have slightly increased due to the addition of new personnel, but it is anticipated to decrease by approximately KRW 170 mn in the future due to the number of people leaving the Company . The advertisement costs include broadcast advertisements and delivery app promotions and have been higher than in previous years due to increased broadcast advertising, such as the sponsorship of Love Twist in 2022 . Source : Management Information III PL Analysis SG&A 2022 2023 2024.05 2024.05 LTM Total 1,880 1,525 541 1,484 Salary 520 568 230 547 Miscellaneous wage - 1 - - Severance benefit 50 37 - 35 Employee benefit 49 50 24 53 Travel expense 44 40 13 43 Vehicle maintenance 5 5 11 5 Training expense 0.49 1 0.49 1 Publication expense 0.25 1 0.24 1 Office supply 1 1 1 1 Consumables 24 21 24 35 Communication 8 8 3 8 Advertisement 796 386 68 319 Taxes and dues 37 39 11 39 Rent paid 40 40 17 40 Building maintenance 14 15 5 15 Utility expense 1 1 1 1 Repair expense 20 59 26 62 Insurance premium 119 121 51 121 Entertainment expense 21 21 14 25 Commission paid 46 43 20 45 Depreciation 76 64 21 86 Amortization 3 2 1 3 Other SG&A 4 0 2 2 ▪ SG&A - Salary : The total compensation includes the CEO and employee salaries/bonuses, which increased due to the addition of new employees compared to 2022 . However, with the future personnel plan aiming to maintain 11 employees, the annual salary is anticipated to decrease to approximately KRW 376 mn . - Miscellaneous wage : One - off costs for repairing the Bupyeong office, etc . - Severance benefit : All employees are enrolled in the DC type, and payments are made to individual pension accounts for employees who have been employed for more than one year every December . - Employee benefit : It consists of employee health insurance premiums, employee meal expenses, and other employee gifts (gift certificates for birthdays), and amounts to an average of approximately 50 million won per year . - Travel expense : They include vehicle - related costs (such as parking fees, tolls, and fuel expenses) as well as travel and accommodation expenses associated with visits to dealerships . On average, these expenses amount to around KRW 40 mn annually . In 2024 , it is underrecognized in 2024 as the vehicle maintenance settlement adjustment has not been reflected . - Vehicle maintenance : The average annual cost for inspecting and repairing vehicles is around KRW 5 mn . Vehicle - related fuel costs are included in travel expenses in the annual settlement report . However, there is no replacement report for May 2024 as it is a provisional settlement figure, and there seems to be an overestimation in vehicle maintenance costs . - Training expense : Annual average of around KRW 1 mn for legally required education such as safety and health education . Salary per capita 2022 2023 2024.05 2024.05 LTM Average salary (KRW mn) 38 33 14 32 No. of employees (KRW mn/person) 14 17 17 17 Employee benefit(KRW mn) 2022 2023 2024.05 2024.05 LTM Total 49 50 24 53 Health insurance 16 21 9 21 Food and beverage 29 28 14 31 Others 3 1 1 1 Travel expense(KRW mn) 2022 2023 2024.05 2024.05 LTM Total 44 40 13 43 Vehicle related expenses 39 37 10 37 Business trip accommodation 5 4 4 6 Strictly Private & Confidential l Nexia Samduk l 25 [Reference] Labor cost The Company currently employs an average of 17 people per year, with each employee earning an average salary of KRW 33 mn . Moving forward, the Company aims to reduce the number of employees to around 10 , resulting in an estimated annual cost saving of approximately KRW 170 mn . Source : Management Information • AS - IS labor cost status - Salary: The Company’s salary consists of labor costs and bonuses, and is recognized entirely as sales expenses and management expenses. The labor cost is in the mid - KRW 500mn range on average per year, and bonuses consist of holiday bonuses (Seollal, Chuseok) and bonuses based on separate work abilities. - Headcount: The company is currently organized into five teams under the CEO, with an average of 17 people per year, including the CEO. - Salary per person: The Company typically offers an annual salary increase of about 1% to 3% per person. However, due to personnel changes at Taewoong Food and a high turnover rate, the proportion of low - level employees with less than one year of service is high. As a result, the average salary per person has decreased from KRW 38mn in 2022 to 33mn in 2023. • To - Be Labor cost status - Headcount: Two more employees are set to start after June 2024. Consequently, an extra annual salary of around KRW 65mn will be added in the future. The future staffing plan aims to have a total of 1 CEO and 10 employees, focusing on operating mainly with support team personnel from the store. - Salary per person : After the recent personnel changes, the average salary per person is expected to increase slightly compared to the past, reaching around KRW 35mn. This is because 5 out of the 8 people who left the Company were mostly individuals with lower salaries who had been with the Company for less than one year. - Labor cost savings: The Company plans to reduce the number of employees by about six compared to the average in the past, resulting in labor cost savings of around KRW 170mn per year. The salary expenses have slightly increased due to the addition of new personnel, but it is anticipated to decrease by approximately KRW 170 mn in the future due to the number of people leaving the Company . The advertisement costs include broadcast advertisements and delivery app promotions and have been higher than in previous years due to increased broadcast advertising, such as the sponsorship of Love Twist in 2022 . III PL Analysis SG&A 2022 2023 2024.05 2024.05 LTM Total 1,880 1,525 541 1,484 Salary 520 568 230 547 Miscellaneous wage - 1 - - Severance benefit 50 37 - 35 Employee benefit 49 50 24 53 Travel expense 44 40 13 43 Vehicle maintenance 5 5 11 5 Training expense 0.49 1 0.49 1 Publication expense 0.25 1 0.24 1 Office supply 1 1 1 1 Consumables 24 21 24 35 Communication 8 8 3 8 Advertisement 796 386 68 319 Taxes and dues 37 39 11 39 Rent paid 40 40 17 40 Building maintenance 14 15 5 15 Utility expense 1 1 1 1 Repair expense 20 59 26 62 Insurance premium 119 121 51 121 Entertainment expense 21 21 14 25 Commission paid 46 43 20 45 Depreciation 76 64 21 86 Amortization 3 2 1 3 Other SG&A 4 0 2 2 ▪ SG&A - Publication expense : It consists of banners and advertising - related printed materials and amounts to an average of approximately KRW 1 mn per year . - Office supply : It consists of stationery necessary for work and costs an average of about KRW 1 mn per year . - Consumables : It consists of educational materials, other business consumables, etc . , and costs around KRW 20 mn per year . However, there is a slight increase in 2024 due to additional consumables such as laptops, mats, and speakers . - Communication : It consists of company landline and business mobile phone charges and costs an average of KRW 8 mn per year . - Advertisement : It includes delivery app promotions, video ads on platforms like TV and YouTube, print ads, and social media ads . In 2023 , the promotional spending was around KRW 800 mn due to aggressive promotion and video ad campaigns . However, it has since decreased to KRW 400 mn . ✓ Delivery app promotion : Promotions are conducted on Baedal Minjok and Yogiyo, spending KRW 400 mn through aggressive promotions in 2022 . Subsequently, the Company spent an average of KRW 300 mn annually due to reduced promotion costs and an increased burden on franchisees related to promotions . ✓ Video advertisement : There was an increase in advertising fees related to video transmissions, such as broadcasting and YouTube, due to production support and broadcast advertising for the KBS drama “Love Twist” in 2022 . Sales decreased due to no broadcast advertising execution after 2023 . ✓ Other advertisements : It includes advertising costs for printing, social media, and branch opening events, averaging around KRW 40 mn per year . On average, this amounts to KRW 39 mn per year . - Rent paid : It comprises the company building rental fee, which is about KRW 40 mn per year on average . - Building maintenance : It comprises company building maintenance, and the average annual cost is about KRW 15 mn . - Utility expense : It comprises company building utility expenses, and the average annual cost is about KRW 1 mn . - Repair expense : It comprises repair expenses and related costs for the Company - owned Duruwa Hotel, averaging approximately KRW 50 mn per year . (* 1 ) Only clear items are classified as hotel - related repair expenses, such as bathroom construction and rooftop waterproofing, due to difficulty confirming specific items . - Insurance premium : It consists of regular management insurance and 4 major insurances, of which management insurance accounts for the majority at KRW 110 mn per year . - Entertainment expense : It consists of entertainment expenses provided to the Company’s business partners, etc . , and amounts to an average of approximately KRW 20 mn per year . The accounting fees amount to approximately KRW 6 mn per year, and the commissions amount to approximately KRW 39 mn per year . - Depreciation : Depreciation expenses for the Duruwa Hotel and other company assets, such as supplies, vehicles, and facilities, total approximately KRW 40 mn per year on average, excluding the Duruwa Hotel depreciation . - Amortization : It consists of company - owned trademarks and intangible assets related to website and video production, and it is worth an average of KRW 3 mn per year . - Other SG&A : It consists of delivery and transportation costs related to company goods, miscellaneous costs related to waste disposal, etc . Commission paid (KRW mn) 2022 2023 2024.05 2024.05 LTM Total 46 43 20 45 A ccounting fees 6 6 5 6 Other commission paid 39 36 15 39 Depreciation (KRW mn) 2022 2023 2024.05 2024.05 LTM Total 76 64 21 86 Duruwa Hotel 33 33 14 33 Other tangible assets 44 32 8 53 Source : Management Information Table of Contents CHAPTER I Scope of Work 03 CHAPTER II Executive Summary 06 CHAPTER III PL Analysis 18 CHAPTER IV BS Analysis 29 CHAPTER V Appendices 37 Strictly Private & Confidential l Nexia Samduk l 30 BS Overview The Company holds cash equivalents of KRW 3 , 914 mn as a result of consistent operating profits in the previous period . The primary assets, which are mostly land and accommodation buildings, are owned by the Company . Additionally, long - term borrowings of KRW 2 , 400 mn are recorded . The Company’s debt ratio indicates a stable financial position, standing at 50 % during the due diligence period . IV BS Analysis Source : Management Information ▪ Current assets - Cash equivalents : The Company holds cash reserves of KRW 9 mn and 8 accounts in 2 banks (Kookmin Bank and Woori Bank) with deposits of KRW 3 , 905 mn . There are no rights restrictions . - Accounts receivable : The Company’s accounts receivable are from suppliers of food materials and goods used in franchise stores . They are collectable within an approximately one - month collection period . - Non - trade receivable : KRW 33 mn in overdue rent from the Company’s real estate lease contract . - Other current assets : They consist of prepaid insurance premiums, deposits, and unpaid VAT due to incomplete settlement . ▪ Non - current assets - Investment assets : The Company recorded KRW 90 mn in retirement pension assets as investment assets . However, due to an accounting error by the tax accounting firm, the balance in the investment assets account is zero following an on - site adjustment . - Tangible assets : The Company’s tangible assets include hotel land and buildings that are held for rental purposes unrelated to the franchise business, with 98 % of the book value being irrelevant to the franchise business . Other assets include vehicles (KRW 23 mn), equipment (KRW 29 mn), and facilities (KRW 26 mn) . - Intangible assets : The Company’s intangible assets include trademarks (KRW 0 . 6 mn) and software (KRW 3 . 6 mn) . The trademarks have been fully amortized . ▪ Current liabilities - Accounts payable : The Company’s accounts payable balance is for advertising expenses and is payable within one month - Withholdings : They consist of VAT withheld of KRW 49 mn and 4 major insurance withheld (KRW 4 mn) - Accrued expenses : They consist of the full amount of unpaid May salaries . ▪ Non - current liabilities - Borrowings : Loan from Kookmin Bank secured by fully owned real estate (hotel building) (maturity February 2025 ) - Rental deposit : The rental deposit for the hotel building amounts to KRW 280 mn . ▪ Equities - Capital : The Company issued 40 , 000 shares with a par value of KRW 5 , 000 and recorded a capital of KRW 200 mn . - Retained earnings : They consist of KRW 41 mn in legal reserves and KRW 5 , 794 mn in retained earnings, and the retained earnings increased due to continuous profits during the due diligence period . BS overview 2022 2023 2024.05 KRW mn Dec Dec 5M Current assets 3,005 3,936 4,243 Cash equivalents 2,660 3,552 3,914 Accounts receivable 344 347 290 Non - trade receivable - 33 33 Other current assets 2 5 7 Non - current assets 4,651 4,585 4,571 Investment assets 90 90 90 Tangible assets 4,501 4,437 4,424 Intangible assets 8 6 5 Other non - current assets 52 52 52 Total assets 7,656 8,521 8,814 Current liabilities 300 241 95 Accounts payable 11 5 1 Withholdings 80 76 53 Deferred tax 157 124 - Accrued expenses 52 36 41 Non - current liabilities 2,680 2,680 2,680 Borrowings 2,400 2,400 2,400 Rental deposit 280 280 280 Total liabilities 2,980 2,921 2,775 Capital 200 200 200 Retained earnings 4,477 5,400 5,840 Total equities 4,677 5,600 6,040 Debt ratio 63.7% 52.1% 45.9% Strictly Private & Confidential l Nexia Samduk l 31 Quality of Net Assets As of the due diligence date, the Company's net assets were recorded at KRW 6 , 040 mn . After due diligence adjustments, the Company's assets were changed to KRW 8 , 684 mn, liabilities to KRW 2 , 745 mn, and capital to KRW 5 , 939 mn . The due diligence adjustments made are as follows : IV BS Analysis Source : Management Information Adjustments - Due Diligence Adjustment A. Write - off of investment assets : The Company made an accounting error, resulting in the pension operating assets . As the Company runs a fully defined contribution (DC) pension system, the entire investment assets accounting amount is written off . B. Write - off of deposit assets : In 2012 , the Company made a deposit with a judicial scrivener concerning a disagreement over interior design costs not paid by franchisees . However, because the deadline has passed and no supporting evidence can be found, it is uncertain whether the asset actually exists . Consequently, a due diligence adjustment was made for the entire amount of the account . C. Depreciation not accounted for : The Company omitted depreciation for certain assets used in the accommodation business in the May 2024 settlement, leading to an accounting adjustment . D. Accounting for accrued interest : The Company recognizes interest expense on a cash basis rather than using the accrual basis for interest accrued from borrowings . As a result, the due diligence adjustment reflects the accrued interest of KRW 7 mn (approximately one month's worth) as of the audit date . E. Offset of non - trade receivable/rental deposit : The Company has recorded KRW 33 mn as overdue rent from a lease agreement for an accommodation building it owns . This amount is classified as a non - trade receivable . We have offset this amount against the rental deposit of the relevant contract to make an accounting adjustment . This adjustment does not impact the Company's capital . F. Offset of VAT withheld/VAT receivables : The Company did not offset VAT withheld and VAT receivables in the May 2024 financial statements . Therefore, we adjusted the accounting to offset assets and liabilities amounting to KRW 4 mn with no capital effect . Strictly Private & Confidential l Nexia Samduk l 33 Current assets The Company’s quick assets include cash equivalents, accounts receivable, and non - trade receivables . Most of the Company's current assets are held as ordinary deposits, and the amount has been steadily increasing during the due diligence period . IV BS Analysis Source : Management Information Source : Management Information ▪ Quick assets - Cash equivalents : cash and deposit products that allow for deposits and withdrawals at any time - . - Accounts receivable : The Company's accounts receivable consist entirely of brokerage commission revenue receivables from suppliers of food and supplies to franchisees . The Company settles with its suppliers on a monthly basis, and the average collection period is estimated to be 1 to 1 . 5 months . The Company has no policy for allowances for doubtful accounts, and there is no history of bad debts . Most of the Company's current assets are held as ordinary deposits, and the amount has been steadily increasing during the due diligence period . IV BS Analysis Source : Management Information ▪ Current liabilities - Account payable, accrued payments : The Company’s accounts payable and accrued payments are debts for the Company's operating expenses . They are typically paid within one month . The remaining balance as of the due dilligence date is to be paid in the following month as accrued payments for Naver advertising fees (GFA performance ad) . - Withholdings : The Company’s withholdings are paid to individual management corporations in the following month as deposits for the four major insurances (national pension, employment insurance, long - term care insurance, health insurance) of employees . - VAT withheld : The Company records VAT withheld and VAT receivables simultaneously as of the sales due diligence date (KRW 4 mn) . We offset them in due diligence adjustment . - Accrued expenses : The Company performed full cash accounting for the interest on Borrowings . We made due diligence adjustments to Accrued expenses for interest after the final interest payment date of May 7 , 2024 . - Long - term borrowings : The Company borrowed KRW 2 , 400 mn from Kookmin Bank, using its accommodation building as collateral . A mortgage of up to KRW 3 , 120 mn is set on the borrowed amount . Below are the mortgage details . - Rental deposit : Recorded as rental deposit for the rental of a building for lodging owned by the Company . The Company recorded overdue rent from the lessee as non - trade receivable (KRW 33 mn) . We conducted due diligence adjustments by offsetting assets and liabilities . However, the older, longer - term franchises use separate POS systems that are not unified . As a result, the Company has been unable to track sales from franchisees using POS systems other than “Smartro,” and sales from deliveries are also not accounted for in the current POS system . Appendix Franchisees and POS/delivery sales • Company POS system : The Company manages franchise sales and related information using the POS system “Smartro . ” However, franchisees that were established before the implementation of “Smartro” are using a different POS system . As of the end of May 2024 , 82 . 9 % ( 321 out of 387 stores) of franchises are using Smartro . • Other POS sales (* 2 ) (estimation) : The sales data of non - Smartro franchise stores is unknown . It is estimated that the sales of other POS stores, in proportion to the number of stores, are around KRW 7 to 9 bn per year . • Delivery sales : The Company carries out delivery sales, which are not recorded on the POS . Data from each delivery agent must be collected (franchisee sales per store cannot be verified) . • Gross sales (gross sales of franchisees) : Gross sales based on franchisees during the audit period are estimated to be between KRW 66 . 3 bn and 77 . 1 bn . Unit: KRW mn 2022 2023 2024.05 2024.05.(LTM) Smartro franchisees (*1) 378 350 328 336 Other POS franchisees (*1) 81 72 67 69 Total No. of stores 459 422 395 405 Smart franchisee sales 41,939 35,496 12,972 33,461 Other POS sales (*2) n/a n/a n/a n/a Delivery sales 26,088 25,928 10,289 25,987 Franchise sales estimate n/a n/a n/a n/a Analysis of delivery sales Unit: KRW mn 2022 2023 2024.05 2024.05.(LTM) Baemin 18,304 17,629 5,190 15,447 Baemin1 1,513 2,075 2,088 3,491 Yogiyo 5,670 5,317 1,845 5,120 Coupang Eats 601 907 1,166 1,929 Total 26,088 25,928 10,289 25,987 (*1) This is the annual average number of franchise stores based on logistics delivery amount and is different from the number of franchise stores at the end of the year. • Delivery sales : During the due diligence period, the Company generated sales not only through in - store purchases but also via delivery . Delivery sales accounted for approximately KRW 26 bn . The Company does not have a dedicated system for aggregating delivery sales data and relies on data from delivery apps . However, as many delivery agencies do not provide data by franchise, it is currently impossible to collect and analyze this data . • Composition of delivery sales : The Company’s franchises are using four delivery apps, with Baedal Minjok and Baedal Minjok 1 accounting for the highest contribution at 70 . 7 % (as of May 2024 ) . Strictly Private & Confidential l Nexia Samduk l 39 Regional Distribution of Logistics Companies The four logistics companies distribute products to franchises regionally and handle sales to the Company's franchisees . Daerim Distribution oversees the entire southern region of Chungcheong, so we expect high logistics costs (SG&A) . Taewoong Food is an affiliate with a higher gross margin than the other three logistics companies . LTD. PO Box 309 , Ugland House, KY 1 - 1104 , Grand Cayman Fair Valuation Review Report BANOLIM PIZZA Co.,Ltd Pursuant to a service agreement with Attn : ORCHESTRA PRIVATE EQUITY SINGAPORE PTE. LTD. ("Your Company"), Samduk Accounting Firm ("Our Company" or "We") have performed a fair value review of the shares of BANOLIM PIZZA Co.,Ltd (the "Target Company“ or the “Company") held by your company as of March 31, 2024 (the "Review Date"), and submit this report for the purpose of supportin g internal decision - making regarding the fair value of the target company. Scope and Features of Services We have performed this work based on the historical financial data of the target company presented by your company and the target company, and have prepared this report based on our review . Our work was performed in accordance with a scope of work agreed with your company to approach the valuation based on the materials presented by your company and the target company, and the agreed upon scope of work may not have covered all material matters necessary for the decisions you are considering . We also cannot guarantee the validity, accuracy, reliability and completeness of the materials and information presented by your company and the target company contained in this report . Accordingly, we do not guarantee that the information contained in this report contains all the material and information you need to make the decisions you are considering, and we do not accept responsibility for any omissions . In this service, the valuation results and related matters are calculated under certain assumptions based on the target company's past performance and other publicly available data, and it is generally accepted that the actual operating results may differ from the actual results due to future economic conditions, changes in the company's business strategy and conditions, and such differences may be material . Therefore, we do not confirm or guarantee that the results of the valuation reviewed in this report will be the same or similar to the actual value in the future, and investors should consider additional risks when making decisions . In addition, we do not express any opinion on the accuracy or validity of the data and evidence used in the valuation . On the other hand, the user of this report should fully and clearly consider the scope and limitations of the work performed by our company as described in the "Scope of Work", and we shall not be liable for any kind of loss or damage based on this report . The work performed by our firm was completed based on materials provided by your firm and the target company as of the review date . This report is based on certain facts specific to your company as of the review date and is not applicable to any other third party, and we assume no obligation to update or supplement this report relevant to changes in facts or events occurring after the date of this report . Purpose and Limitations of Report The use of this report is limited to the purpose of supporting internal decision - making regarding the fair value of the target company . Accordingly, except as provided in the agreement, this report, in whole or in part, should not be provided to or viewed by any third party other than your company without the prior written consent of our company, and we have no liability to any third party who obtains this report without the prior written consent of our company . Work scope Access to information & Limitation Scope of Work ◆ We have performed a fair value review of the shares of BANOLIM PIZZA Co . ,Ltd (the "Target Company“ or the “Company") held by your company and have prepared this report for the purpose of providing a reference in support of your company's internal decision - making regarding the fair value of the target company . ◆ Work Scope ▷ Base Date : March 31 , 2024 ▷ What to Review : - Review of the financial statements of the company as of the Base date - Valuation of a target company using a Guideline Public Company Method(GPCM) - Valuation based on the comparable transaction using a Guideline transaction method(GTM) ◆ How the service is performed ▷ The financial analysis and other reviews related to this report are based on the past performance data presented by the company, and we have reviewed the reasonableness of the business plan through comparative analysis with various industry data . ▷ Major Data Sources Utilized by our company 1 ) Bloomberg, Kisline, DART, Capital IQ, et . c : financial and stock price information of peer companies, and industry analysis, 2 ) Market analysis data from Bank of Korea, securities company analyst reports, etc, 3 ) Key Press Releases ◆ For this engagement, we conducted telephone and documentary inquiries during the review period . ◆ The company has provided the materials in electronic files . The management of the company is responsible for the accuracy of them, but our company is not . ◆ Because the procedures we performed were not audit procedures in accordance with auditing standards, but rather procedures based on review criteria established by prior agreement with your company based on materials presented by your company, we do not express an audit or review opinion on any of the information contained in this report, nor do we provide any assurance that the procedures performed are sufficient for the purposes of this report . ◆ This report assesses the Company's value as of the report date solely based on historical performance . Future cash flows, business plans, and potential risks including unanticipated liabilities, business plan fulfillment, and market conditions are not evaluated . Users should consider these factors when using this report for decision - making . ◆ Some numbers and percentages in this report are rounded to the nearest whole number and may not add up to the same amount or may differ from numbers and percentages on other pages for the same item . (hereinafter “the company,” or “the target”) were established in 2016 , respectively, and are engaged in the pizza franchise operation and the food manufacturing business . In 2021 , Beethoven Advisors Korea Ltd, run by Orchestra PE, took over approximately 89 % of the shares in the headquarters and 100 % of the branch . Valuation Method ▪ GPCM and GTM were applied to analyze the company’s enterprise and equity value . The main contents are as follows . Method Detail Equity value Remark Guideline public company method (GPCM) • Select a domestic listed company with the same or similar business as the target company as peers and calculate EV/EBITDA using the most recent available financial data as of the peers reference date. • Calculate Enterprise Value by applying EV/EBITDA of domestic Peers operating in the same or similar business to the target company's EBITDA. • Calculate the equity value by adding the target's non - operating assets and interest - bearing liabilities as of the reference date to the calculated Enterprise Value. KRW 105,599mm (USD 78.6 mm) • Improving the appropriateness of equity valuation of a company through companies operating in the same or similar business (utilizing data of many similar companies to compensate for uneconomic cases) Guideline transaction method (GTM) • Calculate EV/EBITDA multiple based on the deal value at the time of the transaction for comparable M&A transactions. • Calculated the enterprise value (EV) by applying the peers' multiple to the company's EBITDA. • Calculated the equity value by adding or subtracting net debt to/from the enterprise value. KRW 94,848mm (USD 70.6 mm) • The equity transactions of similar companies were selected as comparable transactions • Valuation of equity using an average of individual transaction multiples of the same/similar business Conclusion of equity valuation analysis (Market Approach) ▪ The stake value range : KRW 94 , 848 mm ~ KRW 105 , 599 mm (USD 70 . 6 mm ~ USD 78 . 6 mm) ✓ Guideline public company method (GPCM) : KRW 105 , 599 mm (USD 78 . 6 mm) - Calculate multiple by considering the market capitalization and financial performance(EBITDA) of listed companies with similar business or operations to the target company . ✓ Guideline transaction method (GTM) : KRW 94 , 848 mm (USD 70 . 6 mm) - Calculated by considering the transaction value and the financial performance (EBITDA) at the time of the transaction using examples of companies with similar operations to the target company and their equity transactions . II Executive Summary CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Strictly Private & Confidential l Nexia Samduk l 8 GPCM & GTM Value The value of the Company's equity using the Guideline Public Company Method and the Guideline Transaction Method under the market approach was estimated to be between KRW 94 , 848 mm(USD 70 . 6 mm) and KRW 105 , 599 mm(USD 78 . 6 mm) . As for regional distribution, franchisees in the metro area contribute 41 . 0 % , whereas more than half of the franchisees are distributed in the non - metro area . Given that about 55 % of the top pizza operators’ franchisees located in the metropolitan area, the company plans to expand the franchisees in the metro area down the road . III Company & Industry Overview Source : Federal Trade Commission (Korea Gov), Management Information Competitor stores and sales trends • The acquisition of Jungseong Foods : The acquisition led to a significant increase in sales, but growth was estimated at approximately 37% excluding the impact of the Jung Sung Foods acquisition. • Closing/Liquidation of Banolim Food Seoul : The Seoul office (branch), which was in charge of attracting franchisees and managing logistics in the Seoul metropolitan a re a, was closed and liquidated to unify management and administration, and the attribution of revenue and costs was also unified. (Accordingl y, profits and losses will be attributed to the headquarters from 2023 except for a small amount of expenses (KRW 9 mm). • Increase in company's store count and revenue The company continues to expand the number of stores by improving brand image and quality, expanding marketing, and achieving higher sales growth than its competitors.
