Item As - is Recommendation 1. Estimation of Retirement Allowances • Target deposits retirement benefits for 6 executives/employees who are under DC plan at DGB Daegu Bank and not saves any funds for other employees. • No retirement allowance is being recorded, as Target only runs DC plan. Contribution amount paid each year is expensed as retirement expenses. • As severance needs to be paid to employees who have worked for over a year, the estimated retirement allowance for the employees as of Dec - 20 is about KRW 0.23bn. 6 out of 15 eligible employees are saving into outside DC accounts, therefore the estimated amount for the remaining 9 employees is KRW 0.18bn. The estimated retirement allowances for people who are not saving into DC accounts is reflected as debt - like item. • The difference in such retirement allowance balance year to year is reflected as normalized expenses. FY19 expense was normalized for FY18 as well, as retirement allowance at Dec - 17 could not have been computed due to scope limitation. 2. Paid Vacation • Target consults with a labor affairs specialist for HR and employment; paid vacation usages are managed by the labor affairs specialist. • No liabilities are recorded for unused paid vacations on the financial statements at the end of each term. • The difference in allowances for unused vacations balance year to year is reflected as normalized expenses. FY19 expense was normalized for FY18 as well, as information on unused PTO as of Dec - 17 was not available. 3. Cut - off • Accounting and tax affairs are handled by a local tax firm, so financial statements are mostly prepared based on the dates tax invoices are issued. • Overall, there is no issue when accounting and tax invoice dates are concurrent, but some cutoff adjustments need to be made for advertising expenses and sales promotion expenses in SG&A. • Model Fees: The model fees for FY19 were recorded as expenses in FY18 when tax invoice was issued. • Smartcon Fees: The fees paid to Smartcon for selling gift cards in FY18 and FY19 were recorded in FY20 altogether. • Coupon Expenses: The cost of Yogiyo and Coca - Cola discount coupons was recorded in Jan - 21, whereas discounts were offered in Dec - 20. • Insurance Fees: Among the variable insurance fees paid in FY17, KRW 12mn was recorded in FY18. No insurance fees need to be adjusted from FY19. (1/2) KRWm FY18 FY19 FY20 Difference in allowances for unused PTOs at the end of each year (15) (15) 3 KRWm FY18 FY19 FY20 Cost for Employees without Retirement Pension (32) (32) (39) KRWm FY18 FY19 FY20 Advertising expenses - model fees 263 (263) - Advertising expenses - fees to Smart Con (4) (10) 14 Sales promotion cost - coupons - - (47) Insurance Fees 12 - - 271 (273) (33) CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven | May 2021 17 One page summary FY21 update Accounting adjustment EBITDA bridge Revenue GP Normalized EBITDA Store analysis Net debt Item As - is Recommendation 4. Random Appraisal of Land • Target recognized loss on valuation of land based on the market price when purchasing the property for Factory 2 in Maecheon - dong, Buk - gu , Daegu in FY20, to avoid one of the requirements of external audit – possessing over KRW 12bn in assets. • There was no particular appraisal procedure when devaluing the land. Adjustment of the book value and recognition of gain on valuation of land is expected in the future. 5. Disposition of Tangible Assets • Some tangible assets have already been disposed, but the disposition has not been communicated with the tax accountant and they are still recorded in book. • The remaining value of such tangible assets as of Dec - 20 was KRW 19mn. • The book value of such tangible assets remaining on the book as of Dec - 20 includes KRW 18mn for machineries, KRW 0.1mn for tools and equipment, and KRW 0.4mn for furniture and fixtures. The corresponding book value should be removed from the book. - According to the interview, the timing of disposition of such tangible assets is unclear, and therefore has been assumed that they were disposed at the end of FY20. 6. Expensed Tangible Assets • About KRW 70mn of factory facilities, including freezer storage, feeders, and steamers is recorded under COGS, not capitalized. • About KRW 70mn needs to be subtracted from COGS (supplies expenses) – Finished Goods. Net BV of such assets of KRW 65mn should be added to ‘Tangible assets.’ In addition, about KRW 5mn depreciation expenses need to be recognized. Executive summary | Accounting adjustment Target prepares its financial statements based on tax statements and the recommendations for the major accounting treatments are as follow. The logistics margin from Jungsung Food increased by about KRW 1.4bn. • SG&A - FY18 - 19: The head office’s advertising production cost and advertising fees increased by about KRW 1.9bn due to aggressive TV commercials and press releases. Amortization of branch office’s goodwill increased by about KRW 70mn. - FY19 - 20: Sales promotion cost increased by KRW 0.52bn in FY20 due to advertising activities on Nego King and Yogiyo . Target’s EBITDA% decreased slightly from 47.8% in FY18 to 40.3% in FY20, and EBITDA increased from KRW 4.4bn in FY18 to KRW 6.1bn in FY20 as a result of increase in finished goods sales and logistics margins due to the increase in sales by franchisees. Gross revenue of FY18 - 20 increased at an annual average rate of 28.5% due to the increase in sales by franchisees Executive summary | Revenue Revenue • Finished goods sales: Sales of dough and sauces manufactured by Target and supplied by Jungsung Food to franchisees. The revenue increased by an average of 28.0% a year in FY18 - 20 due to the increase in the number of franchisee stores and their sales (See ‘Appendices | PQ of Finished Goods’ for PQ graph). - FY18 - 19: Sales increased by KRW 0.7bn due to an increase in the ASP of sauces and by KRW 0.6bn due to an increase in sales volume. - FY19 - 20: No change in ASP, but sales increased by KRW 2.3bn due to a sales volume increase following an increase in the number of franchisee stores and their ASPS. • Franchise income: The number of franchisee stores increased by about 42 in FY18 - 20, and the logistics margin from food ingredients supplied by Jungsung Food to franchisees increased by about KRW 2bn in FY18 - 20 (yearly average of 38.7%). Franchise fees, training fees, and advertising fees collected from franchisees increased by about KRW 0.27bn during the same period (yearly average of 13.4%). • Merchandise sales: Mostly consists of kitchen facilities sold to newly opened franchisees. According to the interview, the head office connects new franchisee stores directly to the vendors for additional purchases, but the branch office recommends additional purchases to franchisees upon opening to collect additional fees. Executive summary | GP Unit: KRW 0.1bn • Finished goods GP increased from KRW 2.6bn in FY18 to KRW 4.6bn in FY20 by an average of 34.2% a year due to i ) an increase in finished goods sales with more franchisee stores openings and increased ASPS, and ii) decrease in APP of raw materials due to the increase in buying power and fluctuation of market price. Executive summary | Store analysis Beginning Open 1 Ending FY18 Closed FY19 FY20 Transfer 1 Head office 111 Branch Office 85 Total 196 123 96 219 130 101 231 Head office 14 Branch Office 11 Total 25 8 5 13 15 15 30 Head office 2 Branch Office 0 Total 2 1 0 1 0 0 0 Head office 21 Branch Office 6 Total 27 29 15 44 20 14 34 Head office 123 Branch Office 96 Total 219 130 101 231 145 116 261 1 Chungnam: The franchisees in Cheonan and Asan are managed by the branch office and other franchisees are managed by the head office. 2 Other locations: Busan, Jeonbuk , Sejong, Ulsan, Jeju , Daejeon, Chungbuk , Gwangju Roll - forward • A total of 30 new franchisee stores opened as the brand’s popularity rose in FY20. Regions with the most number of new franchisees in the last 3 years are: Gyeonggi - do (18), Chungnam (8), Gyeongnam (6), Jeonnam (6), and Seoul (5). • The shut - down rate is very low, as a total of 3 stores closed down in FY18 - 20. In FY18, Okpo Store in Daegu shut down due to the owner’s health problems, and the Dongseobyeon Store has moved locations but has been processed as closed due to a registration issue with the Fair Trade Committee. In FY19, Gimcheon Hyeoksin Store shut down following the continuous delay of payments due to the owner’s personal debt. • In FY18 - 20, the number of stores managed by the head office increased by 22 (average of 8.6% a year) and the number of stores managed by the branch office increased by 20 (average of 9.9% a year). 1 1 2 2 3 3 Unit: store 1 According to the interview, Target does not manage the opening date of new and transferred stores accurately, so it is hard to distinguish all new and transferred stores accurately. Executive summary | Store analysis 305 ( 37.5%) 508 (62.5%) FY18 387 (41.5%) 545 (58.5%) FY19 540 (41.8%) 753 (58.2%) FY20 Franchisee Sales by Region • Number of franchisee stores by main regions are as follows as of FY 20 : Gyeonggi - do ( 56 ), Seoul ( 34 ), Gyeongbuk ( 22 ), Gyeongnam ( 21 ), and Daegu ( 18 ) . Franchisee sales by main region are as follows : Gyeonggi (KRW 33 . 2 bn), Seoul (KRW 23 . 7 bn), Incheon (KRW 11 bn), Busan (KRW 8 bn), and Gyeongbuk (KRW 7 . 9 bn) . Revenues are higher in metropolitan regions managed by the branch office due to high ASPS of metropolitan stores . - In FY 18 , some franchisee stores did not use the head office’s POS system, making sales information unavailable . Therefore, partial discrepancies might exist for ASPS . - In FY 20 , ASPS is about KRW 2 . 3 mn for metropolitan stores and KRW 1 . 3 mn for local stores . ASPS by area is about KRW 10 . 7 mn in metropolitan area and KRW 6 . 3 mn in local area . The logistics margin the Company receives from Jungsung Food makes up 12 . 5 % of metropolitan stores’ revenue, and 6 . 5 % of local stores’ revenue, so the growth in metropolitan stores sales provides upside of growth in logistics margin . • Until FY 18 , metropolitan franchisee sales made up about 62 . 5 % of total franchisee sales, but it decreased to 58 . 2 % starting FY 19 , as the revenue from local stores also increased due to improved brand awareness following aggressive advertising campaigns and discount events via Baemin , Yogiyo , etc . Unit: KRW 0.1bn 2 1 * When calculating ASPS, the number of business days in each year was computed based on the opening date provided by the company, but the opening date information is not accurate for transferred stores and might have some discrepancies (calculated for 26 business days a month). ASPS of newly opened stores in FY18 - 20 is lower than that of pre - 2018 stores. Executive summary | Store analysis Revenue Vintage • Sales by franchisees that have existed pre - FY18 grew about KRW 30.4bn in FY18 - 20 (yearly average of 18.1%) and sales by franchisees that opened in FY18 - 20 grew about KRW 17.6bn in the same period (yearly average of 123.7%). • ASPS of metropolitan stores is about KRW 1mn higher than that of local stores managed by the head office. In FY20, ASPS of pre - 2018 stores is about KRW 1.8mn, ASPS of newly opened stores in FY18 is about KRW 1.6mn, ASPS of newly opened stores in FY19 is about KRW 1.2mn, and ASPS of newly opened stores in FY20 is about KRW 1.2mn. According to Target, brand awareness has improved to shorten the revenue ramp - up period. • ASPS increased significantly in FY19 - 20 in both existing and new stores, owing to the improved brand awareness through the increase in TV commercials and celebrity model advertisements starting FY19. According to Target, many stores saw an increase in revenue after the transfer of existing stores due to the difference in owners’ capabilities. • As monthly sales by franchisees for FY18 - 19 was not provided, seasonality analysis is limited, but as seen from the FY20 monthly revenue analysis, brand popularity and revenue increased with Baemin and Yogiyo discounts in Feb - 20 to Jul - 20 and Nego King discount event in Sep - 20. According to the Company, the revenue increase in Dec - 20 is attributable to the increase in brand popularity and revenue during Christmas and New Year’s season events. Executive summary | Net debt Net debt • As of Dec - 20, the head office’s reported net debt is KRW 2.5bn, consisting of KRW 0.13bn cash, KRW 0.34bn short - term investments, and KRW 3bn long - term borrowings. Adjusted net cash reflecting debt - like items is KRW 1.78bn. • Cash and Cash Equivalents: KRW 0.13bn in Daegu Bank savings account • Short - term Investments: Executives’ insurance consists of KRW 0.25bn in MetLife Insurance and KRW 96mn in Samsung Life Insurance . As of Apr - 21, the estimated amount of refund upon cancellation is KRW 0.24bn from MetLife Insurance (return rate: 79.2%) and KRW 0.1bn from Samsung Life Insurance (return rate: 103%). • Long - term Borrowings: The loans borrowed from Daegu Bank with the maturity and interest rate as follows: Debt(Cash) - like items • Real Estate Investment, Guarantee Deposits: The expected sales price and deposits receivable from the real estate investment have been reflected as cash - like items, as the building is planned to be sold after due diligence. No tax effect is considered. • Short - term Borrowings from Shareholders, Executives, and Employees: According to the interview, the head office has borrowed funds from the CEO when there is a shortage of corporate funds or reaching the credit limit. There is currently no outstanding debt to be repaid to the CEO. • Retirement Allowance: The one - time retirement allowance for employees, who have provided service for over a year with no outside funds for retirement allowance as of Dec - 20, is reflected as a debt - like item. • Accrued Taxes and Prepaid Taxes: Consists of accrued value added taxes for FY20 and pre - paid corporate taxes for FY20 Net debt KRWm Dec-20 Cash and Cash Equivalents (131) Short-term Investment Assets (344) Long-term Borrowings 3,000 Reported net debt 2,525 Debt (Cash) like items Investment in Real Estate 1 (4,690) Guarantee Deposits Receivable 1 160 Short-term Borrowings from Shareholders, Executives, and Employees 24 Estimated Retirement Allowance 177 Accrued Taxes 261 Prepaid Taxes (236) (4,303) Adjusted net cash (1,778) Source: Management information Institution Amount Expiration date Interest rate Notes DGB Daegu Bank 2,000 2021-09-05 2.5% At maturity DGB Daegu Bank 1,000 2023-07-31 2.5% At maturity 3,000 Soure: Management information CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven | May 2021 27 One page summary FY21 update Accounting adjustment EBITDA bridge Revenue GP Normalized EBITDA Store analysis Net debt 202 202 302 46.0% 52.1% 42.7% FY18 FY19 FY20 Tomato Sauce Capacity Utility The head office has two factories: Factory 1 to produce dough and garlic sauce and Factory 2 to produce tomato sauce and sweet potato sauce . According to the interview, tomato sauce line is operating at a maximum capacity and expansion of one additional line is deemed necessary. Executive summary | Capacity & utilization Factory 1 1 Factory 2 1 (Unit: 1,000ea) (Unit: 1,000ea) Factory 1 • Dough: Two out of three lines are being operated. Only two lines were operated until FY19 with one line added in FY20. Assuming two shifts, FY20 capacity is 17,568k and utilization rate is 30%. • Garlic Sauce: There is one automated facility for garlic sauce pouches. The number of franchisee stores in FY20 is 261 and the company believes one additional line would need to be added upon opening the 350 th franchisee store. Assuming two shifts, FY20 capacity of garlic sauce pouches is 17,760k, and 336k kg of 3 kg garlic sauce jars. The utilization rates are 70% and 20%, respectively. Factory 2 • Tomato Sauce: The operation exceeded 100% due to special shifts and remaining jobs over regular hours in FY19, so one more line was added in FY20. The company is operating three tomato sauce lines to maximum capacity as of Apr - 21, and one more line would need to be added immediately. Assuming two shifts, FY20 capacity is 302k and utilization rate is 43%. • Sweet Potato Sauce: One line of sweet potato sauce was added in FY20 to operate a total of two lines. Assuming two shifts, FY20 capacity is 1,258k and utilization rate is 19% . 1 The capacity and utilization rate was computed assuming two shifts. 11,712 11,712 17,568 32% 36% 30% FY18 FY19 FY20 Dough Capacity Utility 17,760 17,760 33% 35% FY19 FY20 Garlic Sauce Pouch Capacity Utility 336 336 336 23% 8% 10% FY18 FY19 FY20 Garlic Sauce (3kg) Capacity Utility 629 629 1,258 21.3% 26.4% 19.1% FY18 FY19 FY20 Sweet Potato Mousse Capacity Utility CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven | May 2021 28 Revenue COGS SG&A Labor cost Non - operating income and Net working capital Accounts receivable Accounts payable Other working capital Supporting analysis CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven | May 2021 29 Revenue COGS SG&A Labor cost Non - operating income and Net working capital Accounts receivable Accounts payable Other working capital Revenue • Finished Goods Sales - The head office manufactures dough, garlic sauce, tomato sauce, and sweet potato mousse and supplies to Jungsung Food . In FY 18 - 19 , sales increased by about KRW 1 . 3 bn due to the increase of ASP . Sales increased by about KRW 2 . 3 bn in FY 19 - 20 due to an increase in the number of franchisee stores and their ASPS . • Franchise Income - Franchise Fee Revenue : Consists of KRW 10 mn franchise fee revenue and KRW 2 mn training fees collected from franchisee stores upon opening . - Radio Advertising Fees : The head office receives KRW 150 k a month from franchisees for radio advertising and the annual average of radio advertising fees increased by 20 . 3 % in FY 18 - 20 due to the increase in the number of franchisee stores . - Logistics Margin : The head office receives commission for the food ingredients Jungsung Food supplies to the franchisee stores (excluding factory - made products) . Therefore, the annual average of logistics margin increased by 40 . 1 % in FY 18 - 20 as the revenues of franchisee stores increased with more store openings and greater ASPS . • Merchandise sales : When new franchisee store opens, KRW 18 mn is collected for kitchen supplies . The sales from uniforms and pizza bags are also included . Supporting analysis | Revenue In FY20, the head office’s total revenue is KRW 13.5bn, which consists of KRW 9.2bn finished goods sales from selling dough and sauces, KRW 3.9bn franchise income including KRW 2.9bn logistics margin, KRW 0.3bn merchandise sales, and KRW 0.1bn rental income. 1 In FY19, onions for the pizza sauce were over - purchased and a portion was resold to a wholesaler. The total cost of raw materials increased by 23 . 9 % in FY 18 - 20 due to the increase in finished goods sales, but the ratio of raw materials to revenues increased from 34 . 6 % in FY 18 to 32 . 5 % in FY 20 due to the decrease in average purchase price, following an increase in the volume of purchase and fluctuations of market prices (see ‘Appendices | APP Trend’ for APP fluctuation of major raw materials) . • Labor Cost : The number of full - time factory workers increased from 13 to 16 since Factory 2 was established in FY 20 , so the cost of labor for production increased by about KRW 0 . 15 bn compared to FY 19 . • Manufacturing Expenses - Packaging Cost : Cost of purchasing plastic and box packages for dough and sauces . Increased by an annual average rate of 21 . 6 % in FY 18 - 20 due to an increase in the finished goods sales . - Supplies Expenses : Supplies expenses include the cost of mechanical parts, gloves, and masks . A portion of FY 20 expenses was included in the normalization items as some machineries including the freezer storage, feeder, and steamer purchased upon the acquisition of Factory 2 in FY 20 (about KRW 70 mn), were expensed as COGS, not capitalized, due to an accounting error . Cost of Merchandise Sold • The cost of kitchen supplies related to the sale of kitchen supplies to new franchisee stores and the cost of merchandise, such as the uniforms and pizza bags . The head office’s cost - to - sales ratio decreased from 54.0% in FY18 to 49.8% in FY20 and this mainly owes to the decrease in raw material ratio due to the decrease in average purchase price of raw materials and the decrease in fixed ratio due to an increase in revenues. SG&A expenses increased from FY19 due to aggressive marketing activities. Supporting analysis | SG&A SG&A • In FY 20 , SG&A expenses of KRW 4 . 2 bn consist of KRW 0 . 36 bn labor cost, KRW 2 . 4 bn advertisement cost, and KRW 0 . 56 bn sales promotion cost . KRW 3 . 4 bn increase of SG&A expenses in FY 19 - 20 mainly owes to KRW 0 . 52 bn sales promotion cost, KRW 0 . 14 bn supplies expenses, and KRW 60 mn sales incentives . • Labor Cost : Shows increasing trend year over year due to the increasing number of employees and minimum wage . See ‘Supporting Analysis | Labor Cost’ for details . • Advertisement Expenses : Advertisement expenses in FY 20 consists of KRW 1 . 6 bn advertising expenses for SBS TV ads, KRW 0 . 25 bn model fees, KRW 0 . 21 bn TV commercial production cost, and other SNS advertising expenses . Advertising expenses increased from FY 19 due to the increase in TV commercials and contracts with celebrity models . Breakdown of advertising expenses is as follows : ‒ TV : Includes TV commercial production cost and advertising fees paid to the broadcasting stations . TV commercial cost increased from FY 19 due to aggressive advertising activities . ‒ SNS : Mostly the cost of advertising on Facebook that began in FY 20 . ‒ Model Fees : The cost of celebrity models . Mostly renewed every 2 years and KRW 0 . 26 bn recorded in FY 18 was adjusted into a normalized item in FY 19 . • Sales Promotion Cost : The head office issued coupons on delivery apps since Nov - 19 to promote sales, and sales promotion cost increased due to discount events through Nego King, a Youtube channel, in FY 20 . • Depreciation : Consists of depreciation expenses of Factory 1 and the HQ office in Hwanggeum - dong . Increase in FY 19 - 20 is due to the expansion of Factory 2 in FY 20 . SG&A expenses increased from FY19 due to aggressive marketing activities. Supporting analysis | SG&A SG&A (Cont’d) • Supplies Expenses : Consists of the cost of steelworks station and other supplies . Increased from FY 19 as the cost of selling kitchen supplies was recorded as SG&A supplies expenses, not COGS – Merchandise . The amount of such cost of kitchen supplies was KRW 0 . 14 bn in FY 20 . • Fees Paid : Following is the list of fees paid each year . Fees increased from FY 20 due to the use of website and apps, the acquisition of Factory 2 , and the move of HQ office . ‒ Realtor Fees : Consists of FY 18 Suseongmot commercial real estate realtor fees, FY 20 Hwanggeum - dong HQ office rental and Factory 2 acquisition realtor fees, all reflected as normalized item . ‒ Tax, Accounting, and Labor Advisory Fees : The head office hires labor affairs specialist for HR and tax affairs specialist for accounting and tax affairs . Tax specialist fees paid for the advisory on gift of shares is reflected as normalized item . ‒ Advisory Fees : Attorney fees for a lawsuit filed by the head office in FY 19 , which is reflected as normalized item . ‒ Registration Fees : Law affairs fees for the acquisition of membership in FY 18 , which is reflected as normalized item . SG&A expenses increased from FY19 due to aggressive marketing activities. Supporting analysis | SG&A SG&A (Cont’d) • Lease – Vehicles : Consists of KRW 43 mn operating lease for CEO’s vehicle and KRW 27 mn corporate car lease . • Sales Incentive : As the logo changed in FY 20 , the head office decided to sponsor KRW 500 k to franchisees that voluntarily replace signboard within 2 years from FY 20 . Reflected on Normalized EBITDA as a non - recurring cost . • Rent Expenses : Among the rent paid in FY 18 , KRW 11 mn is the cost of car lease . Hwanggeum - dong HQ office has been rented from Nov - 19 (KRW 3 mn monthly rent) . Target started to pay KRW 7 . 8 mn rental expenses to C&T Tech in FY 20 for its management of website and app . • Insurance Fees : Consists of head office’s car insurance fees, government - mandated employee insurance fees and KRW 11 mn executive management insurance fees which is reflected as normalized item as it will no longer be incurred in the future . • Other : Consists of KRW 15 mn entertainment expenses, KRW 15 mn travel and transportation expenses, KRW 15 mn vehicle maintenance expenses, and KRW 7 mn building management expenses . The labor cost have also been increasing due to the rise in salaries for related parties. Supporting analysis | Labor cost Labor cost 1. Salaries: Calculated based on total salaries in the company’s payroll register. - CEO and related parties: The CEO’s wife was employed in Nov - 19 and her salary doubled in FY20, increasing the salaries for related parties from KRW 0.36bn to KRW 0.43bn in FY20. - Employees: As Factory 2 opened and the average number of full - time factory workers increased from 13 to 16, manufacture - related labor cost increased from KRW 0.35bn in FY19 to KRW 0.52bn in FY20. - Daily Workers: Labor cost increased in FY18 - 19 with the increase in the number of daily workers hired, following the growth in business. Their wages decreased as some of them were transitioned to full - time employees in FY20. 2. Retirement Benefits - Represents i ) actual payment of severance benefits for retired employees, and ii) amounts contributed to the DC plan employees. 3. Welfare Expenses - Sum of employer portion of health insurance and occupational insurance fees. Related expenses increased following the increase in the number of full - time employees in FY20. 2 Related parties: CEO and CEO’s family (father, mother, spouse) 1 Salaries: The company pays unused paid vacation fees as incentives for holiday seasons and this is included in the total amount of salaries. Non - operating expenses mostly consists of loss on valuation of land properties. Supporting analysis | Non - operating income and expenses Non - operating income and expenses Non - operating Profit • Interest Income : Represents interest income from general savings account . • Return on Bad Debt Allowances : KRW 3 mn was returned from bad debt allowances in FY 18 . • Miscellaneous Income : Mostly consists of marketing grants supported by Jungsung Food and the branch office in regards to the sales promotion on online food delivery platforms including Baemin and Yogiyo . FY 20 miscellaneous income increased due to the increase of such grants and KRW 0 . 2 bn grants received from Jungsung Food and the branch office on the Nego King marketing event . Non - operating Expenses • Interest Expenses : Mostly represents lease interest expenses from the vehicle lease . • Loss on Valuation of Land : KRW 1 . 17 bn loss on valuation of land was recognized voluntarily in FY 20 to avoid asset conditions subject to external audit . Gain on disposition of tangible assets that do not exist may occur when the assets are sold in the future . • Donation : KRW 50 mn was donated to Red Cross Korea Daegu Office . Supporting analysis | Net working capital Net working capital • Trade Receivables - The head office does not have a contractual term set for the collection of trade receivables from Jungsung Food and generally records it in the financial statements based on the tax statements each month. Therefore, DSO is 33 - 41 days. • Inventory - The company changed accounting and tax offices in FY19 and does not record the inventory assets at the end of each term. Raw materials purchased from Jungsung Food (garlic, mayonnaise, tomatoes, etc.) are delivered daily, while flour is delivered once every 2 - 3 days, and sweet potatoes are purchased and stored considering market prices. - Finished goods: Generally shipped to Jungsung Food the next morning after production, and the ownership of inventories is transferred upon shipment, to leave no inventory risk for the head office. • Trade Payables - The company has almost no remaining trade payables at the end of each term as all purchases from Jungsung Food are settled at the end of each month, all purchases from other vendors are settled within a week, and flour purchased from SPC Samlip is deducted from KRW 60mn advance payment. Most of trade payables in FY19 and FY20 was accrued expenses for advertising. No agreed collection term with Jungsung Food exists, and 33 - 41 days of DSO is calculated as the financial statements are prepared based on each month’s tax statements . Analysis of Vendors • Jungsung Food : Jungsung Food is the head office’s main vendor . Upon the production of finished goods, products are supplied by Jungsung Food to franchisee stores . As of Dec - 20, the balance of trade receivables is KRW 1bn for Jungsung Food. The head office irregularly collects the receivables from Jungsung Food, therefore creating an inconsistency in DSO and end - of - term balance of trade receivables. The head office’s usage of trade payables and other payable accounts are not clearly divided and the payables for raw materials among the balance of trade payables at the end of FY20 is approximately KRW 1mn. Other payables for the purchase of machineries are sometimes recorded as trade payables . KRW 59 mn payables in FY 18 is recorded in the other payable account . • Yeongnam Machineries : Represents cost of steamers installed when Factory 2 was established in FY 20 . • Dongsan Distribution : Trade payables in relation to the purchase of onions . • Ajin ESR : Trade payables in relation to the purchase of freezer . Mostly consists of advance payments for the purchase of raw materials and accrued expenses related to salaries. Other working capital • Advance Payments ‒ Advance payments for raw materials: Dec - 20 balance represents advance payments for flour paid to SPC Samlip . The head office generally deposits KRW 60mn advance payments to SPC Samlip each month for flour and deducts the amount upon purchases. KRW 0.12bn advance payments as of Dec - 18 consists of KRW 0.1bn for the purchase of sweet potatoes and KRW 23mn for the purchase of flour. ‒ Other: As of Dec - 20, advance payments included KRW 26mn for the purchase of furniture for the Hwanggeum - dong office and KRW 1mn vehicle deposit. • Other Payables - Other payables for advertising: As of Dec - 18, other payables consists of payables of KRW 0.28bn celebrity model fees, KRW 59mn SBS TV commercials, and KRW 45mn for B&B Communications, an advertising agency. - Other: Dec - 18 balance includes payables for KRW 3.8mn in utility and KRW 8.2mn in car lease fees, fuel cost, and meal cost, similar to accrued expenses. The amount decreased from FY19 as it was recorded as accrued expenses. • Accrued Expenses - Accrued expenses for salaries: Represents accrued salaries as of the end of December each year. The accrued expenses increased to KRW 13mn for retirees at the end of December 2020. - Other: Consists of payables for KRW 3mn utility expenses , KRW 3.3mn tax consulting fees, and KRW 17mn credit card payments as of Dec - 20. • Advances from Customers - Advances for franchise fees: KRW 2mn is the upfront fees for the franchise contract, and the amount of advances increased as the number of new franchisee stores increased by the end of FY20. - Other: Consists of KRW 9.3mn from Nice Payments Inc. and KRW 5mn from Insight Ad as of Dec - 20. Supporting analysis | CapEx CapEx • Tangible Assets - KRW 3 . 66 bn acquisition cost of Factory 2 ( Maecheon Factory) in July 2020 and its relevant cost have been proportionately recorded under land and building . - In FY 20 , stainless steel machines and equipment have been purchased for Factory 1 , but they were expensed as COGS - supplies, not capitalized . The machinery CapEx amount on the table represents the reclassified amounts from COGS to fixed assets . See ‘Executive Summary | Accounting Adjustment’ and ‘Appendices’ for detail . - CapEx for vehicles in FY 20 is related to KRW 13 mn purchase of forklifts . - In FY 19 , KRW 35 mn of fixtures and furniture were acquired for the HQ office in Hwanggeum - dong . - In FY 19 , Target remodeled HQ office which incurred CapEx of KRW 0 . 13 bn for the facilities installed and KRW 0 . 05 bn for others . In FY 20 , the acquisition of Factory 2 incurred CapEx of KRW 0 . 11 bn for the installation of facilities and equipment . • Intangible Assets - Represents development cost of website and mobile application . The amount of capitalized cost was KRW 45 mn in FY 19 and KRW 47 mn in FY 20 . Maintenance CapEx • Tangible Assets - In FY 19 and FY 20 , Maintenance CapEx occurred for the purchase of machinery due to the purchase of Sammyeon Packaging Machine . - In FY 18 , KRW 0 . 2 bn Maintenance CapEx occurred for the purchase of CEO’s vehicle . - In FY 20 , Maintenance CapEx occurred for the purchase of computers and office supplies . - In FY 20 , compressors and stainless steel equipment were purchased for Factory 2 . Supporting analysis | Fixed assets Fixed Assets • Tangible Assets : As of Dec - 20 , the balance is KRW 9 . 22 bn which composes 80 . 0 % of total assets . The acquisition of Factory 2 attributed to the increase in Dec - 20 balance . 1. Land: Following the FY20 Factory 2 acquisition, Target recognized loss on valuation of land voluntarily to avoid the condition subject to external audit. Therefore, land was recorded at KRW 1.1bn lower value than the actual value. See ‘Executive summary | Accounting Adjustment’ for detail. 2. Buildings: Factory 2 building was acquired in July FY20. Vehicles : Dec - 18 balance increased due to the acquisition of a Benz - Mercedes vehicle. As of Dec - 20, the balance consists of KRW 12mn for two forklifts, KRW 80mn for a Benz - Mercedes vehicle, and KRW 0.4mn for a Damas vehicle. 5. Tools and Equipment: KRW 17mn originally classified as COGS - supplies in need of reclassification into ‘tools and equipment,’ including KRW 6mn steam pots acquired in FY16, FY17. See ‘Executive Summary | Accounting Adjustment’ for detail. 6. Fixtures and Furniture : Increased in Dec - 19 due to the installation of desks and other furniture in Hwanggeum - dong HQ office . As of Dec - 20 , the balance consists of KRW 15 mn office furniture, KRW 5 mn computer - related instruments, and KRW 3 mn kitchen - related supplies . 7. Facilities : In FY 19 , the amount of facilities increased by KRW 0 . 17 bn due to the interior decoration of Hwanggeum - dong office and remodeling of Factory 1 . As of Dec - 20 , the balance consists of KRW 7 mn for the facilities in Factory 1 , KRW 85 mn for office interiors, and 86 mn KRW for the facilities in Factory 2 . • Intangible Assets : The company has membership with unlimited years of service, and goodwill, industrial property rights, and development assets with limited years of service . All of these assets are amortized in accordance with the accounting standards . 8. Goodwill : Amortized at a flat rate . The goodwill was recognized when converting the sole proprietorship into a corporation in FY 16 and the net book value as of Dec - 20 is KRW 26 mn . 9. Industrial Property Rights : The trademark for ‘ Banolim Pizza’ acquired in FY 17 for KRW 25 mn is amortized at a flat rate, and the balance as of Dec - 20 is KRW 10 mn . 10. Development Cost : In FY 19 and FY 20 , development cost incurred for the development of app and website . The balance as of Dec - 20 is KRW 86 mn . 11. Membership : The resort membership acquired in FY 16 is still in use and has not been amortized as it has unlimited years of service . Net book value as of Dec - 20 is KRW 0 . 13 bn . Please consider the following along with the previous contents of the Report: Overview • The scope of service shall refer to the service contract we signed with the Company in April 2021. • The information in the final report includes that deems to be most important for the Company among the findings of the service within the agreed scope and does not contain all of the available information . • The final report does not include accounting audit under the corporate accounting standards and accounting audit standards, review of internal accounting management systems, and other verification or review services. Therefore, we do not provide any opinion about the Company’s Financial Statements . Course of Onsite Visit and Collection of Information • We received all required information through emails and interviews with Target between April 5, 2021 and May 7, 2021. • The interview with the representative of Target took place through face - to - face QnA and written questions. - Face - to - face QnA : April 14 - 15, 2021, Banolim Food, head office - Written QnA : April 5, 2021 - May 7, 2021 CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven | May 2021 46 A1: Scope A2: Bases of work IS overview Financial Statements of Franchise income and Recurring vs. Regional Vintage Sales - Finished Goods PQ APP trend Labor Cost of Related Appendices | A2: Bases of work • The integrity of reductions in account receivables, inventories, tangible assets, and other assets, along with trade payables, liabilities, and other liabilities was executed limitedly. Therefore, we do not guarantee the possible insolvency of Target’s assets and the integrity of liabilities. • The report does not consider the negative impact of COVID - 19 on Target’s sale, production, supply networks, or other performances. Therefore, customers are advised to broadly consider the negative impact of COVID - 19 on the Korean and global economy and financial markets and how it affects Target’s financial conditions. Limitations Please note that our service has the following limitations: • Our financial due diligence is the result of due diligence according to the agreed procedure and does not include any accounting audit under the generally accepted corporate accounting standards and accounting audit standards, review of internal control, and other verification and review. Therefore, please note that we do not express any opinion about the Company’s Financial Statements and estimated financial statements. • We followed the scope of service and procedure mentioned in the service contract with the Company and the current Due Diligence Report to perform the service and does not guarantee that the scope and procedure of our service were sufficient for the purpose of the due diligence report and other purposes. • We have not verified the accuracy, reliability, and integrity of Target’s information and resources included in the Report and we do not provide any guarantee over the accuracy of Target’s information and resources. • We have not reviewed Target’s estimated cost list, but briefly reviewed the Company’s business prospectus. Therefore, we do not guarantee the progress of projects which Target has applied or will apply to recognize and estimate the revenue. • Our due diligence report must be used for the original purpose of the service contract. Therefore, the due diligence shall not be used for other purposes and the investors and the Company cannot provide the report to any third party without our prior consent. Also, our service shall not be mentioned without our written consent and we will not be responsible for any third party that receives the due diligence report without our consent under any circumstances. Franchise profit increased as a portion of sales from kitchen supplies which used to be classified into 'Merchandise sales' has been reclassified into franchise profit from FY20. • Cost of Sale: 12mn KRW occurs for each new franchisee store opening in the metropolitan area for kitchen equipment. • Selling and Administrative Expenses: In FY20, it consisted of 0.4bn KRW labor cost, 0.44bn KRW depreciation of goodwill, and 0.14bn KRW consumables. In FY20, 0.13bn KRW of consumables included the cost of kitchen equipment, which is the cost of 'Merchandise sales'. • Non - operating Profit: Miscellaneous income increased in FY20 as 29mn KRW liquidated damage occurred due to the president’s car accident. • Non - operating Expenses: In FY20, 25mn KRW was donated for COVID - 19 relief and non - operating expenses increased accordingly. Finished Goods PQ APP trend Labor Cost of Related Parties Appendices | FY21 update Account Assumptions (1QFY21) Assumptions (9MFY20) Revenue • Based on purchase and sales ledger of tax statements. • Sales of Apr - Dec 20 from GL details COGS COGS - Merchandise • Based on purchase and sales ledger of tax statements. • Applied 66.5%, the ratio of cost of merchandise in FY20 (cost rate before re - classification of cost of sale of kitchen supplies). Material Cost • Based on purchase and sales ledger of tax statements. • Applied 49.4%, the ratio of cost of finished goods to sales in FY20. Labor Cost • Salaries: Calculated by multiplying KRW 297mn, which is the total salaries of Q1 FY21, by 65.8%, the ratio of COGS labor cost to total labor cost in FY20. • Retirement Benefits = Salary x 1/12 Manufacturing Expenses • Manufacturing expenses excluding the depreciation cost is based on purchase and sales ledger of tax statements. • Depreciation cost = Depreciation cost of FY20 x 1/4 (1/3) Labor Cost COGS vs. SG&A FY20 KRWm Total COGS SG&A Related parties 433 205 228 Employees 689 523 166 COGS 523 523 - SG&A 166 - 166 Daily Workers 28 28 - 1,151 757 394 Percentage 100.0% 65.8% 34.2% CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven | May 2021 70 A1: Scope A2: Bases of work IS overview Financial Statements of Franchise income and Recurring vs. Regional Vintage Sales - Finished Goods PQ APP trend Labor Cost of Related Parties Appendices | FY21 update Account Assumptions (1QFY21) Assumptions (9MFY20) SG&A Depreciation Expense • Depreciation Expense = FY20 Depreciation Expense x 1/4 • Calculated by i ) computing the total SG&A expenses of 9MFY20 by applying 35.3% SG&A to sales ratio in FY20 and ii) multiplying it by the ratio to total SG&A expenses of each SG&A account in FY20. Advertising Expense • Applied 1/4 of KRW 0.8bn celebrity contract fees and KRW 0.25bn TV commercial production fees. Labor Cost • Calculated by multiplying KRW 297mn, which is the total salaries of Q1 FY21, by 34.2%, the ratio of SG&A labor costs to total labor cost in FY20. • Retirement Benefits = Salary x 1/12 Other SG&A • Based on purchase and sales ledger of tax statements Supplies Expenses • See details on reclassification of COGS cost of merchandise. (2/3) Labor Cost COGS vs. SG&A FY20 KRWm Total COGS SG&A Related parties 433 205 228 Employees 689 523 166 COGS 523 523 - SG&A 166 - 166 Daily Workers 28 28 - 1,151 757 394 Percentage 100.0% 65.8% 34.2% CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven | May 2021 71 A1: Scope A2: Bases of work IS overview Financial Statements of Franchise income and Recurring vs. Regional Vintage Sales - Finished Goods PQ APP trend Labor Cost of Related Parties Appendices | FY21 update Account Reclassification of Sales of Merchandise & Cost of Merchandise Revenue • The sales of 9MFY20 reflects the sales of Apr - Dec 20 from the GL detail and the sales of 1QFY21 is based on purchase and sales ledger of tax statements. • The sales of kitchen supplies sold to newly opening stores was recorded as the merchandise sales in FY18 - 19, but in the franchise income in FY20 - 1QFY21. For comparability, the sales of kitchen supplies of LTM - 1QFY21 was re - classified into the merchandise sales. The reclassification amount of LTM21 franchise income → merchandise sales was calculated by applying the ratio of FY20 reclassification amount to total franchise income. COGS • The cost of sales of kitchen supplies sold mentioned above was recorded as the COGS – Merchandise in FY18 - 19, but in the SG&A su pplies expenses in FY20 - 1QFY21. For comparability, the supplies expenses for such costs of sales of kitchen supplies of LTM - 1QFY21 was re - classified into the COGS – Merchandise. The reclassification amount of LTM21 supplies expense → COGS – merchandise was computed by applying the ratio of FY20 reclassification amount to total supplies expenses. (3/3) FY20 Reclassification Rate KRWm FY20 Franchise income before reclassification 5,894 Merchandise sales reclassification 467 Reclassification rate 7.9% LTM-1QFY21 Reclassification KRWm Before Adj.1 After Franchise income 6,676 (529) 6,146 Merchandise sales 25 529 554 6,700 - 6,700 1 529 = 6,676 x 7.9% FY20 Reclassification Rate KRWm FY20 Supplies exp. before reclassification 294 COGS - Merchandise reclassification 271 Reclassification rate 92.0% LTM-1QFY21 Reclassification KRWm Before Adj.1 After Supplies Expense 384 (353) 31 COGS - Merchandise 25 353 378 409 - 409 1 353 = 384 x 92.0% CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven | May 2021 72 A1: Scope A2: Bases of work IS overview Financial Statements of Franchise income and Recurring vs. Regional Vintage Sales - Finished Goods PQ APP trend Labor Cost of Related Appendices | Goodwill According to the interview, assuming KRW 40mn average monthly franchisee sale, the goodwill occurred when transferring ownership is often around KRW 60mn. Based on the simple calculation confirmed with the Target, a franchisee with monthly sales of KRW 40mn would earn an average monthly margin of KRW 14mn; therefore, the premium of KRW 60mn is close to four month’s worth of monthly margins. KRWm Annualized Notes Sales 480 Raw material cost 192 According to the interview, around 40% of franchisee sales is raw material cost. Rental expenses 7 Calculated yearly lease based on the average monthly rent price (KRW 0.55mn) of stores with FY20 annual sales of around KRW 480mn (Chungnam Dangjin Store, Daegu Gyeongdae Store, Chungnam Asan Baebang Tangjeong Store, Daegu Seongseo Store) Labor cost 72 Assuming 3 employees, KRW 2mn per month per employee (Without considerations of the owner's labor cost) Delivery app fee 38 Assuming 80% of yearly sales come from delivery platforms, and platform commissions of 10% Utility 4 Assuming KRW 0.3mn per month Margin [167] CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven | May 2021 73 A1: Scope A2: Bases of work IS overview Financial Statements of Franchise income and Recurring vs. Regional Vintage Sales - Finished Goods PQ APP trend Labor Cost of Related Appendices | LTM 1QFY21 High - level normalization # 상세내용 0 Accounting adjustments ‒ Retirement Benefits, Paid Vacation Expenses: Applied same amount of FY20, assuming change in the amount year over year would be immaterial ‒ Expensed Factory Facilities: Since it was expensed consistently throughout FY20, applied 9 - month portion of FY20 adjusting amount for LTM 1QFY21 adjustment ‒ SG&A Cutoff Adjustment: Applied same amount of FY20 as the expenses incurred at the end of FY20 1 Applied same amount of FY20 as there is no change in the head count of related parties as of LTM 1QFY21 2 Applied same amount of FY20 as there is no change in accounting treatment regarding marketing grants received from Jungsung Food 3 As for the sales incentives regarding change of franchisee stores’ sign, applied 9 - month portion of FY20 adjusting amount, assuming no additional subsidies will be provided to franchisees in FY21. Applied same amount of FY20 for executives’ insurance fees and realtor fees for Factory 2 acquisition s the expenses incurred near the end of FY20. 4 Applied same amount of FY20 as the tax consulting fees with regards to gift of shares was incurred in November 2020. 5 Amount represents LTM 1QFY21 rental income from the investment real estate 6 The branch office’s normalization item include costs that occur consistently throughout the year, and therefore same amount of FY20 was adjusted. Project Beethoven Final Tax Due Diligence Report May 20 21 Strictly Private and Confidential English translation for Korean report CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com In particular, we may not have identified all facts or information provided to us, accordingly, we accept no responsibility for the reliability of the information to the extent it is inaccurate, incomplete or misleading, or for matters not covered by the Final Report or omitted due to the limited information or nature of our work. Our work and the Report should not be considered an adequate substitute for a normal scope investigation on which reliance could properly be placed as part of the process in making an investment decision. If you have additional requests or queries related to the Report, please contact Young Pil Kim(02-6676-2432) or Ji Yu Bae(02-6676-2807). May 2021 Dear Orchestra Private Equity Project Beethoven We enclose our Tax due diligence report (the “Report”) prepared in connection with the proposed transaction in accordance with the terms of the Memorandum(the “Contract”) with Orchestra Private Equity. The Report is confidential to you and is subject to the restrictions on use specified in the Contract. No party is entitled to rely on the Final Report for any purpose whatsoever and we accept no responsibility or liability to any party in respect of the contents of this Report. We draw your attention to Section named ‘Scope and Limitation’ in which we refer to the scope of our work, sources of information and the limitations of the work undertaken. Deloitte Anjin LLC CEO Jong Sung Hong 서명 또는 날인 Deloitte Anjin LLC 5F., One IFC, 23 Yoido-dong, Youngdeungpo-gu, Seoul 150-876, Korea Tel:02-6676-1000, 2100 Fax:02-6674-1400, 1600 CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven- Final Tax Due Diligence Report 3 Section Page Executive Summary 3 Tax Audit 10 Findings of Due Diligence 12 Appendix 20 CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven- Final Tax Due Diligence Report 4 § The following summarizes the findings as a result of the Company’s tax due diligence: § Interest penalty is estimated as of May 7, 2021. § Some of the above findings may not be taxed as a result of the tax authority’s tax investigation. Also, please note that there may be potential tax risks not included in the findings due to the limitations concerning the duration of due diligence and access to resources. Summary of Findings ( Unit: 1 mn KRW ) CIT (A) VAT (B) Withholdings (C) Total Estimated Tax (A+B+C) Risk Level Unregistered Property (Building in Dusan-dong) 10 10 High Franchise Profit 97 45 142 High Labor Cost of Related parties 22 36 58 High Sub- total 119 55 36 210 Business-use Vehicles - 67 67 Medium Contract with Jungsung Food Non-quantifiable Low Total 119 55 103 277 Executive Summary- Summary of Findings Executive Summary Tax Audit Findings Appendix CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven- Final Tax Due Diligence Report 5 Items Key Findings Implications General Considerations • Banolim Food Co., Ltd. (the “Target”) has its head office at 1F and 2F 17-12 Nowon-ro 9-gil Buk-gu, Daegu (Nowon-dong 3-ga) and has adopted the Business Unit Taxation System under the Value-added Tax Act since January 1, 2021. • The subsequent properties of business registered in the Business License issued on December 21, 2020 are (i) Factory 2 and (ii) Dusan office. • The Business Unit Taxation System means that the head office shall be responsible for business registration, issuing tax statements, reporting and paying VAT, and making corrections for tax purposes. Scope of Service • The taxation period of each account reviewed during the tax due diligence is as follows: Ø Income Tax: FY2017 ~ FY2020 Ø VAT: Estimates for 2017 1Q ~ Finalized for 2020 2Q Ø Withholdings: Jan 2017 ~ Dec 2020 Ø Local Tax: Jan 2017 ~ Oct 2019 • According to the Framework Act on National Taxes and Framework Act on Local Taxes, national taxes and local taxes may be levied for up to five years, so the tax authority cannot levy additional taxes on taxpayers when five years have elapsed from the point when national taxes and local taxes may be levied. Tax Audit • The Target was investigated by Daegu Regional Tax Office for the income tax reported and paid from 2016 through 2018 in 2019. As a result of investigation, it was levied about 48 mn KRW of penalty tax and the amount was paid in full during 2020. • Generally, redundant tax audit is not allowed for the same tax accounts and the same tax periods, so it is actually construed that all fiscal years prior to 2018 have been closed for income tax. • According to the Target, the items found during the tax investigation in 2019 are properly managed and there are no recurring issues. Executive Summary – General Penalties Target FY Detail Penalty Tax Missing Revenue (Tax statements not issued for furnishings and supplies for newly opening franchisees and revenue missing) FY2016 - 2017 CIT 19 mn KRW VAT 12 mn KRW Withholdings for incentives for CEO (missing revenue recorded as incentives for CEO) FY2016 - 2017 WHT 17 mn KRW Executive Summary Tax Audit Findings Appendix CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven- Final Tax Due Diligence Report 6 Items Key Findings Implications Certificate of Tax Payment § According to the national tax clearance certificate provided to us, we have confirmed that Target did not have any outstanding national and local tax liabilities as of the issuance date. § However, these certificates themselves do not provide any assurance that Target do not have any outstanding tax liability issues. Instead, the certificates simply confirm that all taxes reported by Target or assessed by the tax authorities until the issuance date are paid and that there are no taxes in arrears as of the issuance date. § Therefore, please note that these certificates do not eliminate the possibility of additional taxation being imposed in a future tax audit. Executive Summary – General (Cont’d) Account Date Issued Validity Past Due Issuer National Tax Apr 13, 2021 May 13, 2021 None Bukdaegu Tax Office Local Tax Apr 13, 2021 May 13, 2021 None Daegu Buk-gu District Office Executive Summary Tax Audit Findings Appendix CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven- Final Tax Due Diligence Report 7 Items Key Findings Implications Unregistered Property (Building in Dusan-dong) • According to the VATL, business registration is based on the business place, not the owner of business, so the owner shall register any new places of business even after receiving the business license for the initial place and report VAT for all places of business. However, any owner with two or more places may register the head office of business with the local tax authority to handle business registration, issuing tax statements, reporting and paying VAT, and making corrections for tax purposes (Business Unit Taxation System). • The Target acquired a building in Dusan-dong, Daegu as of November 2017 to run a business as a landlord, but included the income from lease in the Target head office’s VAT base of taxation without an additional business license. When the building in Dusan- dong was registered as a subordinate place on January 1, 2021, the Target applied for the Business Unit Taxation System • According to the VATL Execution Standards #60-0- 8 【 Additional Tax for Base of Taxation of Unregistered place of business Reported by Existing Businesses, if a business owner reports and pays taxes for unregistered place of business included in the tax report of the existing place of business without registering, the base of taxation and tax amount of unregistered place of business shall be determined and levied. Also, the penalty of non- issued invoices and non-reported penalty shall be applied. • The estimated amount of tax risks is 10 mn KRW. Franchise Profit • When the Target opens a new franchisee store, the franchisee pays the head office and Banolim Food Seoul a total of 30 mn KRW for franchise fees (including training fees and kitchen supplies). (i) Local franchisees pay all 30 mn KRW to the Target, while (2) Metropolitan franchisees pay 5 mn KRW to the Target and the remaining 25 mn KRW to Banolim Food Seoul. • Also, even when the Target’s franchisee store is transferred, the franchisee pays the head office and Banolim Food Seoul a total of 12 mn KRW for franchisee fees (except training fees and kitchen supplies). (i) Local franchisees pay all 12 mn KRW to the Target, while (2) Metropolitan franchisees pay 3 mn KRW to the Target and the remaining 9 mn KRW to Banolim Food Seoul. • In case of new store opening, 18 mn KRW out of 25 mn KRW which Banolim Food Seoul receives from franchisee is the cost of kitchen supplies and furnishings (purchased from third parties and resold with a certain rate of margin) with clear explanation. However, what Banolim Food Seoul provides in exchange for 7 mn KRW when opening a new franchisee store and 9 mn KRW when transferring a new franchisee store was unclear. • According to the Target, Banolim Food Seoul is the Target’s related party (CEO of Banolim Food Seoul: brother-in-law of the Target’s CEO) and the amount is collected without providing a particular service. • According to Article 52 【 Declination of Unjust Calculations 】 of the CITL, if it is acknowledged that an act of a local corporation or the calculation of income has unjustly reduced the corporation’s income tax due to a deal with a related party, the tax base shall be increased by the corresponding amount. The estimated amount of tax risks is 142 mn KRW. Executive Summary – Findings Executive Summary Tax Audit Findings Appendix CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven- Final Tax Due Diligence Report 8 Items Key Findings Implications Labor Cost of Related Party • The Target has hired the wife (Min Joo Lee) of CEO Sung Won Yoon, the dominating shareholder, as the head of Development Team and paid salaries from November 2019 through November 2020 and the retirement allowance on December 2020. However, it has been found that the wife did not provide service. • According to the Income Tax and related interpretations (Josim 2019 GU 48, etc.), if exceeding amount of wage is paid to the related parties of the shareholder without a valid reason or the history of service cannot be proven, deductible expenses will be declined as unjust reduction of income with fictitious labor cost. In this case, it can be appropriated as CEO’s bonus with unclear external expenses and the estimated amount of tax risks is 58 mn KRW. Business-use Vehicles • As of 2020, the Target has eight Business-use vehicles (including owned, lease, and rental) and the related expenses and any exclusions from deductible expenses as private expenses are as follows: • Currently, the rate of Business-use in report is over 90% in average, but according to the Target, it is noticed that the rate of corporate use is not recorded accurately. The amount of exclusions from deductible expenses would increase when the accurate rate of Business-use and the corresponding amount of WHT shall also increase. • According to the Target, there is no clear log of Business-use, the conservative limit shall be applied for corporations missing the log of corporate use in the CITL (FY2019: 10 mn KRW, FY2020: 15 mn KRW). When the tax risks are calculated by considering all existing cost as the cost of private use, the amount is 67 mn KRW. Executive Summary – Findings(Cont’d) Executive Summary Tax Audit Findings Appendix (Unit: 1 mn KRW) Account FY2019 FY2020 Total Appropriation Expenses Related to Business-use Vehicles 130 150 280 Total Exclusions from Deductible Expenses 81 86 167 Exclusions from Deductible Expenses (Private Use) 11 12 23 Bonuses Vehicle Lease 41 46 87 Other External Expenses Exceeding the Limit of Depreciation Cost 29 28 57 Reserved CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven- Final Tax Due Diligence Report 9 Items Key Findings Implications Contract with Jungsung Food • The Target 1) purchases some raw ingredients from Jungsung Food and 2) sells the products to Jungsung Food after production, so iii) Jungsung Food sells the products to the Target’s franchisees. The Target issues the tax statements to Jungsung Food for the total amount of sales- finished products. However, the Target does not have a contract with Jungsung Food (not a related party) concerning the deal. • According to the Value Added Tax, Josim-2016-SEO-3866, Nov 20, 2018, it can be determined whether it is a general supply of commodities or purchase service (or logistics agency). When Jungsung Food takes responsible for overall risks the product and makes purchases at Jungsung Food’s responsibility and cost, it is determined that the Target supplies commodities to Jungsung Food. This is the only case when tax statements can be issued for the total amount of sales-finished products, so it is advised to prepare the corresponding contract. • In fact, 1) the Target’s products are delivered to Jungsung Food’s warehouse and sold to the franchisees and 2) Jungsung Food has the right to determine the prices of products sold to the franchisee, it is highly likely that it may be deemed the supply of commodities. However, neither the Target nor Jungsung Food has taken responsibility for past inventories (defective products supplied to franchisees, etc.), so it would be clear evidence if there is a contract stipulating how to handle the inventories. • Also, according to Article 75 paragraphs 10 and 11 of the VATL Enforcement Decrees enacted in February 2021 and Josim 2020 SEO 0220, Jul 7, 2020, consigned trade has been acknowledged as valid tax statements as there was no evasion of VAT or distortion of trading under the VATL. Therefore, tax risks are limited. Executive Summary – Findings (Cont’d) Executive Summary Tax Audit Findings Appendix CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven- Final Tax Due Diligence Report 10 Section Page Executive Summary 3 Tax Audit 10 Findings of Due Diligence 12 Appendix 20 CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven- Final Tax Due Diligence Report 11 Overview • The Target was investigated by Daegu Regional Tax Office for the income tax reported and paid from 2016 through 2018 in 2019. As a result of investigation, it was levied about 31 mn KRW of tax and the amount was paid in full during 2020. • The following summarizes the information in the Tax Investigation Report: Review of Findings of Tax Audit • The Target was incorporated in 2016. In the early years, it sold supplies and furnishings to franchisees and did not issue some tax invoice and the sales amount was omitted the revenue on CITL. • As a result, CIT and VAT were levied along with penalty and the related WHT were added as the omitted amount was deemed as CEO’s bonuses. • The accounts and amounts of tax penalties are as follows : Implications of Tax Audit • According to the recourses provided by the Target and the interview with the Target, the items found during the tax investigation in 2019 are properly managed and there are no recurring issues. • General national taxes and local taxes may be levied for up to five years and redundant tax investigation is not allowed for the same tax accounts and the same tax periods, so it is actually construed that all fiscal years prior to 2019 have been closed for CIT except for particular cases, such as tax evasion charges. Authority NTS Daegu Regional Office Target Period From Jan 1, 2016 through Dec 31, 2018 Target Account Corporate Income Tax Amount of Tax (1) Increase in CIT Income: 74 mn KRW (2) CIT and penalty: Approx. 19 mn KRW (3) VAT and penalty: Approx. 12 mn KRW (4) WHT: Approx. 17 mn KRW Cash Expenditure (2)+(3) +(4): Approx. 48 mn KRW Estimated Date of Notice Dec 1, 2019 No. Penalty Fiscal Year Account Amount of Tax 1 Missing Revenue (Tax statements not issued for furnishings and supplies for newly opening franchisees and revenue missing) FY2016 - 2017 CIT 15 FY2016 - 2017 VAT 7 2 Withholdings for bonuses for CEO (missing revenue recorded as bonuses for CEO) FY2016 - 2017 WHT 17 Total CIT 15 VAT 7 WHT 17 Penalty 9 (Unit: 1 million KRW ) Executive Summary Tax Audit Findings Appendix Tax Audit CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven- Final Tax Due Diligence Report 12 Section Page Executive Summary 3 Scope of Tax Due Diligence 10 Findings of Due Diligence 12 Appendix 20 CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven- Final Tax Due Diligence Report 13 Tax | General General Information § Banolim Pizza Co., Ltd. (the “Target”) is a pizza franchiser and food manufacturer with main purposes in manufacture, wholesale, and retail. § The Target has its head office at 1F and 2F 17-12 Nowon-ro 9-gil Buk-gu, Daegu and has adopted the Business Unit Taxation System under the Value-added Tax Act since January 1, 2021 (Business License No.: 298-86-00407). The Business Unit Taxation System means that the head office shall be responsible for business registration, issuing tax statements, reporting and paying VAT, and making corrections for tax purposes. § The subsequent properties of business registered in the Business License issued on December 21, 2020 are (i) Factory 2 of Banolim Food Co., Ltd. (Maecheon-dong) and (ii) Dusan office of Banolim Food Co., Ltd. (Dusan-dong Shopping Center). Purpose of Tax Due Diligence § The purpose of tax due diligence is to review the validity of the Target’s tax report and proceedings and provide you with the potential tax risks identified as a result of the review to help with your decision-making process. Methodology of Tax Due Diligence § The tax due diligence was based on the limited resources provided between April 8, 2021 and May 6, 2021 (the “Due Diligence Period”) and the Target’s responses to the Company’s questions and the accuracy of resources and information provided was not verified. § See “Appendix 4. Limitations of Tax Due Diligence” for the limitations to the scope of service. Statute of Limitation Period § Under the Korean tax laws, the statute of limitation (“SOL”) for assessment of taxes is generally five (5) years from the filing due date of each tax return (extendable up to 7 or 10 years if there is deliberate or willful intention to defraud). § But the SOL can be extended to 1 year from filing due date of the fiscal year when the carried forward tax loss is utilized if a taxpayer uses the tax loss carry forwards incurred more than 5 years ago (which is limited to 10 years). § General Considerations of Tax Due Diligence Executive Summary Tax Audit Findings Appendix Item Opening Date Address Type of Business Head Office 1F and 2F 17-12 Nowon-ro 9-gil Buk-gu, Daegu (Nowon-dong 3-ga) Manufacture, wholesale and retail, real estate and lease Factory 2 Nov 27, 2020 163 Maecheon-ro Buk-gu, Daegu (Maecheon-dong) Manufacture Dusan Branch Jan 1, 2021 36 Suseongmot 2-gil Suseong-gu, Daegu (Dusan-dong) Real estate CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven- Final Tax Due Diligence Report 14 Tax | General (Cont’d) Statute of Limitation Period (cont’d) § Therefore, the Target cannot ignore the possibility of additional tax penalty for the fiscal years whose taxation period has not elapsed in case of tax audit and the we have reviewed the certificate of tax payment of national taxes and local taxes within the agreed scope of due diligence to review the Target’s potential tax obligations as of the date of due diligence report and reviewed the national tax and local tax reports for the taxation period (the “taxation period subject to due diligence”) of the following accounts whose taxation period has not elapsed (generally 5 years): Ø CIT : FY2017 ~ FY2020 Ø VAT: Estimates for 2017 1Q ~ 2020 4Q Ø WHT : Jan 2017 ~ Dec 2020 Ø Local Tax: Jan 2017 ~ Dec 2020 § For any findings of the tax due diligence, refer to the “Findings” section. Tax Implication on Share Deal Executive Summary Tax Audit Findings Appendix Items Observations Implications Secondary Tax Liability § Under the Korean tax law, the secondary taxpayer is liable to pay tax on behalf of the original taxpayer if the original taxpayer is unable to settle its tax liability. Secondary taxpayers include: the liquidator of a dissolved corporation; a majority shareholder or unlimited partner of a corporation; or an acquirer of a business in a business transfer. § A majority shareholder with more than 50% of the shares of a company and who can exercise governing rights (such as partner of a limited liability company) has a secondary liability for national and local taxes for that company. Such secondary liabilities arise only if the tax authorities are unable to collect tax from the original taxpayer, and the shareholder holds a majority position at the time the original tax obligation arises. The majority shareholder’s secondary liability is limited to outstanding taxes multiplied by the percentage of voting shares that the majority shareholder holds in the company § Thus, if Target is unable to settle its taxes, the buyer company would have to assume the secondary tax liability for Target’s outstanding taxes after it becomes the majority shareholder. Deemed Acquisition Tax (“DAT”) § Under the Local Tax Law, a majority shareholder who acquires more than 50% of an unlisted Korean company’s shares is deemed to have indirectly acquired the underlying assets of the Korean company, and therefore, is generally subject to DAT at 2.2% (2% for motor vehicles) of the book value of the company’s certain taxable assets multiplied by the ownership ratio of the major shareholder. § Taxable assets subject to DAT include real properties, motor vehicles, certain memberships, etc. A majority shareholder should file a DAT return and pay DAT within 60 days after it acquires the shares. • In case where the Buyer acquires 100% shares in the Target, the estimated DAT amount is 213 mn KRW based on the Financial Statements of December 31, 2020. Security Transaction Tax(STT) § Under the Securities Transaction Tax Law (“STTL”), in general a seller of unlisted Korean company shares should voluntarily file and pay the STT at 0.43% of the transfer price of the share. § From the Buyer’s perspective, there is no withholding obligation. CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Project Beethoven- Final Tax Due Diligence Report 25 Appendix 3. Limitation of Due Diligence Limitation of Due Diligence • During our due diligence, we attempted to review the tax returns and compiled relevant tax information and documentation in order to verify whether the Target has met its tax compliance and payment obligations. We focused on the major tax issues, potential outstanding tax liability amount, and the risk level in relation thereto. The exposures were quantified mainly based on figures from financial information provided by Target. • However, our work did not include the analysis of potential tax efficient alternatives available to perform the envisaged operation. Our review was carried out based on the limited financial and tax information provided by Target, and we did not undertake separate reviews to ensure that the information received was correct. In addition, we have not performed a detailed audit or investigation of the Target. As such, should we perform a detailed audit with more detailed data or information, further tax risk or issues not identified in this report may have been additionally discovered. Disclaimer § The tax due diligence was conducted in accordance with the standards and procedures agreed with the Company based on the financial and tax information provided by the Target, including statements of income tax adjustments, other tax reports, and internal regulations, with emphasis on the income tax, withholdings, and local tax that are highly likely to have contingent tax obligations, and limited interview with the Target’s officers. § As we did not verify the accuracy and completeness of resources and information presented by the Target and the factuality of resources or information not provided to us, the report does not include the Target’s potential tax risks that may be caused or affected by the inaccuracy of resources and information suggested to us or critical resources are not provided to us for the due diligence. § Also, tax issues require comprehensive review of tax laws, precedents, and administrative interpretations based on accurate understanding of facts, and conclusions may vary due to the economic, social, and judicial discrepancies of the time of transaction and the time of taxation, such as the understanding of transactions and factuality, clarity of tax regulations, and changes in the perspectives of tax authority. § In addition, there may be other potential tax risks not included in the report due to the limited resources, explanations, and time. Therefore, we do not provide any guarantee or affirmation that the Target is free of any additional tax risks in addition to the items mentioned in the tax due diligence report. § The report shall be used to identify the potential tax issues of the Target only and shall not be provided to any third party unless enforced by law. If the Company provides the report to any third party without our prior consent, we will not take any responsibility for the financial losses incurred to any third party that receive the report.
