BANOLIM FOOD Co., Ltd. Legal Due Diligence Report June 1 4 , 2021 CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 2 Preface For the attention of Orchestra Advisors Korea Limited , This L egal D ue D iligence Report ( this Report ) has been prepared in order to identify important facts and legal issues pertaining to the transaction ( the Transaction ), whereby Orchestra Advisers Korea Limited ( OAK ) will establish an overseas private equity fund ( PEF ) (the PEF ) and an overseas i nvestment purpose company (the SPC ) (the PEF and the SPC , collectively referred to as , the Purchaser ), either of which, may purchase 2,470 ordinary shares (100% of the total number of shares issues, hereinafter referred to as Shares ) of Banolim Food Co., L td., (the Company ) from Yoon Sung - won (an existing shareholder of the Company ) (the Seller ). Matters not directly relevant to the Transaction, and immaterial matters, are not included in this Report. For the purpose of this Report, due diligence was performed during the period from May 21 , 2021 to June 8 , 2021, based on the materials provided by the Company and interviews with the Company’s employees and executives . Apart from the investigation of lega l issues, additional investigation of materials other than the above - stated materials was not conducted. The due diligence was performed based on the premises that: (i) a ll seals and signatures on documents provided to us are genuine, all documents provided to us as originals are authentic , and all documents provided as copies conform to the originals; and (ii) unless there were clear inconsistencies among the information supplied to us, all materials, explanations or statements conce rning factual relations are c orrect, true and genuine, and no change has occurred to any of the factual relations up to the date of this Report. The professionals of LAB Partners are licensed to practice law in the Republic of Korea ( Korea ) and we cannot provide advisory services on matters related to the law s of any other jurisdiction. Therefore, a ny information included in this Report in relation to the laws of jurisdiction s other than Korea , is solely for the benefit of OAK’s understanding. In addition, this Report is p rovided solely to OAK, and thus it shall not be disclosed or provided to a ny third party and no third party will be permitted to use the contents of this Report , without the prior written consent of LAB P artners . June 14 , 2021 Thank You , LAB PARTNERS CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 3 Legal Due Diligence 1. Corporate General 1.1 Overview of Corporate General ★★ 1.2 Transactions with Affiliates and Related Parties ★★★ CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 4 ◼ Overview According to the commer cial registry, the current status of the Company is as follows: Information Details Company Name - BANOLIM FOODS CO., LTD. Company Registration Number - 170111 - 0596455 Representative Director - Yoon Sung - won Head Office - (District 3, Nowon - dong) 17 - 12, Nowon - ro 9 - gil, Buk - gu, Daegu - si Par Value - KRW 10,000 Total Number of Shares to be Issued - 100,000 shares Total Number of Shares Issued - 2,470 common shares Paid - In Capital - KRW 30,000,000 Business Purpose - Food Processing and Manufacturing Business - Food Distribution Business - Franchising Business - Kitchen Appliance Sales Business - Restaurant Business - Food Subdivision or Sales Business - Distribution - Specialized Sales Business - Intellectual Property and License Business - Mail Order Dis tribution Business - E - Commerce Business - Real Estate Purchase, Selling, and Renting Business - Other export and import trade activities related to the foregoing - Other business activities related to the foregoing ◼ Directors According to the due diligence materials provided, the d irectors of the Company are as follows: Position Name Appointment Date Representative Director / Standing Director Yoon Sung - won December 3, 2020 Standing Director Yoon Jong - ye o l December 3, 2020 Under the KCC , there must be at least three directors, however a company with less than KRW one billion in capital may have only one or two directors (Article 383 (1) of the KCC) . The KCC does not separately regulate the quota of statutory auditors. 1.1 Overview of Corporate General ★★ - As a prior condition of the Transaction, i t is necessary to stipulate that: (i) the holding and/or the resolution of a general meeting of shareholders to issue a letter of resignation of existing executive members of the Company ; and (ii) the appoint ment of new executive members desi gnated by the Purchaser , will be required. - The processes of acquiring and disposing treasury shares is deemed to be in compliance with the Korean Commercial Code ( KCC ) and the Articles of Incorporation of the Company (the Articles of Incorporation ) . Therefore, if the payment for the acquisition of treasury shares is made within the range of the di stributable profit , it is deemed that the Company has not violated the KCC or its Articles of Incorporation . CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 5 According to the A rticles of Incorporation : (i) the Company shall have three or more directors , but the Company may have one or two directors if the total paid - in capital is less than KRW one billion (Article 42 ( 1 ) of the Articles of Incorporation ) ; and (ii) a director’s t erm of office shall not be longer than three years, however , if the last day of a director’s term falls between the end of the last fiscal year during such director’s term and before the date of the annual general meeting of shareholders with respect to su ch fiscal year, such director’s term shall be extended until the closing of the annual general meeting of shareholders (Article 43 of the Articles of Incorporation ). According to the Articles of Incorporation: (i) the Company shall have more than one audi tor, but, if the paid - in capital is less than KRW one billion, the Company may not have a n auditor, in such case the general meeting of shareholders shall perform the auditor’s duties (Article 56 ( 1 ) of the Articles of Incorporation ) ; and (ii) the auditor’s term of office shall be until the closing of the annual general meeting of shareholders convened in respect of the last period for the settlement of accounts within three year s from the auditor’s appointment (Article 57 of the Articles of Incorp oration ) . Currently, the Company has two directors and no statutory auditors , but is not in violation of the KCC nor the Articles of Incorporation, as the total paid - in capital is less than KRW one billion. Considerations related to the Transaction : The management rights of the Company are subject to change according to the Transaction, and the Purchaser shall appoint a registered executive of the Company accordingly. Therefore, since a resolution needs to be adopted at the general meeting of shareholder s of the Company for the Purchaser to appoint a designated individual as a registered executive of the Company, the following conditions precedent to the Transaction need to be specified : (i) receipt of resignation letters from the current directors and au ditor; and (ii) convening of the general meeting of shareholders for the appointment of new executives . In addition, the appointment of new auditors also must be reviewed. ◼ Composition of Shareholders 1. Overview According to the due diligence materials provided, Yoon Sung - won holds one hundred per cent. (100%) of the shares issued by the Company as of the date of this Report. 2. Acquisition and Disposition of Treasury Shares Under the KCC, treasury shares are permitted only if : (i) they are acqu ired within the scope of distributable profit (calculated from the immediately preceding period for the settlement of accounts) (Article 341 of the KCC); and (ii) the acquisition of treasury shares is for a particular purpose (Article 341 - 2 of the KCC). If the Company acquires its shares within the scope of distributable profit, the Company must determine, in advance, the type and number of shares that can be acquired, the limit on the total acquisition price, and the period, not exceeding one year, that th e Company is able to acquire treasury shares by a resolution of a general meeting of shareholders (Article 341 (2) of the KCC). On the other hand, the acquisition of treasury shares shall be performed under fair and equal conditions by method of share acqu isition such as notifying or announcing to all shareholders of the acquisition etc. (Article 341 (1) and (2) of the KCC; and Article 9 (1) of the Enforcement Decree of the KCC). According to the due diligence materials provided, Yoon Sung - won transferred 130 shares of the Company to Lee Min - j oo, his spouse , and 400 shares of the Company to Yoon Seung - b um, his son , as a gift and has paid equivalent gift tax (shares of both Lee Min - j oo and Yoon Seung - b um ha ve been calculated to be worth KRW 5,311,834 per share). Subsequently, the Company, through a general meeting of shareholders, determined the class and number of shares acquired as 1,000 ordinary shares, the total acquisition price as KRW 5,311,834,000 ( KRW 5,311,834 per share), and the acquisition period as November 1, 2020, to December 31, 2020, and has notified the shareholders thereof . Both, Lee Min - j oo and Yoon Seung - b um, applied for the transfer of all five hundred thirty ( 530 ) shares of the Company on November 26, 2020, which the Company acquired for KRW 2,815,272,020 ( KRW 5,311,834 per share) on November 30, 2020, and completed the disposition of the shares on December 4, 2020. CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 6 The processes of acquiring and disposing treasury shares are deemed to be in compliance with the KCC and the Articles of Incorporation . Therefore, if the payment made in acquiring the treasury shares is within the range of distributable profit, the Company has not violated the KCC or the Articles of Incorporation . 3. Establishing Stock Collateral and Agreement between Shareholders According to the Company, no security such as pledges have been established over the shares issued by the Company and there is no shareholders’ agreement governing the transfer of the C ompany ’s shares or operation of the Company. ◼ Issuance of Share Certificates According to the Company, the Company has not issued any physical share certificates. Shares certificates are written documents of already existing shares, a nd even if share certificates are not issued, this does not affect the validity of the shares . However , to conduct a valid transfer of shares when physical share certificates are not issued, the Seller shall send written notice of the share transfer to the Company with fixed date affixed thereon , and the Company shall confirm that physical share certificates have not been issued. Considerations related to the Transaction : In principle, the issuance of physical share certificates by the Company and the delivery of the physical share certificates by the seller to the purchaser are required to conduct the transfer of shares. However, with respect to the Transaction, upon agre ement of the parties, the issuance and delivery of physical shares can be replaced with the following procedures: (i) the Seller send ing a notice to the Company of the transfer of shares with a fixed date affixed thereon; and (ii) the Seller receiv ing a le tter from the Company confirming that no physical share certificates have been issued. It is necessary to consult in advance with the Seller and the Company on specific methods of transferring shares. ◼ Restriction on the Transfer of Shares pursuant to the Articles of Incorporation According to the KCC , the C ompany may require the approval of the b oard of d irectors (the BOD ) on the transfer of shares as provided for in the Articles of Incorporation (Article 335 (1) of the KCC). If such requirement exist s in the Articles of Incorporation , any transfer of shares not approved by the BOD shall not be effective against the company (Article 335 (2) of the KCC ). In case approval from the BOD is required for the transfer of shares pursuant to the Articles of Inc orporation , the relevant provisions under the Articles of Incorporation shall be registered under the KCC (Article 317 (2) Paragraph 3 - 2 of the KCC ). I f the Company , which has one or two directors and has no BOD, has a restriction on the transfer of shares in the Articles of Incorporation , the approval of the transfer of shares falls under the authority of the general meeting of shareholders (Article 383 (4) of the KCC ). The Articles of Incorporation do not have a provision concerning the restriction of the transfer of shares. Therefore, the Transaction is possible by an agreement between the Seller and the Purchaser , and no prior approval from the Company’s BOD is required . ◼ Right to Subscribe to Newly Issued Shares and Equity - linked Debt Instruments According to the Company, the Company has not granted any rights to subscribe to newly issued shares to any party other than the existing shareholders. Further, the Company has not granted any stock options to its executives and employees nor issued any equity - linked debt instruments such as convertible bonds (CB), bonds with warrants (BW) or exchangeable bonds (EB). Considerations related to the Transaction : Since newly issued shares and equity linked debt instruments are factors that cau se change in the equity structure of the Company, with respect to the Transaction, it is advisable to obtain r epresentations and warranties from the Seller to the effect that the Company has not granted any rights to subscribe to newly issued shares to any party other than the existing shareholders , and that the Company has not issued any stock options or equity linked debt instruments. CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 7 ◼ Stock Purchase Options etc. According to the Company, the Company has not granted stock options or stock grants to its shareholders, executives, or employees. Considerations related to the Transaction : With respect to the Transaction, it is advisable to obtain representations and wa rranties from the Seller to the effect that the Company has not granted any stock options nor stock grants to its shareholders, executives, and employees. CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 8 ◼ Affiliate A business group refers to a group of companies where the business of which is substantially controlled by the same person in accordance with the standards prescribed by the Presidential Decree (Article 2 (2) of the Monopoly Regulation and Fair Trade Act ( FTA ) ) and two (2) or more companies belong ing to the same group of enterprises are referred to as affiliates of each other (Article 2 (3) of the FTA ). If the same person owns at least thirty per cent . (30%) of the total shares issued by the relevant company alone or with a certain person related to the same person consistently, the same person shall be deemed to have control over the details of the company’s business (Article 3 (1) of the Enforcement Decree of the FTA ). The certain person related to the same person i ncludes a lineal relative within the sixth degree of consanguinity, or a relative within the fourth degree of affinity , etc . (Article 3 (1) of the Enforcement Decree of the FTA ). According to the due diligence materials provided, Banolim Food Seoul Co., L td. ( the Branch ) is one hundred per cent . (100%) owned by Lee Ki - joo who is the brother - in - law of the Representative Director. Since Lee Ki - joo is a relative within the fourth degree of affinity, the Branch is a part of the business group which is substantially controlled by the Representative Director, as the largest contributor, who owns more than thirty per cent . ( 30% ) of the total shares comb ined with the certain person related to the same person , and, therefore, the C ompany and the Branch are deemed affiliated. ◼ Related Party Transactions 1. Transactions related to the Business Lee Ki - joo, the brother - in - law of the Representative Director, owns one hundred per cent. (100%) of shares of the Branch. The Branch has two (2) executive members: Lee Ki - joo as a inside director ; and Shim Min - hee ( spouse of Lee Ki - joo) as an auditor. The Branch has five employees: thre e supervisors ; one branch manager ; and one bookkeeper. The Branch oversees the franchise stores in the metropolitan area (Seoul, Gyeonggi - do, Gangwon - do, Cheonan, and Asan). According to the due diligence materials provided, the Branch is paid the followi ng profits in connection with the operations of the Company: (i) w hen a new franchise is opened in a metropolitan area, the franchise e shall pay KRW 5 million to the Company for franchisee income, and KRW 7 million to the Branch for franchisee income and education expenses ( t he total cost of payment shall be KRW 25 million , but, out of the total cost, KRW 18 million shall be paid as a payment for kitchen appliances ) and when transferring the franchise, three KRW 3 million shall be paid to the headquart ers as franchisee income, and KRW 9 million to the Branch as franchisee income and education expenses; (ii) if Jung Sung Food Co., Ltd. purchases goods (boxes, cheese, ham, etc.) from a third party and delivers them 1.2 Transactions with Affiliates and Related Parties ★★★ - No resolution of the general meeting of shareholders was adopted for t he employment agreement with Lee Min - joo, the Representative Director’s spouse, and the provision of loan by the Branch (as defined below) despite the fact that these transactions are subject to approval under Article 398 of the KCC. - In connection to the Transaction, it is advisable to obtain representations and warranties from the Seller to the effec t that the existing transaction (s) between the Company and its related parties do not violate the relevant statutes, such as the KCC , the FTA (as defined below) , and the Corporate Tax Act , and that there is no possibility that various burdens, such as taxe s and fines, will occur or increase. - It is necessary to consider specifying that, as an obligation, all remaining loans to Shim Min - hee , KRW 1,317,000,000, will be resolved prior to or after the Transaction . CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 9 to franchises in the metropolitan area, it shall pay 7% of sales to the Company, and 5.5% of sales to the Branch as profit margin arising from logistics ; (iii) franchise s shall purchase uniforms from Modern Gown, and Modern Gown shall pay the commission from offices in the metropolitan area to t he Branch for offices in the metropolitan area and commission from the remaining areas to the Company ; (iv) franchise s shall purchase printed materials from Awesome Design, if required, and Awesome Design shall pay the commission to the Branch for franchis es in the metropolitan area and to the Company for franchises in the remaining areas. According to the Company, no separate agreement between the Company and the Branch regarding the transactions above exists . 2. Use of Motor Vehicles and Payment of Salarie s and Provision of Severance Pay ment According to the Company, the Company owns one (1) Mercedes - Benz ( license plate no. 07 So 4703), one (1) leased Mercedes - Benz ( license plate no. 57 Go 0667) and one (1) Porsche ( license plate no. 53 Jeu 1038) which all are mainly used for private purposes by the Representative Director and inside directors. Meanwhile, the Representative Director ’s spouse , Lee Min - joo, was paid as a head of the development team from November 2019 to November 2020, and was paid severance pay ment when she left the company on December 2020. It appears unclear whether Lee Min - joo actually worked for the Company . 3. Loans by the Branch According to the due diligence materials provided, the Branch borrowed KRW 2,190,000,000 from Shim M in - hee, the auditor, without interest and collateral for periods between March 6, 2018 to, March 5, 2023. According to the Company, the remaining loan is KRW 1,317,000,000. ◼ Considerations related to Related Persons Transactions 1. Issues related to S elf - D eal ing Transaction A. Approval of Self - Dealing Transaction s by Directors, e tc. Under the KCC , in order for a person ( Director, etc. ) falling under any of the following categories below to engage in a transaction with the Company ( Self - Dealing Transaction ) , he/she shall ob t ain prior approval from the BOD in advance with an affirmative vote of two thirds or more of the total number of the Directors and the relevant details and procedures of the transaction shall be fair (Article 398 of the KCC ). I n the case of a company having less than three directors and has no BOD , a S elf - D ealing Transaction is subject to prior approval by the general meeting of shareholders (Article 383 (4) of the KCC ). 1. A Director or major shareholder (shareholder with shareholding of 10% or more ) . 2. The Spouse and lineal ascendents or descend a nts of a person falling under subparagraph 1 . 3. Lineal ascendents or descend a nts of the spouse of a person falling under subparagraph 1 . 4. A company in which half or more of the total number of issued and outstanding shares with voting rights are held by a person falling under any of subparagraphs 1 through 3, solely or jointly with others, or its subsidiary . 5. A company in which at least half the total number of issued and outstanding shares with voting rights are held by a person falling under any of subparagraphs 1 through 3, together with a company falling under subparagraph 4 . A S elf - D ealing T ransaction , subject to prior approval by the b oard of directors or the general meeting of shareholders, is a transaction with a risk of conflict of interest between the directors and the company and such transaction may be deemed legally invalid if it is not approved by the BOD or the general meeting of shareholders . B. Review of the Issue Transactions related to the Business : Since the Branch does not fall under any of the subparagraph s of Article 398 of the KCC , the transaction between the Company and the Branch is not subject to approval under Article 398 of the KCC . CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 10 Use of Motor Vehicles and Provision of Salaries and Severance Pay ment : In relation to the use of motor vehicles , n o separate transaction activiti es exist between the Company and Related Persons . Lee Min - joo corresponds to the spouse of a director or a major shareholder (Article 398 (2) of the KCC ), and an agreement on salary etc., concluded by a Director, etc ., as an employee with the C ompany is su bject to approval under Article 398 of the KCC because there is a risk of conflict of interest between the Director, etc. , and the C ompany. Since the Branch has one (1) director and has no BOD, t he Branch shall ob t ain prior approval from the general meetin g of shareholders . According to the Company, the above has not been approved by a separate meeting of shareholders . Loans by the Branch : The Branch’s loan to Shim Min - hee, the spouse of Lee Ki - joo , a n inside director and a shareholder with one hundred per cent. (100%) share s , constitutes a transaction with the spouse of a director or a major shareholder (Article 398 (2) of the KCC ) and is subject to approval under Article 398 of the KCC because there is a risk of conflict of interest. According to the Comp any, the Branch has not received approval from a separate general meeting of shareholders . Self - dealing without approval from the BOD or general meeting of shareholders may be deemed invalid between the C ompany and the counterparty . However , taking into consideration that in the case of Lee Min - joo’s employment contract , the working relationship has already been terminated ( the salaries and severance pay ment have been paid), the Branch’s loan should be resolved or managed prior to and after the Trans action regardless of the validity of the transaction . Then, i t is unlikely that the approval of the self - dealing will be a problem. However, note that if the Company engages in transactions with its directors or major shareholders subsequently, it should o btain approval from the BOD (if the BOD is formed by appointing three or more directors) or the general meeting of shareholders (if the BOD cannot be formed due to having one or two director ( s ) ) prior to such transaction . 2. Unfair Assistance, etc., under the FTA A. Unfair Assistance, etc. Unfair Assistance : The FTA prohibits business entities ( Assistance Provider ) from providing advanced payments, loans, human resources, real estate, securities, goods, services, intangible property rights, etc. , for related parties or other companies ( Assistance Recipient ) or making a transaction with related parties or other companies under substantially advantageous terms ( Unfair Assistance ) (Article 23 (1) 7 (A) of the FTA). Unfair assistance is deemed to have been constituted if : (i) in the case of transactions involving funds , such as provisional payments or loans, where the Assistance Provider provides economic benefits to directly or indirectly use cash or other funds for the financial convenience of the Assistance Recipient ( such as lending funds at low er interest rates compared to the interest rates that the Assistance Provider would normall y transact at with independent persons who have no special relationship with the Assistance Provider ( Arm’s Length Price ) ; (ii) in the case of transaction of goods or services, if the Assistance Provider provides goods or services to the Assistance Recipie nt free of charge, or at a price lower than an Arm’s Length Price , or receives them at a price higher than the Arm’s Length Price . If u nfair p rovision b ehaviors is deemed to have occurred , the Assistance Provider and the Assistant Recipient may be subject to corrective action by the Korea Fair Trade Commission ( KFTC ) (Article 24 of the FTA ) or penalty surcharges may be imposed (Article 24 - 2 of the FTA ). Repudiation of Wrongful Calculation : A company regards the transaction price that is paid to the related party as an expense, and calculates the operating income and pays the corporate tax accordingly. Yet, if execution of the cost due to the related party transaction exceeds the Arm’s Length Price and thus is deemed to have unjustly reduced the corporate tax burden, the tax authority may regard execution of such cost as wrongful calculation, reject it , and impose a tax amount based on recalculation which is based on the Arm’s Length Price (Ar ticle 52 of the Corporate Tax Act). Director’s Violation of Fiduciary Duty or Breach of Trust pursuant to the Criminal Code : If the Company’s transaction price paid to the related party exceeds the Arm’s Length Price, the breach of fiduciary duty or breac h of trust under the Criminal Code , of the Company’s Director who approved and executed the decision of such conditions could become a legal issue (Article 355 (2) of the Criminal Code). B. Review of the Issue CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 11 Transactions related to the Business : In order to examine whether there are grounds for legal issues to arise, such as Unfair Assistance , R epudiation of W rongful C alculation , etc. , in connection with the transaction between the Company and the Branch, it is necessary to confirm whether the service price paid under the relevant transaction is within Arm’s Length Price range, however, this is difficult to determine solely based on the due diligence materials provided. However, according to the Company, the Branch is in charge of counselling the franchise , assisting with its opening and follow - up management (education, inspection, etc.) in the metropolitan area, and the profits received by the Branch a ppear to be reasonable compensation. Use of Motor Vehicles and P rovision of Salaries and Severance Pay ment : If the R epresentative D irector uses the vehicle owned and leased by the Company for private purposes and is paid salar y and severan ce pay ment(s) despite the fact that his spouse had not work ed at the Company , he may be in violation of repudiation of wrongful calculation under the Corporate Tax Act, and the director may be in breach of fiduciary duty or breach of trust under the Crimin al Code ’s duty of good faith , or subject to the crime of breach of trust under the Criminal Act. ◼ Considerations related to the Transaction With respect to the Transaction, it is advisable to ob t ain representations and warranties to the effect that the past transactions between the Company and Related Persons is not in violation of relevant statutes such as the KCC , the FTA , and the Corporate Tax Act, and that there is no likelihood that the Compa ny’s burdens such as tax, penalty surcharges, etc. , arises or increases . Also, there is no separate contract between the Company and the Branch regarding the scope of the Branch’s activities or the basis for calculating fees . Thus, it is unclear whether t he Branch’s profits are appropriate and, in this regard, the possibility of legal issues such as unfair assistance , and repudiation of wrongful calculation may arise . Certificate of SMEs : Under the Framework Act on Small and Medium Enterprises, both size standards, and independence criteria must be met to qualify as a SME . In order to meet the standards for size : (i) the three - year average revenue of the main business must meet the standards for sales by industry under the Enforcement Decree of the Framework Act on Small and Medium Enterprises (Table 1) ; and (ii) the total assets must be less than KRW 500 billion . In order to meet the independence criteria : (i) a corporation (including a foreign corporation, with the exception of a non - profit corporation) with total asset s of more than KRW 500 billion must directly or indirectly own at least thirty per cent. (30%) of the total outstanding stocks, etc. , and be the largest investor ; or (ii), in the case of a company belonging to related companies, it shall not fall under a company that fails to meet the industry standards by the aggregate of average sales equivalent to the ratio of investment (Article 2 (1) of the Framework Act on Small and Medium Enterprises, Article 3 (1) of the Enforcement Degree of the Framework Act on Small and Medium Enterprises). According to the due diligence materials provided, the Company appears to be operating the franchise business (management consulting business) as its main business, and is considered to be operating in the professional, scientific and technical services as its main industry. The company’s : (i) three - year average revenue is less than KRW 60 billion; and (ii) total asset is less than KRW 500 billion . The Company does not fall under : (i) a corporation (including a foreign corporation, with the exception of a n on - profit corporation) with total 2.1. Certificate of Food Manufacturing and Processing and Business Registration : According to the Food Sanitation Act, a person who intends to manufacture or process food shall register with the Minster of Food and Drug Safety, the Mayor of a Special Self - Governing City, or the Governor of a Special Self - Governing Province or the head of a Si/Gun/Gu (Article 37 (5) of the Food Sanitation Act). The Company received a certificate of food m anufacturing and processing , and business registration on November 18, 2020, and November 26, 2020, for its factories in 17 - 12, Nowon - ro 9 - gil, Buk - gu, Daegu (Nowon - dong 3 - ga) and 163 Maecheong - ro, Daegu (Maecheon - dong) respectively, that manufacture dough , garlic sauce, tomato sauce, and sweet potat o mousse. Declaration of Mail Order Distributor : According to the Act on the Consumer Protection in Electronic Commerce, etc., Mail Order Distributors (a person who is engaged in mail order or a person who cond ucts the mail order business by providing information on the sale of goods and receiving a consumer’s order by means of mail, telecommunications or other methods) shall file a report on the trade name, address, telephone number, e - mail address, i nternet do main name, and etc., to the KFTC , t he Metropolitan Autonomous City Mayor, the Special Self - Governing Province Governor, or the head of a Si/Gun/Gu (Article 12 (1) of the Act on the Consumer Protection in Electronic Commerce). The Company se l ls pizza throu gh a Internet website and its mobile applications and received a registration of mail order distribut ion business from the Buk - go mayor of Daegu on February 27, 2020. 2. Reporting changes related to this Transaction Issuance of the revised certificate of SM E : Where the name, representative, or location of a company that has received a certificate of SME has changed, relevant evidential documents shall be submitted to the Minister of SMEs and Startups for the issuance of a revised certificate of SME ( Article 6 (3) of the Regulations on the Scope and Verification of Small and Medium Enterprises). Registrati on or Reporting Changes in Food Manufacturing and Processing Industries : According to the Food Sanitation Act, where a food manufactur ing and processing business changes the location of the business, it shall file an application for registration of change within seven days from the date of change. Changes to other matters such as the name of a business operator (in case of a corporation, the na me of the representative thereof), must be reported within seven days from the date of change (Article 37 (5) of the Food Sanitation Act ; and Article 43 (3) of the Enforcement Decree of the Food Sanitation Act). Failure to register or report a change may r esult in imprisonment up to five years or a fine of up to KRW 50 million (Article 95 (2 - 2) of the Food Sanitation Act). Reporting Changes to declaration of Mail Order Business : According to the Act on the Consumer Protection in Electronic Commerce, where a m ail o rder d istributor changes its name of business, or representative director, it shall file an application reporting the changes within 15 days from the date of change (Article 12 (2) of the Act on the Consumer Protection in Electronic Commerce; and A rticle 45 (3) 3 of the Enforcement Decree of the Act on the Consumer Protection in Electronic Commerce, etc.). Failure to report a change may result in a fine up to KRW 5 million (Article 45 (3) 3 of the Act on the Consumer Protection in Electronic Commerc e). 3. Obligations under the Act on Promotion of Information and Communications Network Utilization and Information Protection The Company is an information and communication service provider that collects and uses personal information from its members in the process of conducting business through its website and mobile applications ( Information and Communication Network ), hence the Act on Promotion of Information and Communications Network Utilization and Information Protection ( Information and Communications Network Act ) applies . The Compa ny’s main obligations related to protection of personal information as a n information and communication service provider are as follows: Article Detail Consent to Access Authority (Article 22 - 2) - Whe re a provider of information and communications service needs authority to access ( Access Authority ) information stored, and functions installed, on mobile devices of users in order to provide relevant services, the provider shall inform users of the following so that users may clearly re cognize such matters and shall obtain consent of users in doing so: 1 in the case of access authority necessary to provide the relevant services: (a) items of information and functions for which access authority is necessary; (b) grounds that access authority is necessary; 2 in the case of access authority not absolutely necessary to provide the relevant services: (a) items of information and functions for which access authority is necessary; (b) grounds that access authority is necessary; (c) fact that users may elect to not provide consent to permission for access authority Securing of Stability of Information and Communications Network (Article 45) - Every provider of information and communications services shall take protective measures to secure the reliability of the information , and security of the information , and communications networks. Installation of Advertising Programs for Profit (Article 50 - 5 ; and Article 63 of the Enforcement Degree of the same Act) - When a provider of information and communications services intends to install a program designed to display advertising information or collect personal information o n a user's computer or any other information processing device prescribed by Presidential Decree, it shall obtain consent from the user. In such cases, the provider shall notify the purpose of use of the program , and the method of deletion. 2. Whether the Company is in Compliance of Law 2.2. Issues related to the Act on Promotion of Information and Communications Network Utilization and Personal Information Protection Act ★★ - The Company needs to improve the procedures for obtaining consent related to the collection and use of personal information from its website and mobile application users . - With respect to the Transaction, it is advisable to receive representations and warra nties from the Seller to the effect that the Company is fulfilling all its obligations under the Act on Promotion of Utilization of Information and Communications Network and the Personal Information Protection Act, and that no administrative disposition h as been imposed against the Company from government agencies due to violation of either statute. Obligations under the Personal Information Protection Act The Company’s main obligations under the Personal Information Protection Act are as follows: Article Detail Special Provisions on Consent to the Collection and Use of Personal Information (Article 39 - 3, Article 48 - 3 of the Enforcement Decree of the same Act) - An information and communications service provider who intends to collect and use personal information o f users shall notify users of the following matters and obtain consent therefor. The same shall apply when changes are made for the following matters: 1. t he purpose of the collection and use of personal information; 2. p articulars of personal information to be collected; and 3. t he period for retaining and using personal information . Limitation to Personal Information P ro cessing Subsequent to Outsourcing of Work - A personal information controller, when outsourcing personal information to a third party, must effect such outsourcing through a document that states the following: 1. p revention of personal information processing for other purposes than the outsourced purpo se; 2. t echnical and managerial safeguards of personal information; (Article 26, Article 28 of the Enforcement Decree of the same Act) 3. p urpose and scope of outsourced work; 4. m atters concerning limitation to re - outsourcing; 5. m atters concerning measures to ensure safety, including limitation to access personal information; 6. m atte rs concerning supervision and inspection of the status of management of personal information retained in relation to outsourced work; and 7. m atters concerning liability, such as compensation for damages caused by a breach of contractual obligations on the pa rt of an outsourcee . - A personal information controller that outsources personal information processing shall disclose the details of the outsourced work and the entity that processes personal information under an outsourcing contract so that data subjects may recognize it with ease at any time. Duty of Safeguards (Article 29, Article 30 of the Enforcement Decree of the same Act) - E very personal information controller shall take such technical, managerial, and physical measures as establishing an internal management plan and pres erving access records, etc., that are necessary to ensure safety that the personal information may not be lost, stolen, divulged, forged, altered, or damaged. - Each personal information controller shall take the following measures to ensure safety : 1. t o formu late and implement an internal management plan for the safe processing of personal information ; 2. t o control access to personal information and restrict the authority to access personal information; 3. t o adopt encryption technology to safely store and transmit personal information and other equivalent measures; 4. t o retain login records to respond to incidents of infringement with respect to personal information and to take measures to prevent the forgery and falsification thereof; 5. t o install and upgrade security programs to protect personal information; and 6. t o take physical measures, such as a storage or locking system, to keep personal information safely . Establishment and Disclosure of Privacy Policy (Article 30, Article 31 of the Enforcement Decree of the same Act) - Each personal information controller shall establish a personal information processing policy including the following matters: 1. the purpose fo r which personal information is processed; 2. the period for processing and retaining personal information; 3. provision of personal information to a third party (if applicable); 4. procedures and methods for destroying personal information (if CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 18 personal informatio n shall be preserved according to the proviso of Article 21(1), this shall include the basis of preservation and particulars of personal information to be preserved); 5. outsourcing personal information processing (if applicable); 6. the rights and obligations of data subjects and legal representatives, and how to exercise such rights; 7. contact information, such as the name of a privacy officer designated under Article 31 or the name, telephone number, etc., of the department which perf orms the duties related to personal information protection and handles related grievances; and 8. installation and operation of an automatic collection tool for personal information, including internet access data files, and the denial thereof (if applicable). Designation of Privacy Officers (Article 31, Article 32 of the Enforcement Decree of the same Act) - A personal information controller shall designate a privacy officer who comprehensively takes charge of personal information processing . - A pers onal information controller shall designate the business owner or representative, or an executive officer as a privacy officer. Special Cases on the Destruction of Personal Information (Article 39 - 6, Article 48 - 5 of the Enforcement Decree of the same Act) - Information and communications service provider, etc., shall take necessary measures as prescribed by Presidential Decree such as destruction to protect the personal information of users who have not used information and communications services for one ye ar: provided, that, if the period is designated otherwise by other statutes or at the request of the user, the designated period shall apply. 2. Whether the Company is in Compliance of Law The Company’s website and mobile applications do not receive consent from the users for the collection or use of personal information, however, the personal information processing policy specifies the purpose of collecting and using personal information, the articles of personal informati on, the retention and duration of personal information, and consent is obtained only for the personal information processing policy. However, the purpose of the Personal Information Protection Act is to ensure that users are clearly aware of important mat ters concerning the collection and use of personal information, hence there may be problems with whether the collective consent , obtained by publishing the full text of the personal information processing policy , can be said to be explicitly agreed upon. W here personal information is collected without the consent of the user, the Protection Commission may impose administrative surcharges not exceeding three per cent. (3%) of the total revenues (Article 39 - 15 of the Personal Information Protection Act). Ther efore, subsequently, the Company needs to improve procedures for obtaining consent related to the collection and use of personal information. According to the website and mobile applications of the Company, the Company appears to be in compliance with all of its major obligations under the Personal Information Protection Act, including disclosure of articles outsourced, compliance with dut ies of safeguards, establishment and disclosure of privacy policy, designation of privacy officers , and the destruction of personal information . 3. Considerations related to the Transaction With respect to the Transaction, it is advisable to receive representations and warranties from the Seller to the effect that the Company is fulfilling all the obligations under the Pers onal Information Protection Act, and that no administrative disposition has been imposed against the Company from government agencies due to violation of the Personal Information Protection Act. Obligations under the Act on the Consumer Protection in Electronic Commerce, etc. The Company’s main obligations under the Act on the Consumer Protection in Electronic Commerce are as follows: Article(s) Detail Preservation, etc. , of Transaction Records (Article 6, Article 6 of the Enforcement Decree) - The subject matter and scope of transaction records to be preserved, and period of such preservation by a business operator shall be as follows: 1. r ecords related to marks and advertisements: six months; 2. r ecords related to cancellation of contracts or subscriptions, etc . : five years; and 3. r ecords related to resolution of consumer complaints or disputes: three years . - Business operators are obliged to provide consumers wi th methods of perusal and maintenance of transaction records. Provision of Information on Identity and Transaction Terms (Article 13) - In placing indications or advertisements to take orders for a transaction of goods, etc., a mail order distributor shall include therein each of the following: 1. t rade name and name of the representative; and 2. a ddress, telephone number, and e - mail address . - A mail order distributor shall indicate, advertise, or notify the following in an appropriate manner so that c onsumers can clearly understand the terms of a transaction of goods, etc., before concluding a contract and sign a deal without any error or discr epancy, and upon conclusion of a contract, a mail order distributor shall provide documents relating thereto, which include the following, to the other party of the contract before supplying the goods, etc.: 1. t rade names of the supplier and seller of the go ods, and names, addresses, telephone number, etc., of representatives thereof; 2. n ames, types, and contents of the goods, etc.; 3. i nformation on the goods, etc. ; and 4. t erms and conditions of the transaction . Confirmation, etc. , of Orders (Article 14) - In response to an order from a consumer for the transaction of goods, etc., a mail order distributor shall promptly confirm the customer’s expression of intent to order a nd provide information on the availability of sale . - A mail order distributor shall hav e adequate procedures that enable consumers to confirm the contents of the order and correct or cancel it before concluding a contract. Cancellation, etc., of Orders (Article 17, Article 18) - A consumer may cancel a contract w ithin seven days from the date of receiving a document on the contents of the contract: p rovided, t hat where the supply of the goods, etc. , has been performed after the delivery of a document, seven days from the date the goods, etc., have been supplied, o r the supply of the goods, etc., has begun. 2. Whether the Company is in Compliance of Law According to the Company’s website and mobile applications, the terms of service related to the Company’s business between the Company and consumers such as provision of information on identity and transaction terms; confirmation, etc., of orders; and cancellation, etc., of orders do not violate the Act on the Consume r Protection in Electronic Commerce, etc., and the Company complies with the period of preservation of transaction records prescribed by the Act on the Consumer Protection in Electronic Commerce, etc. In addition, according to the Company, the Company comp lies with all 2.3. CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 21 ◼ Issues related to the Food Sanitation Act 1. Obligations and Compliance of the Company under the Food Sanitation Act The Company’s main obligations under the Food Sanitation Act are as follows and, according to the Company, is in compliance with all of its obligations. Article(s) Detail Handling Foods, etc. (Article 3) - A ll person shall collect, manufacture, process, use, cook, store, subdivide, transport or display foods or food additives for the purpose of sale (including offering such foods or food additives to many, unspecified persons for purposes, other than sale; here inafter the same shall apply) in a clean and sanitary manner. - Apparatus, containers and packages used for business purpose shall be handled cleanly and sanitarily. Prohibition against Sale, etc. of Harmful Foods, etc. (Article 4) - No one shall sell, collect, manufacture, import, process, use, cook, store, subdivide, transport or display any of the following foods, etc. , for the purpose of sale: 1. r otten, stale or unripe foods, which are likely to harm to human bodies ; 2. f oods that contain or are likely to contain poisonous or harmful substances, or are smeared or are likely to be smeared with such substances , p rovided, t hat foods that are deemed not t o cause any harm to human bod ies by the Minister of Food and Drug Safety are excluded; 3. f oods that are or may be contaminated with microbes causing diseases, which are likely to cause harm to human bod ies ; 4. f oods that are likely to har m human bodies due to t heir uncleanness, other substances mixed with or added to such foods or other grounds; 5. f oods which have failed to undergo safety examination, among agricultural, livestock or fishery products subject to safety examination under Article 18 or foods that are deemed to be inedible as a result of safety examination; 6. f oods, the import of which are prohibited, or foods imported without making an import declaration under Article 20 (1) of the Special Act on Imported Food Safety Control; and 7. f oods that are manufact ured, processed or subdivided by persons, other than business operators. Prohibition against Sale, etc. , of Meat, etc. , Affected by Diseases (Article 5) - No one shall sell, as food, meat, bones, milk, organs or blood of animals which have contracted or are likely to contract diseases prescribed by Ordinance of the Prime Minister or animals which died of such diseases, or collect, import, process, use, cook, store, subdivide, transport or display them for the purpose of sale. Prohibition against Sale, etc. , of Chemical Synthetics, etc., Standards and Specifications which are not Prescribed (Article 6) - No one shall engage in any of the following acts : 1. u sing additives that are chemical synthetics, and substances containing such chemical synthetics as food additives; or 2. s elling foods containing food additives under subparagraph 1 or manufacturing, importing, processing, using, cooking, storing, subdividing, transporting or displaying such foods for sale. 2.4. Issues related to the Food Sanitation Act ★ - With respect to the Transaction, the Company appears to be in compliance with the Food Sanitation Act . However, it is advisable to obtain representations and warranties from the Seller to the effect that the Company is fulfilling all the obligations under the Food Sanitation Act, and that no administrative disposition has been imposed against the Company from government agencies d ue to violation of such statute . CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 22 Prohibition against Sale and Use of Poisonous Apparatus, etc. (Article 8) - No one shall sell any apparatus, containers or packages containing or tainted with poisonous or harmful materials, which are likely to cause harm to human bodies, or any apparatus, containers or packages, which cause harm to human bodies when they are in contact with foods or f ood additives, or manufacture, import, store, transport, display any apparatus, containers or packages for sale or use them for business. 2. Considerations related to the Transaction In connection with the Transaction, it is advisable to obtain representations and warranties to the effect that the Company is fulfilling all the obligations under the Food Sanitation Act, and that no administrative disposition has been imposed against the Company from government agencies due to violation of such statute . CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 23 ◼ Reporting to the KFTC for business combination related to stock acquisition According to the Monopoly Regulation and Fair Trade Act ( Fair Trade Act ), in connection with a purchase of not less than twenty per cent. ( 20 %) of the total of outstanding stock of an unlisted company, the acquirer shall file a report thereon with the KFTC if it falls under the subparagraphs below (Article 12 (1) 1 and Article 2 (1 - 2) of the Fair Trade Act , an d Article 18 (1) and (2) of the Enforcement Decree of the Fair Trade Act) : (i) Acquirer whose total assets or sales are KRW 300 billion or more and the stock issuing company whose total assets or sales are KRW 30 billion or more as of the end of the immediately preceding business year . (ii) Acquirer whose total assets or are sales are KRW 30 billion or more and the stock issuing company whose tota l assets or sales are KRW 300 billion or more as of the end of the immediately preceding business year . The total amount of assets or the sales amount of the acquirer or the stock issuing company means the aggregate of the total amount of assets or the sa les amount of the company that continues to be affiliates from before the date of the business combination until after date of the business combination (Article 12 (2) of the Fair Trade Act) . A report on a corporate combination shall be filed within 30 da ys from the date of the corporate combination ( this date refers to the date of delivery of share certificates if share certificates are issued, and the date of payment of the stock purchase price if share certificates are not issued ). However, if any compa ny, involved in a business combination, has total assets or sales of at least KRW 2 trillion ( Large Company ), the acquirer must receive business merger approval from the KFTC before the date of the business combination ( Article 12 (6), (proviso) of the Fai r Trade Act, Article 18 (8) 1 of the Enforcement Decree of the Fair Trade Act Item C ). Considerations related to the Transaction : With respect to the Transaction, the Purchaser acquires more than twenty per cent . (20%) of the Company’s shares, however , according to the due diligence materials provided, the Company’s total assets, in 2020, are approximately KRW 11.5 billion and its total sales is a pproximately KRW 15.2 billion , which is less than KRW 30 billion . Therefore, regardless of the Purchaser’s total assets or total sales in 2020, the Purchaser is not obliged to report its business combination in relations to its stock acquisition to the KFTC . 2.5. Licenses and Permits related to the Transaction ★ - The Purchaser does not have obligations to report on a business merger related to its stock acquisition to the KFTC. Leased Property According to the due diligen ce materials provided, the Company has leased each floor of the Doosan - dong Commercial Building to different tenants, and the details are as follows: Property Leased Lessee Lease Deposit (KRW) Rent (KRW) Term 1 st Floor , Doosan - dong Commercial Building Park Chang - hwan 60,000,000 5,500,000 May 20, 2018 – May 19, 2023 2 nd Floor , Doosan - dong Commercial Building Choi Hyun - jun 50,000,000 3,600,000 July 12, 2020 – July 11, 2023 3 rd Floor , Doosan - dong Commercial Building Kim Taek - hyun 50,000,000 3,200,000 April 1, 2018 – March 31, 2023 The Commercial Building Lease Protection Act applies to the lease o f commercial buildings except in cases where the lease deposi t of the lease contract exceeds the threshold of lease deposit prescribed by the Enforcement Decree of Commercial Building Lease Protection Act. W here there is a monthly rent other than the lease deposit in a given lease contract , for the purpose of application of the said Act, the deposit amount shall be calculated by multiplying the loan amount by the ratio prescribed by the Presidential Decree , which is currently 1/100 ( Converted Deposit ) . (Article 2 ( 1 ), ( 2 ) of the Commercial Building Lease Protection Act; and Article 2 ( 3 ) of the Enforcement Decree of the Commercia l Building Lease Protection Act). As for the lease contract of a property in Daegu, the Commercial Building Lease Protection Act does not apply to leases with C onvert ed D eposits exceeding KRW 54 0 million (Article 2 ( 1 ) 3 of the Enforcement Decree of the Commercial Building Lease Protection Act). As for the Doosan - dong Commercial Building, t he C onvert ed D eposit of each lease contract is calculated as follows: KRW 610 million for the first f loor, KRW 41 0 million for the se cond floor, and KRW 370 million for the third floor . H ence , the Commercial Building Lease CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 27 Protection Act applies to the lease agreements for the second and third floo rs and not the first floor . 1 If the Commercial Building Lease Protection Act is not appl icable , the transferer/original landlord remains responsible for returning the lease deposit to the tenant under the lease contract even after the ownership of th e leased building has been transferred to the transferee/new landlord, except in the special c ircumstance in which the tenant has given consen t to the transferee’s assumption of debt for lease deposit which would discharge the transferer of its obligation to return the said deposit ( Korean Supreme Court Decision 94Da58599 , dated August 11, 1995). If the Commercial Building Lease Protection Act does apply to the lease contract, the transferee of a leased building shall be deemed to have succeeded the position of landlord (Article 3 ( 2 ) of the Commercial Building Lease Protection Ac t). According to the Company, it has been agreed among the Company and the purchasers of Doosa n - dong Commercial Building that the purchasers shall be responsible for the lease deposit s owed to the tenants. However, the Company must obtain a written agreem ent that the p urchaser s will assume the obligation to return the lease deposit to each tenant and thereby discharge the Company from the said obligation, and obtain the consent of each tenant on such written agreement , so as to ascertain that the Company i s legally exempt from the lease deposit liabilities . 2. Rented / Subleas ed / Deposited Property [Property Used as the Office] According to the due diligence materials provided, the Company has rented JM Tower, 401, Hwanggeum - dong, Suseong - gu, Daegu by paying KRW 50 million as lease deposit and a monthly rent of KRW 3 million , during the period between January 3, 2020 and May 13, 2022. Although the Commercial Building Le ase Protection Act applies to the above 1 According to Article 2 ( 3 ) of the Commercial Building Lease Protection Act, parts of the Commercial Building Lease Protection Act provisions, such as request for contract renewal, may apply to contracts lease agreement , 2 the Company has not acquired the preferential payment right for the lease deposit of KRW 50 million, as the Company did not complete business registration for the l ease agreement nor has it obtaine d a fixed date on the lease agreement . Since the property has a lready been provided as collateral security , with the maximum c laim amount of KRW 60 0 million, the Company runs the risk of not being repaid the lease deposit depending on the l essor’s solvency. 3. Considerations related to the Transaction There is no finding which may significantly impact the Transaction in relation to the leased or rented real estate propert ies . However , it is advisable to obtain representatio ns and warranties from the S eller to the effect that: (i) the Company has legitimate ownership of its rea l estate propert ies , and there are no other encumbrances established over the propert ies except for th ose established over Factory 1 and Doosa n - dong Co mmercial Building ; and, (ii) in relation to the sale of Doosa n - dong Commercial Building, it i s recommended that a w ritten agreement stating that the p urchaser s assumed the obligation to return the lease deposit owed to each tenant and thereby discharge the Company from the said obligation be drafted, with the consent of each tenant on such written agreement. ◼ Movable Propert ies Owned by the Company 1. Store Interior Installation (Article 9) - Interior facilities may be constructed by the franchisee directly or by a c ompany designated by the Company according to the specifications prescribed by the Company . - If constructed directly by a franchisee, the franchisee must pay KRW 220,000 (including V AT) per 3.3 meter squared (1 pyeong) for supervision fees to the Company. Equipment, Fixtures, Kitchen Appliances (Article 10) - The franchisees must use equipment with the same specifications as model s suggested by the Company . - The franchisee may purchase and install equipment by selecting the Company, a business designated by the Company , or a business by themselves. Education and Training (Article 11) - The franchisee must complete the Company’s pre - opening training before the opening date of the franchise . - Immediately after singing of the agreement, t he franchisee must deposit KRW 2,200,000 (including VAT) as an education fee ( per person) to a financial institution designated by the Company. Membership Fee (Article 14) - Membership fee shall be KRW 11,000,000 (including VAT). - Membership fee upon renewal of agreement shall be KRW 11,000,000 (including VAT) . - If the agreement is termin ated during the term of the agreement , the Company shall return the membership fees and the education fees to the franchisee : ✓ i f the agreement is terminated before the commencement of the franchise business , the amount excluding actual expenses, for goods delivered and services provided, and penalties shall be refunded ; and ✓ i f the agreement is terminated after the commencement of the franchise business , membership fee s shall be deemed as an expense incurred for the first time in order to participate as a fr anchise, and shall not be refunded (p rovided that, this shall not apply where termination is due to reasons attributable to the Company ). Membership Fee Deposit (Article 15) - In the following cases, the deposit becomes vested in the Company: ✓ w here a franchisee has started business ; ✓ w here two months have passed since entering into a franchise agreement (provided, that if any of the following measures are taken before two months have elapsed, the refund of the membership fee s may be requested; in case of p oint 4 (below) , it must be before four months have passed) : 1. w here a franchisee has filed a lawsuit to receive a return of the deposit; 2. w here a franchisee has filed an application for an arrangement, mediation, or arbitration to receive a return of the deposit; 3. w here the Company requested the deposit through false or other fraudulent means; and 4.4 Business Relationship with Franchisees ★★★ - N o special legal problem was found in relation to the franchise agreements entered into by the Company with the franchisees . - Expenses related to kitchen appliances i n the disclosure document (for the year 2021) registered by the Company requires correction. - T he Company appears to be in compliance with the franchiser’s obligation under the Fair Transactions in Franchise Business Act . However , it is advisable to obtain representations and warranties from the Seller to the effect that the Company is in compliance with all of its obligations as a franchiser under the Fair Transactions in Franchise Business Act. The initial membership fee to be paid by a new franchisee is as follows: Type Amount Value Added Tax (VAT) Membership Fee KRW 10,000,000 KRW 1,000,000 Training Fee KRW 2,000,000 KRW 200,000 Total KRW 12,000,000 KRW 1,200,000 Other expenses to be borne by the franchisee are as follows: Type of Expense Required/Optional Amount VAT Kitchen Appliances, etc. Optional KRW 18,000,000 KRW 1,800,000 Interior Design Optional KRW 5,000,000 KRW 500,000 Service Fee: KRW 200,000 per 3.3 meter squared (1 Pyeong) KRW 20,000 Signboard KRW 2,000,000 KRW 200,000 Radio Advertisement Required KRW 150,000 KRW 15,000 Total - KRW 25,150,000 KRW 2,515,000 According to the due diligence materials provided, the Franchise Agreement for the metropolitan areas ( agreement for Mabuk - gu, Yongin Branch provided as a sample ) and the Franchise Agreement for the non - metropolitan areas ( agreement for Samcheonpo Branch provided as a sample ) signed by the Compa ny are the same, except for the payment method. According to the Franchise Agreement for metropolitan area s (Mabuk - gu, Yongin Branch), a franchisee must pay KRW 5.5 million (including VAT) to the Company, and KRW 5.5 million (VAT included) to the Branch. On the other hand, according to the Franchise Agreement for non - metropolitan area (Samcheonpo Branch), a franchisee must pay KRW 11 million (including VAT) to the Company. CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 38 In addition, franchisees in a metropolitan area must pay KRW 3 million on the date of provisional agreement , KRW 7 million on the date of franchise agreement , and the remaining amount on the opening date totaling KRW 19.8 million (including VAT) for kitchen appliances, etc. Franchisees in a non - metropolitan area must pay KRW 2 million on the date of provisional agreement and the remaining amount on the opening date. ◼ Issues related to the Fair Transactions in Franchise Business Act The Company is a “franchise business”, a business authorizing franchises ( Franchisor ) , by requi ring the franchisees to sell products according to the Company’s quality standards or business methods through the Franchisor’s trademark, service mark, company name, signpost, business mark, etc., and by supporting, educating, and regulating necessary bus iness and operational activities. The Fair Transactions in the Franchise Business Act regulates matters regarding fair transactions between the franchisor and the franchisees, and the details are as follows: Article Details Registration of Information Disclosure Statements (Article 6 - 2) - Each franchiser shall register an information disclosure statement to be provided to prospective franchisees with the KFTC or with the competent Special Metropolitan City Mayor, Metropolitan City Mayor, Special Self - Governing City Mayor, Do Governor or Special Self - Governing Province Governor . Deposit of Franchise Fees (Article 6 - 5) - Each franchiser shall require its franchisees to deposit franchise fees in a depository , p rovided, t hat the foregoing shall not apply where a franchiser enters into an indemnity insurance agreement , etc., for its franchisees . - When a franchisee commences business or when two months have passed since the execution date of a franchise agreement, any franchi ser may request the head of the depository to pay a franchise deposit . Duty to Provide Information Disclosure Statements (Article 7) - Each franchiser shall provide its prospective franchisees with an information disclosure statement which was registered or the alteration of which was registered by methods prescribed, such as certified mail or electronic mail, by which the point in time o f providing the information disclosure statement may be objectively confirmed. - Unless a franchiser has provided a registered information disclosure document and a document stating the current status of neighboring franchisees or 14 days (7 days where a pro spective franchisee has been given advice and suggestions by an attorney - at - law or franchise trader on an information disclosure statement) have passed from the date it provides the information disclosure statement, etc., it shall not r eceiv e franchise fees from a prospective franchisee or enter into a franchise agreement with a prospective franchisee. Prohibition of Providing False or Exaggerated Information (Article 9) - No franchiser shall provide information different from fact or any exagg erated information , nor provide information by suppressing or minimizing any fact that has significant influence on the conclusion or maintenance of a n agreement. Matters to Be Included in Franchise Agreement (Article 11) If 14 days have not elapsed from the date a franchiser provides its prospective franchisees with a franchise agreement, the franchiser shall not r eceiv e franchise fees from a prospective franchisee or enter into a franchise agreement with a prospective fra nchisee. - Each franchise agreement shall include the following: (i) m atters concerning the grant of a license for business marks; (ii) m atters concerning the terms and conditions of business activities of the franchisee; (iii) m atters concerning the education, training, and business guidance of the franchisee; (iv) m atters concerning the payment of franchise fees and ot her fees ; (v) m atters concerning th e demarcation of business territory; (vi) m atters concerning the term of the agreement; (vii) m atters concerning the transfer of business; (viii) m atters concerning the grounds for termination of the agreement; (ix) t he fact that a franchise deposit shall be deposited in the dep ository ; CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 39 (x) The fact that the prospective franchisee has consulted an attorney - at - law or a franchise trader, if it is the case; and (xi) m atters concerning the obligation to compensate franchisees for loss es arising . Prohibitions on Unfair Trade Practices (Article 12) - No franchiser shall engage in, or cause any other business entity to engage in, any of the following acts that are likely to hamper fair franchise business transactions: (i) u nreasonably suspending or refusi ng the supply of commodities or services or business assistance to a franchisee or placing significant limitations thereon; (ii) i mposing unfair restraints or limitations on the prices of commodities or services that a franchisee handles, or on customers, busin ess territory, or business activities of a franchisee; (iii) p utting a franchisee at an unfair disadvantage by abusing its position in transactions; (iv) u nreasonably imposing obligations to compensate for damage on a franchisee, imposing an excessive penalty compare d with criteria prescribed by Presidential Decree, such as the purpose and contents of an agreement, and losses that will occur; or (v) a ny act that is likely to interfere with fair transactions in franchising, such as inducing franchisees of a competing franchiser to conduct transactions with the franchiser. Notification of Execution Details of Advertising and Promotional Events (Article 12 - 6) - Where the franchiser holds advertising and promotional events whose expenses are borne fully or partially by a franchisee, it shall notify the franchisee of the execution details and allow the franchisee to peruse the details if requested. Renewal of Franchise Agreement (Article 13) - Upon request by a franchisee to renew the franchise agreement durin g the period between 180 days and 90 days prior to the expiration date of the franchise agreement, no franchiser shall reject such request without good cause. - Any franchiser that intends to refuse the request for renewal shall notify the relevant franchise e of the grounds for refusal within 15 days from the date it receives such request. Limitations on Termination of Franchise Agreement (Article 14) - Any franchiser that intends to terminate a franchise agreement shall clearly state the franchisee's breach of the agreement during the grace period of not less than two months and shall give written notice at least twice that it will terminate the agreement unless such breach is corrected during the given period. - The termination of a franchise agreement without complying with the procedure above shall have no effect. The franchise fee deposit system is a system requiring the franchise fee to be deposited at a depository for a period of time in order to prevent franchisees from losing their franchise fees before the commencement of franchisee business due to the franchisor ’ s failure to fulfill its obligations of ordinary business support by acts of suspending or abolishing the franchise business etc. , after collecting the franchise fee from the franchisee. Therefore, it is difficult to establish that the act of the franchisor directly receiving the franchise fees , after the commencement of franchisee’s business , is a violation of the Fair Transactions in Franchise Business Act ( Fair Trade Commission 2015 Gwangsa 2742, March 4, 2016; Fair Trade Commission 2013 Bus a 3235, October 15, 2014; Fair Trade Commission 2011 SeoJae 1720, March 15, 2012). According to the documents provided, the franchise fee and education fee of the Company are included in the ‘ initial franchise fee ’ and is considered to be a ‘ franchise fee de posit ’ under the Fair Transaction in Franchise Business Act as it is a payment made by the franchisee to use the business sign age and to receive support and education for its operations. According to the Company, the Company did not enter into an indemnity insurance agreement , etc., for its franchisees, hence, it has an obligation to deposit the franchise fees. The Company receives the franchise fee deposit by a method in which the franchisee mak es a direct deposit to the Company’s bank account . However , it appears that the Company is not in violation of its obligation to deposit franchise fees under the Fair Transactions in Franchise Business Act because the time of receipt is after the commencement of franchisee’s business. However, if the date of receipt is changed to a date before the commencement of franch is ee’s business, the Company shall not directly receive the deposit. CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 40 On the other hand, no franchisor shall engage in acts that are likely to hamper fair franchise business transactions, which include imposing unfair restraints or limitations on the prices of commodities or services, or on customers, business territory, or business activities of a franchisee (Article 12 of the Fair Transactions in Franchise Business Act). There may be a risk of violatio n of the Fair Transactions in Franchise Business Act if the franchisee was forced to do business with a business designated by the franchisor for subsidiary materials and kitchen appliances (timers, napkin, fork, sauce cups, etc.) that do not have an effec t on trademark protections or maintaining uniform quality of its goods and services (Fair Trade Commission 2018 Hyupshim 0653, 2016 Gamaeng 3583). According to the documents provided, the Company purchases kitchen appliances from the following suppliers: OTOK AEM, PIZZA CAMP, JUBANG BANK , etc., and sells the appliances to new franchisees. According to the Company, franchisee s may choose to purchase kitchen appliances from the suppliers designated by the Company, but it is not obligatory. However, i f the franchisee s are in fact forced to purchase kitchen appliances not directly related to the taste or quality of the pizza or the Company’s trademark from a business designated by the Company, such act may correspond to Unfa ir Trade Practices which is prohibited by the Fair Transactions in Franchise Business Act . ◼ Considerations related to the Transaction After reviewing the franchise agreement provided, there seems to be no particular legal issue . In addition, the Transactio n does not constitute a valid reason for the cancellation or termination of the F ranchise A greement between the Company and the franchisee s , and with regard to the Transaction, the Company is not obliged to consult with the franchisee s or seek their consen t. According to the due diligence materials provided, the Company receives KRW 19.8 million (including VAT) for kitchen appliances, etc., from each franchisee. However, the information disclosure statement registered with the Fair Trade Commission on Apri l 27, 2021, states that the fee for kitchen appliances, etc., to be paid by each franchisee is KRW 16,940,000 (including VAT) . T herefore, this section of the statement must be revised. According to the due diligence materials provided, the Company is in c ompliance with the Matters to Be Included in Franchise Agreement (Article 11) in its information disclosure document. In addition, according to the due diligence materials provided, the Company is in compliance with Registration of Information Disclosure S tatements (Article 6 - 2), Deposit of Franchise Fees (Article 6 - 5), Duty to Provide Information Disclosure Statements (Article 7), Prohibition of Providing False or Exaggerated Information (Article 9), Return of Franchise Fees (Article 10), Prohibition of Un fair Pressure to Improve Store Environment (Article 12 - 2), Prohibition of Unfair Restrictions on Business Hours (Article 12 - 3), Prohibition of Unfair Violation of Sales Areas (Article 12 - 4), Prohibition of Measures of Retaliation (Article 12 - 5), Notificati on of Execution Details of Advertising and Promotional Events (Article 12 - 6), etc. However, it is advisable to obtain representations and warranties from the Seller to the effect that the Company is in compliance with its obligations under the Fair Transac tions in Franchise Business Act as a franchisor.
