Employment & Labor Relations 5.1 Human Resources ★★ 5.2 Wage Composition and Related Issues ★ CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 46 ◼ Executives and Employees 1. Executives According to the due diligence material s provided, th e Company has two (2) executives. The details are as follows: Name Category Position Registration in the Commercial Registry Full - time/ Part - time Yoon Sung - won Representative Director CEO Registered Full - time Yoon Jon g - yeol Standing Director Director Registered Full - time 2. Employees According to the due diligence material s provided, as of the date of this Report, the Company has thirty (30) employees. The details are as follows: Position Number of Employees Manufacturing Factory 1 17 Factory 2 6 Manager 3 Office 4 Total 30 ◼ Rem un eration and Severance Pay for Executives Article 388 of the KCC is a mandatory provision which states that if the amount of remuneration to be paid to the registered directors and the statutory auditor is not set forth in articles of incorporation, such amount shall be determined by a resolution of the general meeting of sh areholders ; p rovided, it is possible to determine only the total amount or the cap of total remuneration at the general meeting of shareholders and delegate the decision of specific matters, such as the amount to be paid to individual directors, to the board of directors ( Korean Supreme Court D ecision 2012 Da 1993, dated March 29, 2012). Unless there is a resolution of the general meeting of shareholders, a director does not have the right to demand remuneration ( Korean Supreme Court Decision 92 Da 28228, dated December 22, 1992), and any remuneration paid to a director without being determined either in the articles of incorporation or by a resolution of the general meeting of shareholders shall be deemed unjust enrichment on the part of such director and must be returned to the company ( Korean Supreme Court Decision 2007 Da 71271, dated March 11, 2010). According to the A rticles of I ncorporatio n: (i) remuneration of directo rs (excluding severance pay and compensation for bereaved families) shall be limited to KRW 3 billion per year, and it shall be prescribed by a separate regulation on the payment of executive member’s remuneration approved by the resolution of general meet ing of shareholders (Article 50 ( 1 ) of the Articles of Incorporation); (ii) severance pay for directors and auditors shall be limited to KRW 5 billion per year calculated by [Salary Before Retirement x Length 5.1 Human Resources ★★ - The Company must draft and maintain the minutes of the general meeting of shareholders approv ing the executives’ remuneration. - In connection with the Transaction, it is advisable to obtain representations and warranties from the Seller to the effect that the Company is compl ying with the relevant laws and regulations with respect to employment or labor, such as the Labor Standards Act , and that it has not received any administrative disposition nor has it been involved in any lawsuits, disputes, or conflicts with respect to em ployment or labor . CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 47 of Service x Payout Ratio], and the details of p ayment shall be determined by a separate regulation on the severance pay for executives , which shall be approved by a resolution of general meeting of shareholders (Article 50 ( 2 ) of the Articles of Incorporation). According to the Rules: (i) executive remuneration comprise of [ regular benefits + bonus ]; (ii) the regular benefit s are compris e d of [ base salary + allowance ] , and the amount determined by the resolution of the general meeting of shareholders each year shall be included in the annual remuneration agreement ; while a new annual remuneration agreement is not necessary when the amount of regular benefits in a given year is not changed from that of the year before , the remuneration agreement shall be amended by resolution of the general meeting of shareholders if the regular benefit s for the remaining period is change d throughout the ye ar (Article 5) ; (iii) b onus is comprise d of regular bonus and performance - based bonus ; the size of bonus may not exceed 200% of the regular benefits, and the bonus amount, time of payment, etc., of regular bonus es to individual executives shall be 5 Special contribution compensation shall be 50% of severance pay; retirement compensation shall be paid within 50% of severance pay where one is retiring due to an injury or disease from work, and 100% for death at work (Article 8 of the Rules on the Executives’ Severance Pay ment ) . finalize d by a resolution of the board of directors (or resolution of the general meeting of shareholders in the absence of a board of directors) and shall be stated in the remuneration contract for individual executives (Article 6) ; (iv) p erformance - based bonuses may be paid upon resolution of the general meeting of shareholders, and if such resolution exists, the remuneration contract shall be amended (Article 7) and (v) e xecutive remuneration , aside from performance - based bonuses, must be paid within the limits of Article 50 ( 1 ) and Article 60 ( 1 ) of the Articles of Incorporation (Article 9). According to the Company and due diligence materials provided , the Company is paying KRW 10 . 5 million to Yoon Sung - won, the Representative Director , and KRW 9 . 5 millio n to Yoon Jong - ye o l, a s tanding d irector, as of April 2021. Considerations related to the Transaction : According to the due diligence materials provided, in accordance with the A rticles of I ncorporation , the executives of the Company must be paid based on the Rules and the Rules on E xecutive s’ Severance P ayment . A ccording to the Rules , an executive’s remuneration shall be determined by a resolution of the general meeting of shareholders e ach year , within the limit prescribed by the A rticles of Incorpora tion (KRW 3 billion per year). While t he Company has formal regulations governing the remuneration and severance pay for its executives, it has not drafted any minute s of general meetings of shareholders approving such regulations as of yet. In addition, t he Company does not appear to have determined the remuneration of executives by resolution of a general meeting of shareholders until now . Meanwhile, i n the case of a so - called one - person company , one person owns the total shares of a joint stock company a s the sole shareholder of the company . Since it is clear that, if the shareholder attends the general meeting of shareholders as the sole shareholder, the resolution will be made according to th e sole shareholder’s decision, even if the general meeting wa s not held, if the minutes of the general meeting of shareholders indicating that there was a resolution by the single shareholder ha s been prepared, it may be deemed t hat there was such a resolution , in the absence of special circumstances ( Korean Supreme Court Decision 74 Da 1755, dated April 13, 1976). However, since the R epresentative D irector has been the sole shareholder since the company went public, if the R epresentative D irector : (i) authorizes the executive remuneration payment regulations, the executive retirement payment regulations, and payments to executives, and (ii) prepares the minutes of the general meeting of shareholders retrospectively approving the remuneration of executives paid to date, there are grounds fo r the paid remuneration to executives and the possibility of conflict may be eliminated. In connection with the Transaction : (i) the regular benefits of executives should be determined by resolution of the general meeting of shareholders in the future ; an d (ii) the Rules and the Rules on Executives’ Severance Payment must be a pprov ed by a resolution of general meeting of shareholders, and it is advisable to prepar e minutes of the general meeting of shareholders , which retrospectively approve the past remun eration paid to executives. ◼ Implementation of 52 - Hour Workweek System According to the Labor Standards Act, work ing hours shall not exceed 40 hours per week, and eight hours per day (Article 50 of the Labor Standards Act), but where an agreement is made b etween the parties, work ing hours may be extended by up to 12 hours per week (Article 53 ( 1 ) of the Labor Standards Act). In relation to this matter, the Ministry of Employment and Labor has maintained the administrative interpretation that the maximum working hours per week for employees shall be 68 hours [= (Weekday 40 hours (= 8 hours x 5 days) + 12 hours for Extended Work ing Hours + 16 hours for holidays (=8 hours x 2 days) = 68 hours) ] , provided that Saturday is considered as a holiday ; if Saturday is considered as a non - working day , the maximum working hours shall be 60 hours instead of 68 hours as the 8 working - hour s ( Saturday ) need be deducted. On the other hand, the Labor Standard s Act, amended and enforced as of November 1, 2019, prescribes one (1) week as seven (7) days including holidays (Article 2 ( 1 )7 of the Labor Standards Act), and provides that the maximum working hours per week for an employee shall be 52 hours [= Weekday 4 0 hours + 12 hours for Weekday and Holiday Extended Work Hours] ( the 52 - Hour Workweek System ), and the enforcement date of the 52 - Hour Workweek System depending on the size of the business is as follows: (i) July 1, 2018, for a busines s regularly employing at least 300 or more peopl es; (ii) January 1, 2020, for a business regularly employing between 50 and less than 300 p e ople ; and (iii) July 1, 2021, for a business regularly employing between 5 and less than 50 p e ople . However, any business employing less than 300 people has been given a one - year probation period from January 1, 2020, suspending the application of 52 - Hour Work w eek System . According to the due diligence materials provided, the 52 - hour W orkweek System shall apply to the Compa ny as of July 1, 2021 as the Company is regularly employing between 5 and 50 people . According to the Company, the working hours of its employees do not exceed 52 hours per week. ◼ Prohibition of Competitive Transaction and Confidentiality According to the due diligence material s provided, the Company obtains a pre - drafted security undertaking from each employee, which is a separate document from the employment contract. The undertaking states that the employee shall not : ( i ) disclose or divulge trade secret s, development secrets, production secrets, etc. , of the Company without permission; ( II ) illegally use or appropriate any intellectual or physical property without consen t; and ( iii ) use the Company’s trade secrets to start a new business, or transfer to or partner with a competing company or any other third par ty , during one’s employment and for three years after the end of employment ; and further states that ( iv ) any violation of ( i ) through ( iii ) will lead to penalties in accordance with relevant regulations . Meanwhile , given that a non - competiti on agreement restricts the freedom of occupational choice as well as an employee’s labor rights, etc., even if an employee agrees to a limited non - competition period with the employer, the length of non - competition period may be limited to a reasonable extent if it is deemed excessively long in consideration of all circumstances , including the employer’s interests that are wor thy of protection , status of the employee before retirement, the details of retirement, whether to provide the employee with remuneration, etc. ( Korean Supreme Court Decision 2006 Ma 1303, dated March 29, 2007) . While the courts have recognized the validit y of a range CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 49 of non - competition period s depending on the facts of each case, a non - competition agreement between one or two years is generally deemed valid. The particular text of the security undertaking used by the Company can be interpreted as applying to a case in which an employee t ransfer s to a competi ng company and using the Company’s trade secrets . 6 Alternatively if the statement i s interpreted as a typical non - competition clause barring the employee’s move to a competi ng company for three years, such non - competition agreement will be effective in principle, provided that the period of non - competition recognized by the court may be within one or two years if it becomes a subject of legal dispute . In connection with the Transaction , it is advisable to include : ( i ) the scope of protected trade secrets ; and ( ii ) prohibiting engagement in competitive transactions such as employment with competitors for a period of time, or establishing and operating competing businesses of their own, r egardless of the use of trade secrets in such endeavor , in the security undertaking signed by the employees, to ensure protection of the Company’s trade secrets . ◼ Four Major Insurances and Severance Pay According to the Company, the Company maintains healt h insurance, national pension, employment insurance and industrial accident compensation insurance for its employees in accordance with relevant laws and regulations and there is no outstanding payment . According to the Company and the due diligence mater ial s provided, the C ompany has adopted d efined benefits r etirement p ension p lans for six employees who have been employed for more than one year, and there are no outstanding payments under such plan. For other employees, the Company has adopted a severance pay scheme, under which any employee who retires after one year of service shall be paid the average wage for a 30 - day period per year of service (Article 110 ( 1 ) of the Employment Regulations). 6 Article 3 of the Security Undertaking states , “I pledge that I will not use the Company’s trade secrets to start a business, transfer or partner with a competitor, use the trade secret s for myself, competitors or other t hird parties while in office as well as for three years after retirement” , and Article 1 and 2 of the Undertaking prohibits an employee from disclosing or illegally using business secrets, and According to the Company, there are no outstanding s everance pay owed to any former employees . CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 50 1. Classification of Employment Agreements Employment agreements are divided into employment agreements with fixed periods and employment contracts without fixed periods. In the absence of any special circumst ances, said agreements are di stinguished by the inclusion of a definite employment contract perio d with in the employment agreement . According to the due diligence materials provided, the Company entered into an employment contract with several employees with specified date s of employment and termination, hence the employee i s deemed to be an employee with an agreement with a fixed period ( fixed - term worker ). 2. Precautions for Entering into a Fixed - term Employment Agreement In the case of a fixed - term worker, in principle, the state o f employment is terminated at the end of fi xed term as per the contract. However, the Act on the Protection, etc. , of Fixed - Term and Part - Time Employees ( Act on the Protection of Fixed - Term Employees ) prescribe s that an employer may hire a worker for a fixed - term not exceeding two (2) years, and wh ere any employer hires a worker on a fixed term, and such term lasts longer than two (2) years, such worker shall be deemed an employee who has entered into an employment contract without fixed period (Article 4 of the Act on the Protection of Part - Time Em ployees). If an employe r intends to terminate the employme nt without fixed term , the provision on the restriction on dismissal applies, therefore, if an employer terminates the contract without justifiable cause, it may be deemed as an unfair dismissal (Article 23 of the Labor Standards Act). In the case of a fixed - term worker with less than 2 years of employment, where there is a trust relationship between the parties of the employment contract and the employee forms a justified belief that t he employment contract shall be renewed subject to certain requirements, then the employer’s refusal to renew the employment contract in violation of the employee’s justified expectation for the renewal of employment contract is legally invalid, and the em ployment relationship as per the original employment contract persists regardless of the end of fixed - term ( Korean Supreme Court Decision, 2011 Do 12528, dated February 13, 2014). However, even when a fixed - term employee has a justified expectation for a r enewal of employment contract, the employer’s refusal t o renew the contract would not constitute an unfair dismissal if it has a reasonable reason not to renew the said contract, in which case the employer has the burden of pr oving that the rationale and p rocedures for the refusal to renew the employment contract are objective ly reasonable, and fair in light of social conventions ( Korean Supreme Court Decision, 2015 Do 44493, dated October 12, 2017). Furthermore, a fixed - term employment contract must inclu de, in writing : (i) the contract period ; (ii) working hours and rest hours ; (iii) the components and the method of calculation and payment of wages ; (iv) holidays and leave ; and (v) the place of work and duties to be perform ed (Article 17 of the Act on the Protection of Fixed - Term Employees). In addition, an employer shall not discriminate a gainst a fixed - term employee compared to employees without fixed - term period s in a similar industry . Any fixed - term employee who has received discriminatory treatment may file a request for correction with the Labor Relations Commissions . If the Labor Relations Commission determines that the treatment in question is indeed discriminatory , after completing an investigation and inqu i ry into the ma tter , it shall issue a corrective order to the employer (Article 9 and 12 of the Act on the Protection of Fixed - T erm Employees). 3. Considerations related to the Transaction According to the Company and the due diligence materials provided, the Company has six ( 6 ) fixed - term employees, is compl ying with the terms and conditions of the fixed - term contract s entered into with the said employees, and is not discriminating against the fixed - term employees compared to its full - time employees. As of now the Company is not planning to convert the fixed - term employees to full - time employees , hence , the Company must take caution not to exceed two years of contract work with such employee s. As for fixed - term employees with less than two years of work , the emp loyees’ right to renew al of employment contract may be recognized , meeting certain requirements. Therefore, it is necessary to clearly define the criteria and procedures for renewal for employment contracts within such contracts or in the CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 51 E mployment Regula tions so as to prevent any legal dispute surrounding fixed - term employment from arising . In connection with the Transaction, it is advisable to obtain representations and warranties from the Seller to the effect that the Company is not in violation of the Act on the Protection of Fixed - Term Employees and that it has not received any administrative disposition from government authorities regarding employment agreement s with fixed - term employees. ◼ Foreign Workers According to the due diligence material s provided, the Company has not hired any foreign workers. ◼ Obligation to Hire Persons with Disabilities According to the Act on the Employment Promotion and Vocational Rehabilitation of Persons with Disabilit ies ( Act on the Employment of Persons with Disabilities ), any business owner who regularly employs at least 50 employees shall employ persons with disabilities to fill at a least 3.1% of the total employees (Article 28 ( 1 ) of the Act on the Employment of Pe rsons with Disabil i ties; Article 25 ( 2 ) of the Enforcement Decree of the Act). A business owner who employs persons with disabilities , but fails to meet the mandatory employment ratio shall pay a contributory charge. The amount of contributory charge shall be the annual aggregate of the amount calculated by multiplying the total number of persons with disabilities whom the business owner is obligated to employ at the mandatory employment ratio less the number of persons with disabilities regularly employed e ach month by the base amount of contributory charges (Article 33 of the Act on the Employment of Persons with Disabilities). As t he Company is currently employing l ess than 50 people, it is does not have an obligation to hire persons with disabilities unde r the Act on the Employment of Persons with Disabilities. ◼ Labor Union and Labor - Management Council According to the Company, the Company does not have a labor union. However, ccording to the Act on the Promotion of Employees’ Participation and Cooperatio n ( Act of Employees’ Participation ), any business employing more than 30 employees on a regular basis must establish a labor - management council, and the council shall hold meetings regularly every three months (Article 4 ( 1 ) of the Act of Employees’ Participation; Article 6 ( 1 ) of the Act of Employees’ Participation; and Article 12 ( 1 ) of the Act of Employees’ Participation), and the council shall establish bylaws governing its organization and operation and submit them to the Minister of Employment and Labor within 15 days from the date of establishment of the council (Article 18 of the Act of Employees’ Participation). According to the Company, the Company has not yet established a labor - management council. A person who rejec ts or obstructs the establishment of a labor - management council without any justifiable reason shall be punished by a fine not exceeding KRW 10 million (Article 30 of the Act of Employees’ Participation), and any employer who fails to submit council bylaws shall be punished by an administrative fine of up to KRW 2 million(Article 3 3 of the Act of Employees’ Participation) . As of April 2021, the Company has 30 employees . However, this figure includes employees who se employment may or may not continue, such as the R epresentative D irector’s mother , and the figure appears to fluctuate continuously. S ince the number of regular employees is close to 30, it may be come necessary for the Company to establish a labor - management council depending on t he number of empl oyees in the future . ◼ Provision of Mandatory Legal Education According to the Equal Employment Opportunity and Work - Family Balance Assistance Act ( Equal Employment Act ), the employer shall conduct preventative education in sexual harassment in the workplac e every year in order to prevent sexual harassment in the workplace (Article 13 ( 1 ) of the Equal Employment Act; Article 3 ( 1 ) of the Enforcement Decree of the Act), which may be provided through the worker’s training, morning meetings, conferences, cyber ed ucation using an information and communications network, such as the i nternet, in consideration of the business size or characteristics (Article 3 ( 3 ) of the Enforcement Decree of the Equal Employment Act), and where an employe r fails to conduct preventative education of sexual harassment, it shall be CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 52 punished by an administrative fine not exceeding KRW 5 million (Article 3 ( 2 )1 - 2 of the Equal Employment Act). According to the Act on the Employment of Persons with Disabilities, the business owner shall conduct education for improving awareness of persons with disabilities every year for one hour, and the business owners and employees shall receive educat ion for improving awareness of persons with disabilities (Article 5 - 2 of the Act on the Employment of Persons with Disabilities), and if the employer fails to conduct education mentioned above, the individual shall be subject to an administrative fine not exceeding KRW 3 million (Article 86 of the Act on the Employment of Persons with Disabilities). According to the Occupational Safety and Health Act, an employer with at least 50 workers s hall require the worker to regularly complete safety and health educ ation, at least three hours each quarter for office workers, and at least six hours each quarter for production workers (Article 31 of the Occupational Safety and Health Act; Article 33 ( 1 ) , Table 8 of the Occupational Safety and Health Act). According to the Personal Information Protection Act, a personal information controller (public institution, legal person, organization, individual, etc. , that processes personal information directly or indirectly to operate personal information files as p art of its activities) shall provide personal information handlers ( any p erson in charge of e mployment and l abor, a dministration, etc.) with necessary educational programs on a regular basis in order to ensure the appropriate handling of personal informati on (Article 28 ( 2 ) of the Personal Information Protection Act). According to the Company, the Company is regularly conducting preventative education of sexual harassment, education for improving awareness of persons with disabilities, and safety and health education for its employees . ◼ Disputes related to Employment and Labor, etc. According to the Company, the Company has not received any administrative disposition from government authorities regarding its employment and labor affairs and is not involved i n any form of legal disputes including lawsuits, disputes or conflicts regarding employment and labor affairs. CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 53 ◼ Components of Salary According to the due diligence material s provided, the Company has adopted: (i) the annual salary system for the employee s working in office ; and (ii) the monthly salary system for other employees with respect to wages. T he components of wages are as follows: Type Components Payment Condition Field Employee Base Salary - Full - time Allowance - Pay able when an employee has worked without being absent, leaving early, etc. Dough - related Allowance - Payment of KRW 20,000 per day for moving dough Office Employee Base Salary - Fixed Overtime Allowance - 1.5 times the hourly salary rate for overtime work over the weekend Meal Allowance - No specif ic criteria applicable According to the due diligence material s provided, only the R epresentative D irector and one (1) employee receive d meal allowance , and only the R epresentative D irector receive d car maintenance allowance of KRW 200,000 in April 2021. ◼ Possibility of Unpaid Wages related to the Calculated Ordinary Wage and Average Wage 1. Calculation Method of Ordinary Wage and Average Wage An o rdinary wage is the “amount determined to be paid regularly and uniformly to employees for fixed hours of work or total work” , which serve as the basis for calculatin g various legal allowances . Whether a wage belongs is considered an ordinary wage shall be determined by its objective nature on the basis of whether the wage is paid regularly, uniformly or in fixed intervals in return for a fixed amount of work and is not determined by a formal criteri on such as the name of the wage or the length of the payment cycle ( Korean Supreme Court Decision 2012 Da 89399 , dated December 18, 2013). The average wage is the total amount of wages paid to the employee in the three months prior to the date of calculation divided by the total number of days in the period . The average wage serves as the basis for calculating shutdown allowance and emergency payment under the Labor Standards Act, and severance pay under the Act on the Guarantee of Employees’ Retirement Benefits and the Labor Standards A ct. All monies and goods of valu e received by an employee as compensation for work in accordance with the employment agreement or the Company’s internal regulations , regardless of its name , shall be included in the total amount of wages which is the basis for the calculation of the average wage. 2. The Wage Calculation and the Possibility of Unpaid Wages 5.2 Wage Composition and Possibility of Wage Miscalculation ★ - As of the date of the Report, the Company is unlikely to incur contingent liabilities in connection with employees’ wages. - The Company needs to promote the employees’ use of annual paid leave so as not to incur the obligation to pay annual paid leave allowance . - It is advisable to obtain representations and warranties from the Seller to the effect that the Company does not have any outstanding wages owed to its employees such as any unpaid legal allowances. CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 54 According to the Company, the Company includes, regardless of an employee’s line of work : (i) only the base salary in ordinary wages ; and (ii) each of the w age components to the total wage , which serves as the basis for calculation of the average wa g e. The Full - time A llowance and D ough - related A llowance paid by the Company to some employees working in production are not included in ordinary wages, but only in average wages. Since the Full - time A llowance i s paid only to employee s who have not been absent or late , 7 and Dough - related Allowance is paid only to the employees who have performed a particular task , each a llowance is deemed to be an irregular and non - uniform type of allowance ; as such, Full - time A llowance and D ough - related A llowance are deemed not to be ordinary wages. Meanwhile, with respect to whether the Fixed Overtime Allowance which is paid monthly under the comprehensive wage system shall be deemed as a type of ordinary wage, if the Company decided to make overtime pay ments to its employees at a fixed rate, because it is difficult to measure the actual hours an employee has worked past the working hours , owing to the nature of the business , and the calculation of such fixed - rate overtime payment is based on Article 55 of the Labor Standards Act which is predicated on actual overtime work, such overtime pay men t shall not be deem ed a type of ordinary wage (Seoul High Court 2001 Na 24961 Decision , dated October 12, 2001). According to the due diligence materials provided, the re are three sales supervisors in the Company who are being paid the Fixed Overtime Allo wance under the comprehensive wage system , and whose employment agreement s specif y overtime hours predicated on actual overtime work. As such, the Fixed Overtime Allowance paid to the sales supervisors would not be deemed an ordinary wage . In conclusion, there are no special legal issues to be raised with regard to the calculation of ordinary wages. ◼ Validity of the Comprehensive Wage System and the Possibility of Unpaid Wages 7 Wages payable upon meeting a certain number of working days will be paid only when the additional conditions (namely, meeting a certain number of working days , in addition to providing a fixed number of working days ) are met, and the achievement of these conditions cannot be said to be ‘ stable ’, because it is an uncertain condition the fulfillment of which cannot be asce rtained on any given day involving 1. Validity of the Comprehensive Wage System According to the due diligence materials provided , the Company has adopted a comprehensive wage system for its three sales supervisor s . The Korean Supreme Court recognizes the validity of the comprehensive wage system under limited circumstances, in which : (i) the calculati on of working hours under the Labor Standards Act is difficult due to irregular working hours and breaks ; and (ii) there is no practical disadvantage to the employee ( Korean Supreme Court 2008 Da 6052 Decision, dated May 13, 2010). If a comprehensive wage system has been adopted in the absence of difficulty in calculating the working hours , and the statutory allowance included in the comprehensive wage falls short of the statutory allowance calculated in accordance with the standards pres cribed by the Labor Standards Act, such shortage will be deemed disadvantage ous to the employee , thus partially invalidat ing such comprehensive wage system. In such case, the employer shall pay the shortage of statutory allowances based on the principle of compulsory application and of subsidiarity of the Labor Standards Act ( Korean Supreme Court 2008 Da 6052 Decision dated May 13, 2010). In principle, the comprehensive wage system is invalid if the comprehensive wage system is adopt ed despite the possible calculation of working hours or lack of manifest difficulty in such calculation. A ccording to the Business Guidance Index on Comprehensive Wage System of the Ministry of Employment and Labor (October, 2017) , however, the comprehensive wage sys tem may be deemed valid if: (i) working hours vary depending on daily weather conditions ; (ii) the length of working hours is determi ned while working outside the workplace; or (iii) it is physically impossi b le or nearly impossible to calculate working hou rs, due to the intermittent nature of work. 2. Possibility of Unpaid Wages in connection with the Comprehensive Wage System over - time, night shift or work over holiday ( Korean Supreme Court Decision 2012 Da 89399, dated December 18, 2013 ) . Th is decision held that the allowance payable upon any full month without absence does not constitute ord inary wages. CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 55 According to the Company, the sales supervisors subject to the comprehensive wage system appear to be working in varying amounts depending on the situation s , and the relevant employees do not work overtime in excess of the fixed working hours included in the comprehensive age system. As suc h, in connection with the Transaction, there do not appear to be any special legal issues to be raised with regards to the validity of the comprehensive wage system or possibility of unpaid or outstanding wages. ◼ Compliance with the Minimum Wage System Und er the current minimum wage law, the minimum wage is KRW 8,720 (Article 8 of the Minimum Wage Act and Notice of Minimum Wage Applicable in 2021). Based on the review of due diligence material s provided , the Company is compl ying with the minimum wage system for all its employees. ◼ Allowance for Un taken Annual Paid Leave According to the Labor Standards Act, an employe r shall notify the number of unused paid leave days for each employee within ten days as of six months prior to the completion of the annual pa id leave period to urge the employee to take annual paid leave . T he relevant employee shall then notify the employer in writing of the time the employee wishes to use the unused paid leave, and if the employee receiving such notice fails to notify the empl oyer of the period of use of all or part of the unused leave within ten (10) days, the employer shall notify the relevant employee, in writing, of the time of use of the unused leave by no later than two months prior to the end of the annual paid leave per iod. If the employer does not comply with the above and the employee’s paid leave has expired because the employee failed to take the paid leave within the applicable time frame , the employer shall be obligated to compensate for the unused paid leave (Arti cle 61 of the Labor Standards Act). Based on the review of due diligence materials provided, the Employment Regulations of the Company include provisions promoting the use of annual paid leave in accordance 8 An employer may designate a specific working day as a day - off in replacement of the annual paid leave, by a written agreement with the representative of employees pursuant to the Article 62 of the Labor Standards Act. with the Labor Standards Act (Article 24 and 25 of the Employment Regulations). According to the Company, the Company has not been urging 8 its employees to use their annual paid leave nor has it designated holidays corresponding to the number of unused annual paid leave . As such, it is possib le that the Company may be liable for the compensation of its employees ’ unused annual leave. ◼ Considerations related to the Transaction In connection to the Transaction : (i) it is advisable to obtain representations and warranties from the Seller to the effect that there are no unpaid wage s or statutory allowance s owed to the Company’s employees, and (ii) it is necessary to implement an annual paid leave promotion system in accordance with the Labor Standards Act and Employment Regulations in the future. The Company’s Claim for Damages Against CHIYONAM CHICKEN Co. According to the Company and the due diligence material s provided, the Company was made aware of CHIYONAM CHICKEN Co. ( C hiyonam ) using similar recipes to those of the Company . O n June 3, 2019 , the Company filed a lawsuit against Chiyo nam seeking KRW 50 million in damages, for an alleged violation of the Unfair Competition Prevention and Trade Secret Protection Act by Chiyonam (Daegu District C ourt , Case Number 2019 KaHap 205354), and filed for an injunction against Chiyonam ’s sales based on disputed recipes . The lawsuit ended by settle ment on April 21, 2020, as both parties consented to the court’s recommend ation for conciliation, and the Company withdrew its application f or the injunction on the same day. 2. Chiyonam ’ s Claim for Damages Against the Company Taking issue with the certification of contents sent by the Company to five C hiyonam fr anchisees in connection with the Company’s lawsuit against Chiyonam, C hiyonam filed a lawsuit claiming d amages for defamation against the Company on May 13, 2020, which is currently in progress in the court of first instance . Initially, C hiyonam claimed KRW 15 million in damages , but reduced the claim to KRW 10 million on May 25, 2021. C hiyonam is maintaining that the Company spr e a d false information among Chiyonam’ s current and potential franchisees, and thereby hinder ed its recruitment and business operation s , as well as the franchisees’ business es . The Company is responding to the above lawsuit with the professional assistance of an attorney . 3. According to th e Company, Daegu Bank’s pledge over the fire insurance claim for F actory 1 was established to secure the loans related to the purchase of F actory 2 in 2020. According to the Company, there is no outstanding insurance premium for the insurances acquired by the Company . 2. Compulsory Insurance Fire Insurance : A building registered as a factory under the Industrial Cluster Development and Factory Establishment Act, with a total floor area of at least 3,000 square meters is deemed to be a special building, and the owner of a special building shall obtain fire insurance (Article 5 ( 1 ) under the Act on the Indemnification for Fire - Caused Loss and the Purchase of Insurance Policies; and Article 2 ( 13 ) of the Enforcement Decree of the Act on the Indemnification for Fire - Caused Loss and the Purchase of Insurance Policies). According to the due di ligence material s provided, the total floor area of each of Factory 1 and Factory 2 does no t exceed 3,000 square meters . As such, the Company is not obligat ed to obtain fire insurance for the said Factories . 9 Nonetheless, the Company meets the said requir ement for fire insu r ance under the Act on the Indemnification for Fire - Caused Loss and the Purchase of Insurance Policies , as the package insurance purchas ed for each F actor y covers the damage by fire. Elevator Insurance : Under the Elevator Facilities Safety Management Act, any one who owns or manages an elevator shall obtain elevator insurance to guarantee compensation for damages related to an elevator accident such as causing damage to a person’s life, body, or property (Artic le 30 ( 1 ) of the Elevator Facilities Safety Management Act; and Article 27 of the Enforcement Decree of the Elevator Facilities Safety Management Act). 9 Total floor area of Factory 1 is 628.49 square meters, and total floor area of Factory 2 is 1019.29 square meters. 10 The relevant insurance certificate has not been provided. According to the Company, there is one elevato r per each Factor y . The Company state d that it has not purc hased elevator insurance for the elevator in Factory 1, but has recently purchased elevator insurance for the elevator in Factory 2 . 10 Under the Elevator Facilities Safety Management Act, an elevator is subject to liability insurance regardless of i t s use. However, a “ lift ” which can load only up to 300 kg and is prohibited from carrying person s is not an elevator under the Elevator Facilities Safety Management Act, but a lift regulated by the Occupational Safety and Health Act ; as a lift is legally disting uished from an elevator, it is not subject to mandatory insurance provision under the Elevator Facilities Safety Management Act . 11 If the elevator in Factory 1 : (i) carries freight with a person on the lift ; or ( ii ) has a load capacity of more than 300 kg, it shall be deemed a freight elevator , the owner of which must acquire insurance under the Elevator Facilities Safety Management Act . As such, the Company may have to acquire insurance for the elevator in Factory 1 depending on its us e and specifications. Vehicle Insurance : Under the Guarantee of Automobile Accident Compensation Act, any motor vehicle owner shall purchase a liability insurance policy or enter into a liability mutual aid agreement which covers the amount that shall be paid to a third party who has died or has been injured due to the operation of a motor vehicle (A rticle 5 ( 1 ) of the Guarantee of Automobile Accident Compensation Act). A motor vehicle owner means any person who has the authority to use a vehicle, and therefore, a liability insurance policy must be purchased for leased vehicles. According to the due di lig ence material s provided, the Company has rented four K5 vehicles through the Shinhan Card Auto Lease program, and since the rental company has comprehensive insurance coverage for its vehicles ( the Company, using the vehicles ) the Company does not have an obligation to acquire insurance under the Guarantee of Automobile Accident Compensation Act. The Company has purchased insurance for the two vehicles owned and two vehicles leased , meeting the requir ements under the Guarantee of Automobile Accident Comp ensation Act. Meanwhile, the two forklifts owned by the Company are not m otor vehicle s under Article 2 ( 1 ) of the Guarantee of Automobile Accident Compensation Act . As such, the Company is not under an obligation to acquire insurance for the above mentioned forklifts. 11 Article 2 ( 5 ) of the Elevator Facilities Safety Management Act; and Table 1 of the Enforcement Decree of the Elevator Facilities Safety Management Act. CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 61 ◼ License and Permits related to the Environment 1. Industrial Complex Tenancy Agreement According to the due diligence materials provided, the Company has entered into a n industrial complex occupancy agreement with the m anagement c orporation for Daegu 3rd Industrial Complex ( Management Corporation ) for Factory 1 ( with total floor area of 568.62 square meters, and building area of 651.07 square meters), the details of the agreement are as follows: Article Details Restriction on Disp osal (Article 2) ① Where an occupant intends to dispose of industrial complex, factories, etc., it owns, it shall d o so pursuant to Article 39 of the Industrial Cluster Development and Factory Establishment Act) ( Development and Establishment Act ). ② Where an occupant intends to lease part of a factory, etc., it shall lease as prescribed in Article 38 - 2 o f the Development and Establishment Act. Occupancy Requirement (Article 3) Qualification for occupancy shall be determined separately for industrial facility and support facility areas. ① Industrial Facility Area - Any institution meeting the requirement pursuant to Article 6 of the Development and Establishment Act that wishes to operate a manufacturing business pursuant to Article 2 of the Act. - Any institution that wishes to use substances pursuant to Article 3 of the Enforcement Regulation of the Wastes Control Act. ② Support Facility Area - Any institution qualifying as a support institution pursuant to Article 2 ( 19 ) of the Development and Establishment Act meeting the tenancy requirement under the Financial Insurance Act and Article 6 of the Enforcement Decree of the same Act to support the business of its tenants. - Any institution moving into a Knowledge Industry Cen ter pursuant to Article 2 ( 13 ) of the Development and Establishment Act. Changes to Tenancy Agreement (Article 4) Where an occupant wishes to change its tenancy agreement agreed upon under Article 35 of the Enforcement Regulation of the Development and Es tablishment Act, a new ly modified agreement must be executed with the management agency. Report on Completion of Establishment of Factory, etc. (Article 5) Where the occupant completes a n establishment of its factory, in other words, from the time the building is approved for use and the installation of machinery and devices is completed, a report on completion of establishment of factor y , etc., shall be made to the management authority wi thin two months. Termination of Occupancy Agreement (Article 6) ① The m anagement authority shall terminate the tenancy agreement if the tenant company falls under any of the following: - Termination, etc., of occupancy agreement pursuant to Article 42 of the Development and Establishment Act . - Violation of occupancy agreement . ② Where an occupancy agreement has been terminated, the occupant shall immediately stop its business except for the operations pursuant to Article 5 6 of the Development and Establishment Act. ③ Where the occupant transfers ownership without performing the disposal procedures under Article 39 of the Development and Establishment Act, the occupancy agreement may be terminated immediately notwithstanding S ection 1 of the Act. Restitution of Industrial Complex (Article 7) Where the occupant uses the industrial facility for purposes other than the purposes under the occupancy agreement , the Management may retrieve the relevant site pursuant to the Article 41 of the Development and Establishment Act upon the payment of price determined as per the Article 39(5) of the same Act . Disposal of Property, etc., after Termination of Tenancy Agreement (Article 8) Where an occupancy agreement has been termin ated, the disposal of the site must be carried out in accordance with Article 43 of the Development and Establishment Act. 6.2 Environment ★★ - In connection with the Transaction, it is advisable to obtain representations and warranties from the Seller to the effect that: (i) the Company has not received any administrative or criminal disposition, such as corrective orders, fines, penalties, warnings, etc., fro m any government agencies for any vio lat ion of environment al laws and regulations; and (ii) no environment - related accident ha s occurred within the areas controlled by the Company . CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 62 Safety Management and Environmental Conservation (Article 11) ① Where the standards of a business, pursuant to Article 1, are prescribed in rel evant statutes, a workplace safety management plan shall be submitted to the management authority pursuant to Article 16 of the Industrial Complex Management Guidelines and also where there are changes to the above terms and conditions. ② Wh ere the occupant installs discharge facilities for air pollutants or wastewater, it shall obtain permission to install discharge facilities and submit a copy of the permit to the management agency . ③ An occupant shall actively cooperate when the management a uthority implements joint projects to improve the environment of an industrial complex or to preserve the environment . Submission of Documents (Article 12) The occupant shall submit the following matters to the management authority along with the relevant documents. - Matters concerning the construction, expansion, completion, relocation , and operation of a factory . - Matters concerning factory operation, such as production, export, employment, etc. - Matters concerning temporary closure or permanent clo sure of a business . - Matters concerning the transfer of tenants . - Matters deemed necessary by the management authority . Relationship with Other Regulations (Article 14) Matters not specified in the a greement shall be governed by the Development and Establishment Act, the Industrial Complex Management Guidelines, other related regulations, and provisions prescribed by the management authority . Additional Agreements (Article 16) In addition to this a greement, the management authority may, if deemed ne cessary for the performance of this a greement by the Company, receive a separate additional agreement as a part of this agreement. Obligations to Pay Operating Expenses (Article 17) ① The occupant shall fulfill the obligation to pay its occupancy contributi on payment and the annual management expenses imposed by the management a gency at the time of entering into the occupancy agreement. ② P rior to the date of notification of the plan for management, the occupancy contribution payment shall be paid by the occupant for the amount in accordance with the standards set by the management authority a fter the date of notification, the occupant shall pay a new occupancy contribution payment equivalent to 0.2% of t he actual transaction price purchased. 2. Reporting Obligations in connection with the Transaction If the Company ’s name , name of the representative, the location of factory, etc. , is changed upon the Transaction, the Company would have to execute a new contract with the management authority (Article 4 of the Industrial Complex Occupancy Agreement ). However, given that the application of Article 35 of the Development and Establishment Act is triggered by the reques t of the company , if the type of change occurred is the name of the representative , it can be interpreted that the change of the name of the representative would not necessarily trigger the application of Article 4 of the Industrial Complex Occupancy Agree ment in the absence of the occupant’s request for the execution of a new contract. Therefore, it appears that the Company would not be obligated to execute a modified contract under the Industrial Complex Occupancy Agreement in connection with or upon the Transaction . According to Article 12 ( 5 ) of the Industrial Complex Occupancy Agreement, the Company shall submit matters deemed necessary by the management authority along with related documents and may be requested to submit related documents for matters subject to change, such as the name of the representative, after the Transaction but no other reporting obligation arises under the same agreement. In connection with the Transaction, it is necessary to obtain representations and warranties from the Selle r to the effect that the Company, has not violated provisions under the Industrial Complex Occupancy Agreement, and that there is no outstanding fee as of the time of the Transaction . ◼ Occupational Safety and Health According to the Occupational Safety and Health Act, an employer of a business who has more than 50 full - time employees for manufactur ing operations shall nominate a person in charge of the safety and health management, and an employer of a business who ha s more than 50, but less than 500, full - time employees for manufacturing operations shall have at least one person in charge of safet y and health management to perform the duties related to occupational safety and health. However, such employer may delegat e such duty to a n agency special izing in safety and health management as designated by the Minister of Employment and Labor (Article 15 and Article 16 of the Occupational Safety and Health Act, and Article s 24 and 26 of the Enforcement Decree of the Occupa tional Safety and Health Act). CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 63 According to the due diligence material s provided, the Company is not a workplace with more than 50 full - time employees and therefore is not under the obligation to nominate a safety and health supervisor under the Occupatio nal Safety and Health Act, however, the head of p roduction of the Company, Ahn Hee - seop, has been designated to perform the role of safety and health supervisor. ◼ Considerations related to the Transaction In connection with the Transaction, it is advisable to obtain representations and warranties from the Seller to the effect that: (i) the Company has not received any administrative or criminal disposition, such as corrective orders, fines, penalties , warnings, etc., from any government agencies f or any violat ion of environment al laws and regulations , and (ii) no environment - related accidents have occurred within the areas controlled by the Company. then the ones that would be in a Cash Flow Statement,
one that includes the description of the company, maximum one paragraph,
one that includes a variable that is the type of company, if it is a company or a fund, 
if the whole business of the company is to invest in other companies then consider it a fund.

Banolim has 2 92 franchised stores (as of Jun - 21) and has headquarter s and 2 factories in Daegu . Banolim ’s current core market is in the southeastern region (which includes Daegu) of Korea and has been expanding the franchis ee system nationwide in recent years. The C ompany currently has no direct stores. The Company utilizes delivery - only model with no in - store dining area (a.k.a. delivery pure - play) . As such, typical store s require relatively small er footage in off - locations that can facilitate kitchen , storage, and waitin g area for delivery man and customer pick - ups. Among the top 5 Korean pizza chains , Banolim exhibits the highest store efficiency where it has the highest average m 2 revenue and the shortest average store payback period making the value proposition strong for franchisees . The Brand is uniquely positioned as the ‘ premium pizza at a reasonable price ’ where average selling price is at KRW 25,000 compared to that of established top 5 players at + KRW 30,000. Banolim is especially popular to 1 0 to 2 0’s age segment and efficiently utilize online delivery apps for orders. The Brand’s marketing is centered on online advertising and mobile - app - utilized promotions and uses brand ambassadors that are popular with young - age c rowd ( K - pop superstar ‘ IU ’ contracted as ambassador from Jan - 21) . Jay Kim has had decade - long professional relationship . ▪ In 2019, OPE ha ve teamed up with FCC to develop deals in the food and beve rage (“F&B”) industry. OPE and FCC identified F&B franchisors through top - down evaluation and developed short - list ed candidates that were fit for OPE SEMM buyout . ▪ In 2020, based on the short - list, FCC connect with Banolim’s owner CEO, Sungwon Yoo . FCC beca me seller’s broker for the deal. ▪ I nitial discussion with Banolim was a ‘partnership deal’ where the seller maintains significant minority and continue running the business. OPE later learned that the seller wa s a ‘serial entrepreneur’ (Banolim was his third start - up) and that he desired to sell the entire shares so to start a new entity in the IT space. Investment Thesis: Why do we want to buy this business? Acquire growing delivery pure - play pizza chain franchisor in Korea that also performed very strongly during COVID . Continue to grow domestically through organic growth by expanding the franchise e system to metropolitan Seoul area and buy - and - build via acquiring franchise stores available for sale and converting them to direct operations. Initiate international growth plan s through entering Singapore market initially and continue expansion to 2 ~ 4 additional Southeast Asian countries. At tain continued support from the departing owner CEO while installing new management team . T riple EBITDA and sell a t qualitatively larger and better company to a strategic buyer looking to enter the F&B space , a financial buyer, or exit via the public marke ts in Korea . Fast g rowing strong brand , at an attractive entry multiple ▪ During the height of COVID, Banolim’s revenue grew at 41 % CAGR from FY19 to Mar - 21 LTM. This is a significant growth if considered the GDP decrease of Korea at - 0.9 % in the same duration (source: IMF). ▪ The Company’s E BITDA growth was even more spectacular at 76% CAGR from FY19 to Mar - 21 LTM (Note: The Company fiscal year ends in December) . ▪ The Company is a fast - growing brand, that has increased its numbers of stores, average store revenue, and company revenue at a very strong pace . - Not only numbers of stores are increasing at 10.5% CAGR from FY 18 to Mar - 21 LTM , but also average store revenue is increasing at 15.1 % CAGR from FY 18 to Mar - 21 LTM . - T he Company also has healthy recurring revenue (which excludes initial franchise fees and other one - item revenue ) . Between FY18 to FY20, recurring revenue was at majority portion of the Company’s total revenue at average 87% . ‘ B anolim Pizza Shop’ Performance FY 18 FY 19 FY 20 Mar - 21 LTM CAGR ( FY18 to Mar - 21 LTM ) Number of Banolim S tores 219 231 261 274 10.5% T otal Chain Revenue K RW 81.3B K RW 93.1B K RW 129.4B K RW 139.7B 27.2 % Average Store Revenue KRW 371M KRW 403M KRW 496M KRW 510M 15.1 % Banolim Total Revenue K RW 9.2B K RW 11.0B K RW 15.2B K RW 16.9B 2 2.5% Recurring Revenue K RW 7.6B K RW 9.9B K RW 13.3B K RW 14.8B 34.0 % Non - recurring Revenue K RW 1.6B K RW 1.0B K RW 1.9B K RW 2.1 B 13.3 % S ource: Deloitte ▪ The deal presents an opportunity to acquire a growing delivery pure - play pizza chain franchisor in Korea at comparably attractive 5.9 x TEV/EBITDA multiple (based on Aug - 21 closing LTM) . ▪ C omparable TEV/EBITDA average (numeric) transaction comp is at 11.0x (from 8 controlled buyout transactions of F&B franchisor s in 2019 and 2020). - TEV/EBITDA transaction comp of chicken franchisors (which closely resembles pizza franchisors) were almost all double digit TEV/EBITDA multiples. This is due to lower initial franchise fee Banolim charges to franchisors (Banolim KRW 40M versus Domino’s KRW 330M) and Banolim’s flexibility to construct smaller - footage stores . ▪ B ased on superior store economics and relatively underpenetrated metropolitan Seoul region, Banolim is expected to increase the number of stores further significantly . - Banolim considers southeaster n region (which includes Daegu where the Company’s headquarters and 2 factories are located ) as the core market and has been expanding franchising network nationwide in recent years . In the next 5 years, management plans to expand franchise stores to 420 , adding 30 new stores per annum . ✓ Simply b enchmark ing to Domino’s statistics , Banolim will be able to add + 100 stores in heavily populated metropolitan Seoul. ✓ U pdate on Jun - 21: On YTD bases (Jan - 21 to Jun - 2 1), Banolim has add ed 30 stores and already achieved FY2021 management plan. T he total number of stores is at 292 stores ( as of Jun - 21) . - Considering superior store economics (exhibiting the industry’s shortest average store payback period) and considering smaller capital hurdle to set up its stores, Banolim has been very popular with prospective franchisees.
