CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 5 ▪ The Company had only 3 store closures in 2018 and 2019, from the current total of 292 (as of Jun - 21) , or at 1% closure rate . The management commented that the closure was due to ill - located store sites and thus failure to place new owners when incumbent ow ners decided to dispose. Of the noted 3 territories, 2 are now occupied with new franchisees with stores at better location. Add - on acquisition of attractive franchise stores ▪ One of the advantages of being a franchisor is the opportunity to ‘cherry pick’ healthy franchise stores for sale and convert ing them to direct store s . T he upside of this inorganic growth strategy is to ‘ roll - up ’ sizeable number of franchise stores at chea p TEV/EBITDA entry multiple and attain ‘multiple arbitrage’ by exit ing the portfolio at higher multiple . - For the acquired stores to sustain store performance , heavier management resource and intense shareholder oversight will be required. - C ash use for store acquisitions will also be dependent on LBO loan repayment schedule (note: OPE is in discussion to secure LBO loan at KRW 20B (senior) and KRW 2B (revolver) from Kiwoom Securities ) . ▪ Orchestra strategy is to pace the acquisition of franchise stores to 5 per annum during the investment period . - Based on B anolim’s franchising contract, Banolim headquarters has the veto rights to franchise ownership transfers. As such, franchise es that intend to sell their stores are obligated to report to the HQ and attain approval of the ownership transfer . Such begin the case, Banolim has structural advantage in identifying and acquiring attractive franchise stores on sale . - Between 2018 to 2020, Banolim had annually 15 to 20 franchise store ownership transfer s (changing hands from the incumbent owner to the buyer) . The average price of stores sales was at KRW 80 ,000,000 . - Considering that OPE will acquire grade - A stores that are price at KRW 100,000,000, entry multiple per store is at about 1x TEV/EBITDA. If assuming acqui sition of 5 stores per annum for 5 years, the Company will have total of 25 direct stores where they will in aggregate generat e net running EBITDA of KRW 3 .1B. ✓ [ Calculation: Net running EBITDA of KRW 3.1B = Total store EBITDA at KRW 4.1B – Decrease HQ EBTIDA from lost royalty & product margin revenue at KRW 1.0B ] Banolim Franchise System Performance Number of S tores FY18 FY19 FY20 Beginning 196 219 231 Open 25 13 30 Close (2) (1) 0 Net 23 12 30 Ending 219 231 261 Average Store Annual Revenue KRW 81.3B KRW 93.1B KRW 129.4B A verage S ales per S tore (“ASPS”) per day KRW 1.3M KRW 1.4M KRW 1.7M S ource: Deloitte Outsized returns possible with i nternational growth, in Southeast Asia ▪ Strong returns can be generated in just the domestic opportunity, but an outsized return is possible by successfully penetrating the overseas markets. Banolim currently does not have presence in the overseas market. ▪ B anolim has the potential to expand business o verseas, particularly to Singapore and other parts of Southeast Asia including Malaysia, Indonesia, and Vietnam . Korean F&B brands have had successful track record in the noted countries due to the general population’s favorable acceptance of established, popular Korean retail brands . Initiate international growth plan s through entering Singapore market initially and continue expansion to 2~4 additional Southeast Asian countries. - A strategic approach to global expansion where first attempting to fully penetrate one target countries is deemed effective. OPE believes Singapore market to be the appropriate ‘ test bed ’ before regional deployment of the franchise concept. OPE Singapore Office’s Ivica Turza can be the operator for such effort. - After ‘tweaking the business model’, OPE can explore master franchise arrangement with local partners in other Southeast Asia countrie s. V alue C reation : Must win battles Build professional management team , from the current self - proprietorship set - up ▪ B anolim’s owner CEO, Sungwon Yoon, has agreed to serve as Chairman after acquisition under 1 - year part - time executive service contract. Yoon will allocate up to 20% of time managing Banolim and administer smooth ownership transfer ( Yoon to additionally sign 5 - year non - competition and 2 - year non - solicitation ). CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 6 - Yoon (age 4 3 ) is A - grade talent that started up the business with sheer will to succeed. He is a motivated entrepreneur and has stellar work ethics. The CEO has good kudos in operation and marketing and has significant knowhow in menu development. All in all, he has single - handedly grown the company to become #4 pizza chain in Korea. ▪ T wo incumbent executes of the Company, COO Seunghwan Shin and General Manager Yeunggyun Yoon , will remain with the company as full - time members . ▪ OPE will additionally recruit CFO to further enhance the management team . - CFO : Strategic - minded CFO that can lead finance, tax, legal (franchise contracts and negotiations ), HR, IT (MIS implementation and mobile app improvement), etc. - 2 SG&A employees to be additionally hired to facilitate CEO and CFO. ▪ Sid Kim, President of ‘Vatos Urban Tacos’ of Singapore , has agreed to serve as Banolim Singapore Country Manager on part - time bases . - Bilingual Korean American that has been residing in Singapore for 6 years, operating one of the most successful Korean F&B br ands in Singapore and the Philippines ( total of 6 establishments) . Kim is well known entrepreneur in Singapore and has experience in concept development, menu development, new outlet execution, and local sourcing. Attained BA from UC Berkeley and PhD from UC San Diego . Move headquarters to Seoul , and expand franchise coverage ▪ Metropolitan Seoul is critical for Banolim’s franchise expansion. - The seller agreed to relocate headquarters to Seoul and converted Daegu HQ to a regional office to manage franchisees in the southern regio ns and manage 2 factories. - Additional talents and consultants in franchise sales, marketing, IT, and international sales can be better sou ght out with HQ in Seoul . Margin improvement through operational efficiency ▪ The Company can further increase efficiency in l ogis tics. - B anolim outsources all its logistics to a Daegu - local 3PL called Jungsung Food Co., Ltd. (“Jungsung Foods ”). The business is driven through legacy relationship with the owner CEO Yoon . M ajority of revenue of Jungsung Foods is with Banolim. - Deloitte identified that Jungsung Foods charges Banolim higher cost at 2.4% EBIT margi n than that of peer group average at 1.9% EBIT margin. OPE to continue using Jungsung Foods as logistics provider only if charge is lowered to 1.9% EBIT margin . ▪ The Company can further increase efficiency in production. - F actory 1 and Factory 2 are in Daegu and manufacturers key ingredients including dough, tomato paste, garlic sauce, and sweet potato mousse. - Accord ing to Deloitte, Banolim is currently at 30% utilization rate is assuming 2 - shifts scheme ( total of 16 hours per day operation ) at the current 274 franchise system . Under 100% utilization rate, factories can theoretically serve up to 900 franchise system . OPE to install 2 nd shift (night - time) when franchise system eventually expands to 4 0 0 stores. ▪ The Company can further increase efficiency through implementing management information system (“MIS”). - OPE to overhaul ERP system and set to invest up t o KRW 0.5B to support effective management utilizing data - driven decisions . Also, install analytic tools that can help improve logistics, customer relations, and supplier management . Risk Mitigation: What keeps us up at night? Departing CEO ▪ B anolim’s owner CEO, Sungwon Yoon , has maintained amicable professional relationship with all Banolim franchisees. After acquisition, it is critical to continue maintaining good relationship with the franchisees. R isk Mitigation: - Yoon has agreed to stay on as Chairman after acquisition under 1 - year part - time executive contract. Yoon will allocate up to 20% of time managing Banolim and administer smooth ownership transfer. Yoon to make extra effort to stabilize franchisee relationsh ip post - acquisition. N ew entrants in the segment ▪ B anolim’s business model can be copied by other entrants. Still much smaller than Banolim, few local copy - cats have started delivery - pure play pizza chain operations since 2018. R isk Mitigation: - OPE to sustain Banolim m arketing budget at historical 17~19 % of revenue , where the Company continuously invest in marketing to further increase brand equity . ✓ The Brand’s current marketing campaign with K - pop superstar ‘IU’ is deemed hugely successful. T he Company has contracted ‘IU’ as brand ambassador from Jan - 21 to Dec - 22, for two - year term. ✓ Considering that Banolim ’s core customer group at 1 0’s and 2 0’s , the Company to continue hiring celebrities that is popular with younger age group as brand spokesperson. Utilize BTL (“below the line”) online advertisement in key platforms (social network platforms, delivery app platforms, etc.). - M enu development to continuously cater to demands and trends of 1 0’s and 2 0’s age group . Also, develop menu to diversify into hi gher age groups as the Brand is becoming CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 7 more mainstream. ✓ OPE to consistently monitor customer opinion through customer survey and focus group interviews. OPE to also hire employees and external consultants to develop menu to consistently rejuvenate the Brand’s offering . E xit Strategy ▪ Over the next 4 to 6 years, OPE intend s to grow the Banolim brand domestically and acquire and convert target 25 franchise stores to direct stores. OPE will manage Banolim to expand in Southeast Asia and continue to fuel the growth of the business and leave significant opportunity for growth on the table for the next owner of the busines s. ▪ OPE can make this business a qualitatively better one during the investment period , achieve significant domestic - based organic growth, diversify revenue streams to direct stores and new geographies, and double EBITDA from KRW 8.1B to KRW 15.7B in 5 year s . ▪ Exit opportunities include sale to a financial buyer, sale to an international strategic player looking to enter or expand in the Asian market, or a public offering of shares on the Korean stock exchange. COMPANY OVERVIEW Products ‘P remium pizza at a reasonable price ’, with products popular to 20’s and 30’s ▪ Banolim’s best - selling products are ‘ Sweet Potato Gold Crust Pizza ’ (#2), and ‘ Cheese Fries Cream Cheese Pizza ’ (#3), and ‘ Hot Chicken Shrimp Gold Crust Pizza ’ (#4) . The #1 product is cal led ‘ Four - ten Pizza ’ which is four - pizza - in - one product with 1/4 each of best - sellers. - B anolim’s product characteristics is ‘heavy topping’. Compared to US pizza chains, Banolim products are literally much heavier due to large number of toppings on the product . Also, pizza crust is with heavy favor s and with various options (cheese ring crust, sweet potato mousse crust, ‘soboro bread’ crust, etc.). This is quite different than classic - the me central product offerings ( i.e., ‘ pepperoni and mushroom pizza ’ ) which is typical of American pizza chains (i.e., Domino’s , Pizza Hut ) . - Many of the best - selling products have sweet potato mousse and garlic sauce as key ingredients , which are produced e xclusively at the Company’s factories. ▪ The company’s pizza menu is catered to younger consumer’s taste and trend, where large assortment of toppings is utilized to present unique theme - based products . This determines consumer perception of Banolim being ‘premium’. ▪ Av erage MSRP of large size Banolim pizza is at KRW 25,000 . Other players offer large size pizza at MSRP at KRW + 30,000. At ‘reasonable price’ and by offering theme - driven pizza offerings with many toppings , Banolim is very popular to 20 ’s and 30’s age segment s . Banolim Best - sellers Product Four - ten Pizza (#1) Sweet Potato Gold Crust Pizza (#2) Cheese Fries Cream Cheese Pizza (#3) Image Attributes #1 product , which is four - pizza - in - one product with 1/4 each of Banolim’s best - sellers. Toppings : Sweet potato mousse, bread crust, cheese, fries cream cheese, hot chicken shrimp, bulgogi, and garlic. #2 product . S weet potato mousse is produced internally . Toppings : Sweet potato mousse, bacon, bread crust, corn, and olives. M ain toppings are two types of cheese mixed with garlic potato and bacon. Toppings : Sweet potato mousse, bread crust, cheese, fries, cream cheese, garlic, and olives. MSRP (Large Size) KRW 23,900 KRW 21,900 KRW 22,900 Customers Core customers at age group 20’s and 30’s ▪ Banolim’s core customer base are younger generation Koreans in their 20’s and 30’s. The Brand is also popular to teens. Typical of this younger age group is that the group is well exposed to (PC and mobile phone based) online platforms ( Youtube, Kakao, Facebook, Instagram , etc.) and online delivery apps (Baemin, Yogiyo, Coupang Eats, etc.). - Younger age group ( often termed as ‘m illennials ’) are at 17 million which makes up about 1/3 of Korea’s population. - In 2020, Banolim won first place in brand recognition among teens for pizza chains ( awarded by Korean Marketing Association). ▪ Younger age group are heavy consumers of pizza products and are typically price sensitive as many have sin gle - person - household status , or dependent on parents as many are to start CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 8 their social independence . To this age group, Banolim is considered as a reasonably priced option compared to other larger pizza establish ments . ▪ Core market in southeastern region , now going nation - wide ▪ Banolim considers southeastern region as the core market (2/3 of the current 292 stores are in this region) , which includes major cities Daegu, Busan, and Ulsan, where the region is at a total of 15 million inhabi tants. The Brand is very popular in the region as it was the base where the Company started the business. ▪ With strong base in southeastern region, Banolim is now expanding franchising network nationwide. Marketing Savvy marketing of Banolim brand identity ▪ Banolim has strategically used well - known brand ambassadors to popularize the B rand as ‘ young and cool ’ . - Since its first use of a brand ambassador in 201 8 (comedian and celebrity, Nare Park) , the Brand gained wide - recognition and popularity among younger customer groups. - From Jan - 21, Banolim signed up with K - pop superstar and self - proclaimed Pizza aficionado ‘IU’ to represent the brand. The collaboration was well received among younger age group and contributed to acerat ing total chain sales in Q1 and Q1 2021 . ▪ T he company reestablished brand identity and renewed its logo and corporate colors to look ‘young and cool’ (bright yellow , blue , etc.) . Marketing spen ding at 17~ 19% ▪ T he Company spends 17~19% of revenue on marketing, at KRW 2.8B in FY2019 and KRW 2.4B in 2020, utilizing TV commercials, social network advertisements , press release, collaboration with celebrity models , etc. ▪ The Company’s vigor in marketing makes copy - cat players h ard to catch up, where difficult to match the absolute amount of marketing spending to that of Banolim ’s . D elivery Mobile App Channel Mobile delivery apps as main channel ▪ In Korea, mobile app based online shopping reached KRW 5.4T size in Q4 2020 ( 3 - month figure ). Per below graph entitled “mobile app based online shopping in Korea”, the market tripled when compared to Q1 2019 . The primary driver of the drastic increase was due to general acceptance and popularity of the online shopping platforms and COVID - induced delivery demand for food, grocery goods, and general consumables. ▪ According to Ministry of the Interior and Safety , age group 20’s and 30’s use delivery mobile apps extensively when compared to age group 50’s and 60’s. Younger age group typically use mobile apps (at almost 85~ 90% of time) when ordering pizza. ▪ According to Banolim management, the Company receives 90% of orders through mobile apps with only 10% of orders through call center. - Banolim’s core customer group is younger age group and is reflective of the general statistics . - The Brand ’s growth was part contributed to the increased usage of mobile app - based food delivery platforms. O nline collaboration with delivery apps ▪ Banolim, as one of the early collaborators with mobile delivery app companies, has constantly maintained key customer relationship with Baemin and Yogiyo. T he Company has launched many successful collaborations to keep the online exposure high, including s pot promotions like ‘buy one get one free’, ‘free drinks’, and ‘free side dish’. CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 9 S ource: Statistics Korea, Korea Agro - Fisheries & Food Trade Corporation, Ministry of the Interior and Safety (Survey: n=2,000, Oct - 20, online survey in 16 largest cities in Korea) I ndustry and Top Players Korea pizza franchise industry at KRW 4 .0 T ▪ According to LEK Consulting CDD report, the industry is at KRW 2 .0T in 2019, where pizza franchise market has been expanding at 4.7% CAGR (2015 - 2019). ▪ C OVID - induced 2020 has proven to be a good growth year for the industry. LEK Consulting projects the industry growth rate to sustain at 4.7% CAGR from 2019 to 2025F . - Pizza franchise industry forecasted growth (2019 - 2025F) will be primarily driven by volume growth from (1) increased volume per store and (2) increased number of franchise stores. Below please note excerpts of CDD report. Pizza Franchise Industry S ource: LEK Consulting Market players employee distinguished strategies ▪ According to LEK Consulting, pizza franchis ors employee strategies based on (1) origin of the brand (i.e., US versus Korean), (2) core business model( i.e., delivery versus in - dining), (3) product concept, (4) product menu, (5) price range, and (6) core customers. ▪ Two distinguished groupings lead the market. - US pizza chain group (Domino’s, Pizza Hut, Papa John’s) with “ American style pizza with emphas is on cheese and tomato sauce theme” and target general mass market. - Local IP - owned Korean chains, including Banolim, with “Korean - style pizza with rich amounts of diverse toppings theme” at generally at lower price. In terms of franchise system, Korean ch ains have lower initial franchise fees with flexibility in smaller store footage which makes it more attractive to prospective franchisees Top P izza Chain Players in Korea O rigin US master franchise US master franchise US master franchise O wn - IP O wn - IP O wn - IP Core B usiness Model I n - dining Delivery pure play Delivery pure play I n - dining Delivery pure play I n - dining Product C oncept “Family dine - out, premium” “30 - minute delivery, premium” “American style premium delivery” “Family dine - out, localized” “Abundant toppings, great value ” “Healthy, fresh ingredients” Product Menu U S style topping - based pizza U S style topping - based pizza U S style topping - based pizza Korea style theme - based pizza Korea style theme - based pizza Korea style theme - based pizza Large size price range KRW 14,900 ~ 35,900 KRW 21,900 ~ 39,900 KRW 25,900 ~ 35,900 KRW 22,900 ~ 36,500 KRW 16,900 ~ 27,900 KRW 19,000 ~ 31,000 C ore Customers Family in - dining G eneral General F amily in - dining A ge group 20’s and 30’s G eneral CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 10 F ranchising System Franchise royalty and product margins ▪ The Company’s core competencies are developing a brand, system, and infrastructure to support growth through the franchise model. In terms of initial fees, Banolim charges franchisees upfront fees at KRW 10,000, 000 , ‘education’ fees at KRW 2,000,000, and r equire purchasing from HQ ‘opening items’ totaling at KRW 18,000,000 which includes kitchen hardware including oven and refrigerator, uniform, etc. In terms of running r oyalty fee, it is fixed at KRW 15 0,000 per month. - Direct product margins : About 60% of revenue is driven from ‘direct product margins ’ on Banolim - manufactured - products (made in the Company’s 2 factories in Daegu) which include dough, tomato paste, garlic sauce, and sweet potato mousse. - Indirect product margins : About 25% of total rev enue (or 36% franchise revenue per noted in below illustration ) is driven from ‘indirect product margins’ on all other products which is outsourced to Jungsung Foods suppl ied to the franchise system. Those other products include cheese, mayonnaise, pepperoni and other meat products, various vegetables including pickles , pizza boxes and bags, etc . - Royalty fee : About 5% of revenue is from royalty fees, where the rate is in - line with market practices of the general Korean F&B franchisors’ franchising practices. Banolim Franchise System (Note: Below data will be updated in English) S ource: LEK Consulting Franchise selection process by the Company ▪ Banolim’s owner CEO, Yoon, has a distinguished philosophy when screening and selecting franchisees for Banolim franchise system: Age limit of 45. In fact, over 90% of franchisees are owned by individuals in their 30’s and 40’s. - The Company has a favorable bias toward younger f ranchise owners given that Banolim core customer segment is younger age group at 20’s and 30’s . Matching franchise owner profile to that of core customer group aligns service expectation, online mobile app savviness, etc. - From experience, Y oon well recognize that operating franchise stores is a very hard labor with long work hours. When making franc hisee selection, Yoon places value on work ethics and vigor to succeed. For that reason, the Company has had bias toward favoring younger store owners that are ‘enthusiastic and energetic’ than on senior retirees considering next phase of life. Franchise s upport provided to new franchisees ▪ One of the Company’s strengths is the platform to drive growth and the ability to provide support for its franchisee network to ensure the operational success of the franchisees. The areas of support include: - Real Estate Site Selection : Good store location is one of the key factors in determining a store’s operating performance. The Company takes a rigorous analytical approach to site selection, evaluating a range of factors in determining appropriate sites, area demograph ics, average rents, and other factors that drive performance. - Store Design and Construction : The Company assists franchisees with store design, layout, and construction. The Company also provid e support for negotiating with landlords. - Training : I n - store training for new franchisees is provided. This is bolstered through regular training updates both in - store and online through Youtube . - IT Infrastructure and POS System : The POS systems allow franchisees to track their CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 11 own performance, as well as be nchmark their operations against the entire Company network of stores. Grade - C store management ▪ The company manages score card of each franchisees based on frequent violation of franchise polices (more than 2 violation per annum is considered grade - C ) . Ban olim actively manage franchisees at grade - C to either improve scores or to sell the store, strictly based on professionalism abiding to contractual agreement. Of the current 2 92 stores, there are 10 stores that are grade - C (as of Jun - 21) . - Score cards are assessed in four key areas : (1) general store operations (i.e., opening hours, store cleanliness , service - mindedness, etc. ) , (2) store profitability, (3) product quality concerns . - The Company has 5 supervisors (full - time employees) that provide solutions and advice to support the grade - C franchise operator. ▪ If grade - C store shows lack of improvement, HQ typically will terminate franchise contract at cause, or simply not extent the renewal which is due every 2 - years. IT Systems, including in - house mobile app ▪ The in - house delivery app was launched Google Play Store and Apple App Store in September 2020 (free download) . To date, 150,000 downloads of in - house apps were made. ▪ The Company does not have extensive management information system. Banolim relies on 3 rd party web - based ERP and point - of - sales (“POS”) system. TRANSACTION UPDATE Transaction Transaction and Financing Update We are seeking final approval to acquire 100% of the common stock of Banolim Pizza Shop Co., Ltd. (“Banolim”, or the “Company”) for KRW 55B. O n Aug - 21 closing LTM bases, at the noted purchase price of KRW 55B and at Normalized EBITDA of KRW 8.3 B , TEV/EBITDA multiple is at 5.9 x . We expect the transaction to close in Aug - 21 . We expect the transaction to require up to KRW 35B of equity and KRW 20B of debt (senior) . Kiwoom Securities will be the loan provider for the acquisition. Kiwoom Securities is one of the largest financing company in Korea and they are eager to finance the acquisition. W e have reached consensus on the key commercial terms of the financing per below . ▪ Key financing terms from Kiwoom Securit ies : - Tranche A (Term Loan ): KRW 20B with interest rate at fixed 5.0% - Trance B (Senior Revolving Credit Facility ): KRW 2B with interest rate at fixed 5.0% - Term: 3 years - U pfront Fee: 1.5% - Net debt/EBITDA Covenant: 2021 exempted; 2022 [4.25]x; 2023 [4.0]x Financial Summary based on Deloitte FDD Report P&L Summar y based on Deloitte FDD Report (FY2018 – Mar - 21 LTM) ▪ P&L Summary is a consolidated PL which includes financials of D aegu HQ and financials of Suwon Branch (metropolitan Seoul sales office) . Based on R evenue, D aegu HQ is at 88.7% of FY2020 revenue and Suwon Branch at 11.4% of FY2020 revenue . ▪ Financial reporting - Banolim prepares its financial statements in accordance with K - GAAP. Consolidated financial statements prepared by Deloitte. - Due to small size, e xternal audit requirement is relieved. - Banolim SG&A has 4 employees in General Affairs Department and the unit’s role includes HR function , franchise m anagement function , and f inance & a ccounting . function . Also, the Company’s factories have additional SG&A at 3 employees. ▪ Revenue - Increased at 28.4% CAGR between FY2018 to FY 2020. Target’s sales consist of finished goods sales, merchandise sales, franchise fees , and rental income . - Sales - Finished Goods : Finished goods sales consist of sales of dough, garlic sauce, tomato sauce and sweet potato mousse manufactured by HQ and supp lied to franchise stores through Jungsung Food. Finished goods sales increased by approximately KRW 3.6B from FY 20 18 to FY 20 20 due to KRW 48.1B increase in sales by franchises from KRW 81.3B in FY 20 18 to KRW 129.4B in FY 20 20. - Sales - Merchandise : Consist of sales from selling merchandises such as kitchen equipment/supplies, uniforms, and pizza boxes for newly opened stores. - Franchise Fees : Consist of logistics margin recognized through Junsung Food (KRW 4.2B), franchisee opening fee revenues and training fees (KRW 739M) and advertising fees for new/vintage stores (KRW 463M) as of FY2020. Franchise fee revenue growth is mainly driven by an increase in logistics margin which increased by approximately KRW 2 .0 B in FY 20 18 to FY20 20 due to the increase in sales by franchises. - Rental income (normalized in the analysis ) : Recognized from rental of non - core real estate building. Real estate building investment, located in Suseong - gu, Daegu South Korea, has been reflected as cash - like items of net debt since real estate is expected to be CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 12 sold in Jul - 21 at KRW 4.7B. Rental income will not be incurred once it is sold and has been deducted from sales as pa rt of normalization items. ▪ Gross Profit - Increased by KRW 4.4B from FY 20 18 to FY20 20 at CAGR 31.8%. As finished goods sales and purchase volume increased, it led to a decrease in average purchase price (APP) of raw materials resulting in KRW 2.1B increase in finished goods sales margin. Gross margin of finished goods sales showed increasing trends from 46.0 % in FY 20 18 to 50.5% in FY 20 20. Considering finished good sales along with logistics margin and franchise fees, the Company’s gross margin in FY 20 20 was 68.3%. Gross margin continues to trend upward as the Company gains leverage through high purchase volum e and through product sales increase. ▪ SG&A - As of FY 20 20, SG&A expenses consist of advertising expenses (KRW 2.4B), sales promotion costs (KRW 0. 6 B), and personnel expenses (KRW 0. 4 B). Through aggressive marketing with Korean celebrities (for instance ‘IU’) , TV/radio commercials, and SNS in FY2019, the Company’s SG&A increased from KRW 2.1B in FY2018 to KRW 4.4B in FY2019, resulting in 16~17% increase in SG&A as % of revenue. Sales promotion costs increased beginning Nov - 19 as the HQ issued discount coupons through delivery apps to promote sales. OPE F UND IV B ANOLIM P IZZA U PDATE M EMO RANDUM O RCHESTRA P RIVATE E QUITY A PRIL 20 2 4 CONFIDENTIAL Orchestra Private Equity Singapore 3 5 FL The Gateway West 150 Beach Road 189720 Singapore + 65 .6 727 . 4920 Orchestra Private Equity Japan 3FL Sanno Park Tower 2 - 11 - 1 Nagatacho Chiyoda - ku Tokyo 100 - 6162 Japan +81.3.6205. 33 00 Orchestra Private Equity Korea 21FL Seoul Finance Center 136 Sejongdaero Junggu Seoul 04520 Korea +82.2.3782.4520 www.orchestraprivateequity.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com Banolim Pizza – UNREALIZED Platform Investment Company d escription Banolim Pizza (the “Company”), established in 2011, is the 3rd largest pizza chain in Korea (based on total chain revenue). Banolim has 375 franchised stores and has headquarters and 2 factories in Daegu. The management team moved HQ function to Seoul in 2022 . Banolim’s current core market is in the southeastern region (which includes Daegu) of Korea and has been expanding the franchisee system in metropolitan Seoul in recent years. The Company currently has 5 directly owned stores. The Company utilizes delivery - only model with no in - store dining area (a.k.a. delivery pure - play). As such, typical stores require relatively smaller footage in off - locations that can facilitate kitchen, storage, and waiting area for deliveryman and custom er pick - ups. Among the top 5 Korean pizza chains, Banolim exhibits one of the highest store efficiencies where it has the highest average m 2 revenue . Banolim exhibits the shortest average store payback period making the value proposition strong for franchi sees. The Brand is uniquely positioned as the ‘ Korean - style premium pizza at a reasonable price’ where average selling price is at KRW 25,000 compared to that of established top 5 players at +KRW 30,000. Banolim is especially popular to 1 0 to 2 0’s age segment and efficiently utilize online delivery apps for orders. The Brand’s marketing is centered on online advertising and mobile - app - utilized promotions and uses brand ambassadors that are popular with young - age crowd ( i.e., K - pop superstar ‘IU’ and ‘ Jiko ’ contracted as brand ambassador). Location HQ and #1 #2 factory in Daegu K orea (Note: HQ function in Seoul ) Ownership acquired 100 % (Seller: S u ngwon Yoon ) Business Delivery pizza franchisor. Also, pizza ingredient manufacturer and logistics supplier Invested capital KRW 35 . 5 B Industry s ector Food & beverage franchis ing Entry TEV/EBITDA multiple 7 . 4 x Transaction t ype Leveraged buyout Exit TEV/EBITDA multiple Not yet exited Entry date | Exit date Nov - 21 | Not yet exited R eference TEV/EBITDA multiple 13.2 x Trading Comps 1 1 . 7 x T ransaction Comps ( based on 3 rd party v aluation r eport by Nexia International on Apr - 24 ) Holding p eriod 2 years 5 months , on Apr - 24 Unrealized value 2 . 2 x Gross MOIC as of Dec - 23 (based on 3rd party valuation report by Nexia International on Apr - 24) RECAP OF ENTRY MEMO, DATED SEP - 21 Sourcing & transaction ( Recap from Entry Memo dated Sep - 21 ) Proprietary, private deal, through top - down thesis - driven approach o The deal was introduced by a franchising consulting firm, FC Changup Co., Ltd., (“FCC”) through a top - down thesis - driven approach. Jay Kim has had decade - long professional relationship. o In 2019, OPE have teamed up with FCC to develop deals in the food and beverage (“F&B”) industry. OPE and FCC identified F&B franchisors through top - down evaluation and developed short - listed candidates that were fit for OPE SEMM buyout. o In 2020, based on the short - list, FCC connect with Banolim’s owner CEO, Sungwon Yoo. FCC became seller’s broker for the deal. o I nitial discussion with Banolim was a ‘partnership deal’ where the seller maintains significant minority and continue running the business. OPE later learned that the seller was a ‘serial entrepreneur’ (Banolim was his third start - up) and that he desired to sell the entire shares so to start a new entity in non - competi ng segment . Why do we want to buy this business ? ( Recap from Entry Memo dated Sep - 21) Acquire growing delivery pure - play pizza chain franchisor in Korea that also performed very strongly during COVID. Continue to grow domestically through organic growth by expanding the franchisee system to metropolitan Seoul area and acquiring best - performing franchise stores available for sale and converting them to direct operations. Attain continued support from the departing owner CEO while installing new management team and relocating HQ functions to Seoul. Fast growing strong brand, at an attractive entry multiple o During the height of COVID, Banolim’s revenue grew at 41% CAGR from FY19 to Mar - 21 LTM. This is a significant growth if considered the GDP decrease of Korea at - 0.9% in the same duration (source: IMF). o The Company’s E BITDA growth was even more spectacular at 76% CAGR from FY19 to Mar - 21 LTM (Note: The Company fiscal year ends in December). o The deal presents an opportunity to acquire a growing delivery pure - play pizza chain franchisor in Korea at comparably attractive 7.4 x TEV/EBITDA multiple (based on Sep - 21 closing LTM). o C omparable TEV/EBITDA average (numeric) transaction comp is at 11.0x from 8 controlled buyout transactions of F&B franchisors in 2019 and 2020. CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com CONFIDENTIAL Fabrice Fabrice seinecap.com 3 Superior delivery pure - play model, which the Company exhibits the highest store efficiency, which in turn will benefit Banolim to increase the number of stores o ‘Banolim Pizza’ brand is one of the largest players based on chain store revenue in Korea pizza franchise industry. o Among the top 5 players, Banolim exhibits the highest store efficiency based on average store m 2 revenue and average store payback period. o B ased on superior store economics and relatively underpenetrated metropolitan Seoul region, Banolim is expected to increase the number of stores further significantly. o Banolim average store revenue and average sales per store (“ASP”) per day has also been performing strongly. Add - on acquisition of attractive franchise stores o One of the advantages of being a franchisor is the opportunity to ‘cherry pick’ healthy franchise stores for sale and converting them to direct stores. The upside of this inorganic growth strategy is to ‘roll - up’ sizeable number of franchise stores at cheap TEV/EBITDA entry multiple and attain ‘multiple ar bitrage’ by exiting the portfolio at higher multiple. Value Creation: Must win battles ( Recap from Entry Memo dated Sep - 21 ) Build professional management team, from the current self - proprietorship set - up o Banolim’s owner CEO, Sungwon Yoon, has agreed to serve as Chairman after acquisition under 1 - year part - time executive service contract. Yoon will allocate up to 20% of time managing Banolim and administer smooth ownership transfer (Yoon to additionally sign 5 - year non - competition and 2 - year non - solicitation). Move headquarters to Seoul, and expand franchise coverage o Metropolitan Seoul is critical for Banolim’s franchise expansion. Margin improvement through operational efficiency o The Company can further increase efficiency in l ogis tics. o The Company can further increase efficiency in production. o The Company can further increase efficiency through implementing management information system (“MIS”). OPE to overhaul ERP system and set to invest up to KRW 0.5B to support effective management utilizing data - driven decisions . Also, install analytic tools that can help improve logistics, customer relations, and supplier management . Risk Mitigation: What keeps us up at night? ( Recap from Entry Memo dated Sep - 21 ) Departing CEO o Banolim’s owner CEO, Sungwon Yoon, has maintained amicable professional relationship with all Banolim franchisees. After acquisition, it is critical to continue maintaining good relationship with the franchisees. New entrants in the segment o B anolim’s business model can be copied by other entrants. Still much smaller than Banolim, few local copy - cats have started delivery - pure play pizza chain operations since 2018. o OPE to consistently monitor customer opinion through customer survey and focus group interviews. OPE to also hire employees and external consultants to develop menu to consistently rejuvenate the Brand’s offering. If FY24 and FY25 adhered to management plans, Banolim expects to be # 2 ranking in Korea: Superseding Pizza Hut Korea. Moved headquarters function to Seoul. Professional management team hired ( CEO , CFO , CMO, COO) o To expand effectively in metropolitan Seoul, main office now moved to Seoul from Daegu. CEO and CFO to be also located in Seoul. Total of 23 SG&A employees are newly hired in Seoul HQ including finance team, R&D team, and franchise sales & management team. Below new Seoul main office floor plans. o In Dec - 21, OPE hired Justin Ma as Banolim Pizza CEO. Justin was COO of Outback Steakhouse Korea (“Outback”) for 10 years and was one of the key executives that lead Outback’s stable profitable growth. Outback was the portfolio company of SkyLake Investment s, a private equity fund, and had exited in 2021. Outback eventually became #1 market player in the family restaurant segment at 80 direct stores with USD 250M revenue. o I n Jun - 2 4 , OPE hired Dong h yo Han as Banolim Pizza CFO. Dong h yo was the CFO of Sunnong Food , which is a Korean F&B manufacturing company owned by Anchor Equity Partners . o Also hired in FY23 two executives, Tim Song as CMO and Jeongmin Gwak as COO. Both have PE portfolio experience and have extensively worked for food & beverage franchising industry . Tim has experience with BBQ and O ur H ome and Jeongmin has experience with Norangtongdak and Gyochon.
